description: I accidentally walked away with my plated sando and dropped it in the midst of taking a picture, so I walked back and was so thankful to get a new one. The sandwich was really good with Tabasco sauce!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Spectacularly good service during hyper-busy Friday pre-performance dinner by a wry, seen-it-all waiter made the experience enjoyable. He coaxed cocktails and wine from the packed bar quickly, put up with our indecisions and hesitations, made spot-on suggestions, and helped guide us to excellent food.

I also loved the busy, but almost elegant, atmosphere. And, the simple "grill" food of quality fish and fries definitely has appeal as a contrast to the ueber complex offerings elsewhere. And, the sauces for the fish were wonderful as were the starters, drinks, and wine.

But, folks! Two of the four of us were served fish that was cold, solid and raw right under the grilled 1/8 inch top layer. Different fish, but both had to go back as they were way worse than merely underdone. 

In the end the two of us who had the weirdly uncooked meals had to rush through the re-fired and late-delivered course to get to our performances on time.

The Grill needs some serious training of the line cooks. Nice menu, great service, top quality food... and you serve the salmon absolutely raw? 

I like the vibe, even the too-loud noise. Great, simple menu. But, let me eat COOKED food next time.
author: Galen W.

description:
I'm still not impressed by HSG, but it's been around 3 years since my last review and they're still here. So I guess they have a good amount of return customers.  This place just isn't for me. 

I had the Shizuan chicken salad, and it came with noodles. It was just spicy chicken on top of lettuce. I'm glad it came with noodles on the side because that was the best part. This salad option seems so out of place considering the other items available. But that's why I ordered it, hoping it would stand out in flavor. It did not. I should've just ordered one of their fish options because that's what they do best. 

The other good thing about this restaurant is their wine menu. They do have a really good selection of wine. I would come back just for that.
author: Vira P.

description: Normally Hayes Street is tried and true before the Symphony however, this past Sunday saw us leaving the performance before intermission with extreme food poisoning.  The grilled halibut was watery and the substitution of a "green" sauce for the tomato salsa, well let's say, the bathroom was the substitution for what was emerging as a phenomenal performance of Stravinsky. The restaurant will be called on Tuesday.  A very poor performance by HSG.
author: Jean B.

description: When I walked in, I felt immediately comfortable. We were going to dine and then go to the opera. It seemed like the place had a discriminating clientele(was that just my imagination?). The food was very disappointing. I had the grilled opah which was dry and served with a tasteless beurre bland sauce. I asked for rice instead of French fries. They brought me a dish of the plainest white rice I've had since Uncle Ben retired. My wife ordered scallops and they were served on a bed of corn. It did not look good.
author: Billy S.

description: I wish I could rate it 4.5. But ah well... we dropped In with some old friends prior to going to a show at the Jazz Center. The interior is very nice and the ambiance is pleasant. Not loud. We had a marvelous time and the food was great. We'll be back
author: Tom M.

description: Besides always eating at Rolli Roti, we decided to try something else and that was their neighbor.  They make seafood sandwiches. The prices might be a little high for the size you get, but the quality is very good.  We got the oyster sandwich and the crab one since they are in season.  The coleslaw inside the sandwich is quite good and it is very tasty. The bacon makes it all better too.  I enjoyed both of them.  If you are willing to pay $13 to $17 dollars for it, then it is worth it :)
author: Keven W.

description:
Had lunch here recently with several business colleagues.  Overall, the lunch was fine - but nothing was particularly memorable.  
A large portion of the lunch menu were entrees in the mid to high $20's, which seemed pricey considering how many other competitive offerings there are in this neighborhood.
We had a variety of fish dishes (salmon, sole), along with salads, soup, and one burger.
All ok.  Probably won't be rushing back.
author: Lewis C.

description: Food that is always fresh and excellently prepared. The service is spot on. Folks complain that the place is "stodgy" but given the main clientele are oper and symphony attendees and tend to be more mature, I can see why a 20 something would think so. If you've got tickets, they make sure you're out on time and don't feel rushed. If you want to linger, that's ok too.
author: Tim T.

description:
Really bad. Rude bartender. We were eating at the bar and when I said that I didn't want sauce on my fish and could I replace an item, he literally ripped up the check he had written right in my face and then started a new one, his aggravation apparent.

Only white people dining that night.

Outrageous price for mediocre food.

I mean the creme brulee was burnt!
author: Ebo S.

description:
I go to the farmer's market at the Ferry building every Saturday and I have Haye's grilled salmon BLT for lunch every single time I go. I sit on the pier and eat [devour] my sandwich while enjoying the beautiful views the Pacific Ocean has to offer.

I can honestly say it's the best sandwich I've ever had. The bread is slightly crispy, the salmon is fresh and grilled to perfection, the sauce is creamy and the cabbage adds a nice crunch - it's just spot on. 

I strongly recommend this place and I will keep going there every single Saturday.
author: Sabrina B.

description: Dropped back in this place after a few years and was delighted. Quiet, intimate, excellent service, and great food. We both had the grilled fish option with the sauce selection of our choice (I got the beurre blanc but noticed they also offered Seka Hills olive oil - the best.) Fish was delicious, fresh, and cooked very well. My Nebbiolo was fantastic and affordably priced. And the dessert was divine! A scoop of cantaloupe ice with a scoop of tangy frozen yogurt - and a crisp buttery cookie to go with it. I wish we had tried more of the deserts on the menu.  They looked amazing.  Solid, delicious food in the heart of the City served by a great waitstaff. We'll be back soon!
author: Lita F.

description: Meh. Overpriced and underwhelming. I had the pollock and a side of the calamari with white beans. I've had better. The only thing that was really good was the lemon mousse dessert thing. That's it. Wouldn't go back.
author: Noor M.

description: Had an enjoyable pre-show meal here even though it was super busy. We had a nice table near the front window. We shared oysters (one was much smaller than the others). The meal was fairly expensive for what we got (1 appetizer, 2 main meals and a couple glasses of wine) but it was good meal. The service is friendly and professional and we got to our show in plenty of time.
author: Rozie W.

description: This really us my favorite for special seafood, year over year. Great martinis and seafood so fresh it still has that lovely subtle ocean sweetness. HSG is quite special in how they handle their foods. The fried oysters and soft shell crab meunière are some of my favorites! And if you are lucky in shad row season, it's amazing. HSG opens up around 7:30 when the theater crew leave for their seats. And then you get the really professional wait staff and performing arts-scene ambiance to yourself.
author: Anne F.

description:
I found HSG to be hanging in there well. 6 of us there pre-theater. Table ready, excellent service throughout the meal. 

I had looked at the online menu so I was hoping to have the sand dabs or the petrale sole on the bone with a little brown butter, but as the menu changes daily, they were not available, and after all, it was Monday, not always the best day for the freshest fish. 

2 of us had halibut, mine was perfectly grilled at med-rare, with a lemon caper sauce, excellent. 2 had grilled Maine scallops, both diners loved the accompanying corn succotash, but found the scallops lacked the flavors, seemed like they were steamed, no crispness. 1 had a nice New York steak, well prepared. 

Deserts-excellent, chocolate Sunday, creme  brûlée, apricot and cherry cobbler, all delicious. 

Corkage is buy 1, get 1 free, from then on $25.

Noise level very acceptable, no background music very welcome!
author: Dave Y.

description: We have gone there since the 1980's, typically before an opera performance with some friends. But the last two times were disappointing.  I did not want to write a negative review the prior time, when our guests became unwell, since we could not identify the cause. But the most recent time forces me. Our orders came fast, so fast that I asked if there were microwaved, which the server denied. The food was ok, but not at the level of a fine seafood restaurant. Since they focus on Opera and concert goers, their operation makes sense. But for taking guests to San Francisco seafood it's no longer an option for me.
author: Gio W.

description: We go to this restaurnt often when we attend San Francisco Symphony, Opera, Jazz Center and New Year Eve performing arts. It is conveniently located in the heart of San Francisco performing arts center. Tom was our server during New Year's Eve 2017 and he went beyond the call of duty to serve us, accommodate our dietary needs and to make sure we have an enjoyable  dinner before attending San Francisco Symphony concert. The food is delicious and healthy and the restaurnt will always accommodate dietary needs. Thank you Hays Street Grill.
author: Enci S.

description: We were there before the SF Symphony last weekend.  Great location for dinner before symphony/opera/ballet performances.  Environment is cozy, customers are tier 1 as expected.  Service can be a bit better with more attention on the clients in stead of just serving plates and can be more tolerant to young kids(perhaps younger kids are rare at this place).  Food is 6-7 out of 10, fresh, well made, but lack of surprising.   Wine list can be better with more options.  Will try again.
author: Michael K.

description: Incredibly overpriced food.  My halibut with no veggies and standard French fries was $33 dollars...let that sink in $33!!!  I should've taken a pic of the plate of mediocrity but wanted to rush out of their and forget about the absolutely underwhelming experience.  Save your money and grab a bite to eat at some of the other neighboring restaurants and cafes.  I can't believe they draw a crowd.
author: Clement C.

description: Has a neighborhood feel to it, attentive staff went out of their way to help.  Had the Opa fish, flaky and fresh.  They were put of some dishes which indicates freshness.  Scallops were perfectly cooked.  Desserts were very good.  Deserves 4.5 stars but option is not available
author: Fernando S.

description: Had the grilled salmon plate and it was amazingly delicious. Perfectly seasoned and it was so soft. The tarter sauce made it even more amazing. Quick and friendly service. Must come back to try more!!!
author: An N.

description: This place reminds me of old San Francisco (read: stuffy).  It's a bit of a zoo between 5 through 7:30 particularly before the symphony or opera.  My last meal here was really mixed - fantastic salad and dessert but the steak was really hammered. Service was also a tad slow but it was really busy.
author: Andrew S.

description: What a pleasure it is to enjoy a simply decorated, warm atmosphere in which friendly, attentive service and delicious food prevail against the neighborhood's tide of icy hipsterism. My petrale sole with chanterelles was an understated delight. This is what being a dinner guest without fuss is all about. My wife and I intend to become regulars here.
author: Eric P.

description:
It's convenient for sure. Fairly busy. Crowd skewed 65+. Service attentive and fast. Food mediocre but decent. Expensive, surprisingly because the food was so simple and straightforward. Got us out in 45 min to make It to Hamilton. Wouldn't come here again or recommend it unless you're going to a show nearby. 

Good not great.. and overpriced. 

.5 star+ for the heavy hand with wines by the glass! They sure know how to pour! The Pinot was nice and not expensive.
author: Shanna N.

description: We picked this restaurant due to its close proximity to the New Conservatory Theater. We made on-line reservations and we were immediately seated upon arrival. The waiter asked if we were going to a show and what time it started. Service was fast. The food was very good. We had the sword fish, pork chop, steak, and crab cakes. All meals were delishious with big servings. We started with the warm goat cheese salad.  We finished with coffee and chocolate cake.  Our glasses were never empty. The staff was friendly.  We made the show with plenty of time to spare. We would go back here.
author: P G.

description:
This place knows what it is and does it well. No, it's not a foodie spot with a stunning menu of fresh and new tastes, but it has class and a pleasant ambience, the service is very good, and the food and menu are both solid. Frankly I found it refreshing to get truly polite and attentive service--many of the SF foodie spots really fall down on that part of the experience, many of them have a staff that makes you feel that you are lucky to be there, not as if they are thrilled to have you. 

We had a very tasty fall salad with fresh fruit and radicchio and smoked trout, my crab cakes with French fries were quite good and my wife was very happy with her opah and greens dish. The Brussels sprouts side with ginger and mustard seed was cooked perfectly and made a very nice complement to the meals. 

The highlight was the flourless chocolate cake, delicious with perfect texture. Left us feeling happy to pay the slightly heavy price tag for a very pleasant evening.
author: Kelly W.

description:
I seem to always have a bad time here since it opened in 1979: either the fish is overcooked, the sides are too salty or heavily sauced, or the service is terrible. None of these things happen all at once, but it is disheartening. Still, the provender was great in the beginning, when Paul Johnson, I believe, supplied the fish, and I have hope.
I wonder if Patricia Unterman is still a part owner. If so, she should come here incognito and see what is going on.
author: George T.

description:
Fantastic all the way around! 
We were greeted and seated promptly at the time of our reservation. 
We had a number of questions about the menu; our server Tom was very patient and kind making suggestions and accommodations for our requests. 
The fish is all fresh, the menu changes daily.
The halibut and opah were both prepared beautifully, beurre blanc sauce and lemon caper butter both added just the right flavor. 
We will definitely return
author: Kim K.

description:
What happened to this SF LANDMARK LEGENDARY RESTAURANT?  Haven't been here in years. And was not impressed. Food was just ok. And service was a little weird. Waiter was very lukewarm and almost mad at us when we asked questions.  Fish was over cooked and veggies were unimpressive.

Overall not worth the price.  #disappointed too bad - I was hoping to have a nice meal. Really wanted to write a good review.
author: David M.

description: Exquisit and delicious yet uncomplicated and wholesome at the same time. Located just behind the Opera House and Davies Symphony Hall, the walls are adorned by pictures of visiting performers from around the world. I've been coming here since the 80's. It's fine dining that's not overly expensive.
author: Ray D.

description: good food, great service esp. when you're going to a show.  Would go again but only when going to a nearby show.
author: Sue C.

description:
In a changing neighborhood, there are few things that are still the same. Hayes Street Grill is one of them. 

This is the place you come to when you want a nice quiet lunch. A business meeting or a family meal before the opera, symphony or ballet. The menu is pretty standard.

We came here for a holiday work luncheon, you can call in advance or make an Open Table reservation. All 11 of us arrived at the same time and were seated in the main dining room. Service was quick and friendly.

About a little less than half the table ordered the dungeness crab special which was served cold and came with a side salad with pickled beets. I asked for a side of warm butter and my meal was complete. 

The other half ordered the Steak with potatoes, the salmon and a couple other dishes. Everyone seemed to like their lunch and then it was on to dessert. 

I picked the creme brûlée, which my ultimate cheat dessert. It came with a burnt top and completely cold. A total fail. Creme brûlée should be cold, yet the top is supposed to be hot and sugary. Not cold, burnt and disappointing. 

We all enjoyed our meals overall. If I were to do it over, I would have went with the Hot fudge sundae instead.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Went back to Hayes Street Grill a few weeks ago, and again ordered the deep fried Oysters. It doesn't get any better than this folks. The best I've ever had. Please go on Sunday, Monday or Tuesday so you can experience Chef Adrian Yerena. He is by far one of the top ten best chefs in San Francisco.
author: Vince F.

description:
A friend, my honey, and I recently treated my parents to a dinner and theater night. (This restaurant is in a great location for any performances near Civic Center -- SF Symphony, Orpheum, etc.) Our show was at 7:30 PM so we opted for an early, 5:30 PM, dinner reservation. It turns out that my dad came here many moons ago (pre-Yelp) and he said that it was just as great as he fondly remembered.

They accept online reservations although I wasn't able to book a table for our group of five online. I'm not quite sure why because I called and got a reservation no problem. They called a few days prior to confirm, which I appreciated since I didn't have an e-mail confirmation or anything. 

We started with a round of drinks and oysters. The oysters were good, nothing particularly memorable about them. Each of us also ordered a salad, except for my honey who went with the lentil soup. I stole a bite and I think he made a good choice, especially for a chilly winter night. For my entree I finally decided on the scallops, served over kale polenta and delicata squash. I thoroughly enjoyed this dish, and while I would order it again, I got a bite of my friend's crab cake and that bite was SO GOOD. Pretty much all crab, with little filler. Upon return, it will be a tough decision between the scallops and crab cakes. We also ordered a side of brussels sprouts to share. These were a bit disappointing because, although they were cooked just fine, I prefer the crispy bits of roasted sprouts. 

Service was fabulous, from the moment I made the reservation to our exit.
author: Emily J.

description:
Had dinner there last night before the opera.  It's a shame this place isn't better, given its location.  Service was very good.  My entree (paella) was brought out cold.  Send it back and got a hot one.  Reallyt isn't a paella in the true definition.  More just spicy seafood, chorizo and rice.  Decent but not great.
My friend had the salmon and liked it.
They have a good wine list and selection of wines-by-the-glass.
All in all, its an okay place near the civic center. Not great and probably not worth the price.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: We were there last night 09/16/2017  for dinner, $$$ small Champagne Gloria Ferrer wine was 12$ each, my crabs cakes, I found crabs  shells inside it. $176.00 a meal for two! We won't be back because the food was not up the price we paid for, nah! Never again!
author: Joe V.

description: Really terrible service--waiter totally unwilling to answer questions about the menu (ie, "It's all fresh, so it's all good." and non-helpful comments like that). After he dropped our meals off, he never came back. We finally had to track down the host to get our check in time to get to the opera. We mentioned to the host what terrible service we had, and instead of apologizing and urging us to come back (the simple, no-cost way to be gracious), he argued with us and said we finished our meal too soon and that is why the waiter never came back to ask us how the food was and take dirty plates away. We just walked away--what kind of place charges $30 for a meal and then blames the customer for the bad service? Don't waste your time--so many better places nearby where you can get treated with a modicum of respect and courtesy.
author: Julie A.

description: Loved Hayes Street Grill! My wife and I walked over here after a matinee at Orpheum Theater. We had a reservation and were promptly seated. We loved the menu as they have an assortment of fresh fish. They are also famous for their french fries and the Creme Brulee. We shared the HSG Chopped Salad with Beets, Radishes, Walnuts, Blue Cheese. I had the Petrale Sole with mushrooms and my wife had the salmon. Everything was exceptional as well as our waiter, Sherman. He was attentive and steered us in the right direction on what we ordered. The Creme Brulee was fantastic! We'll be back to as we absolutely loved Hayes Street Grill!
author: Len S.

description:
The crab cakes were terrible, very mushy inside with mostly fillers. The grilled Alaskan halibut was fresh, but too bad the sauces were boring. The best dish was the french fries.

The service was so so. We ordered a bottle of wine, our waiter only poured us wine once.  Our main entrees were served without any utensils.

Definitely does not warrant the high prices.
author: TopCat W.

description:
Mediocre food and awful service.

We had a reservation last night before a performance at SF Jazz Center.  Our server was obviously having a bad day, and was surly from the start.  About 45 seconds after giving him our order, my wife asked if she might change to a different appetizer.  "You gotta be kidding me" he snarled, and walked away.  The people at the next table shared our bewilderment.

I went to the front of the house and asked to speak to the manager.  I was told there was none...that all the servers were, in effect, managers...whatever that means.

Service throughout was curt and perfunctory.  Upon presenting our bill, he offered an apology.  Too little too late in our opinion.  Our dinner experience had been ruined...but our evening luckily redeemed by a great SF Jazz performance.  We hadn't been here in several years and thought we'd give it another try.  Never again.
author: Mark S.

description:
This is where political junkies, lawyers and businessman ponder lofty ideas of conquest and world  domination. The location also attracts performing arts patrons and neighborhood locals alike. Good luck finding parking if you attempt to come in your own car.
.
At $5 per shrimp the $15 Oregon Bay Shrimp Louie was expensive but delicious as a starter. In the past I have asked to have this prepared as a main dish and for a price I was graciously accommodated, thank you HSG.
.
For $28.00 the Grilled Niman Pork Chop fell very short. Was this a Jenny Craig meal? The smashed potatoes arrived as plain as possible. I requested gravy of any kind and found none exist. The accompanying carrots came steamed or blanched, also quite plain. If it were not for the minuscule apple cherry chutney I would not have been able to choke down this very dry over cooked waste of a pork chop. 
.
The $32.00 fish filet was an embarrassment. I felt like we should have returned the entire meal less the Louie. The filet arrived looking like someone had taken a one third potion bite right out of it?
.
The Hot Fudge Sundae and coffee were nothing extraordinary.
.
The plusses are its location, their full bar and the service which has always been not only friendly but very professional.
author: Caesar A.

description: Went there before the symphony.  Had the calamari salad, beat salad, bass and fried oyster.  The food was OK but the ambiance and plates etc were like if you were in a diner.  For the price they charge, I would go some where else in Hayes.  There are so many more better restaurants in Hayes.
author: John R.

description: I think the only reason this place is still in business is because of its close proximity to the performing arts center.  We had reservations for 5:15 before the ballet. Everything felt dated, from the restaurant's look to the wait staff and menu. We sat looking at the uninspiring menu for 15 minutes before being greeted. The fish dishes all came grilled with the choice of one of several sauces. What chef does this in 2017??  After being told that they were already sold out of the steak at 5:30 (my date doesn't eat fish), with a very unprofessional excuse, we left and ate elsewhere.  We were so relieved to have had a fabulous dinner around the corner and still made the ballet on time.
author: Jennifer A.

description: HSG is reliable for pre and post theater or concert meals but offers nothing new or interesting for this diner.  Of course, that's the way their more frequent guests want it I guess.  We've eaten there four times in the last year and are likely to return for the convenience of the location more than the food or drink. The cocktails are well made but not generously poured.  Wines by the glass offered some interesting whites. Food portions are modest in size and may be too small for some and therefore expensive. $16 for a tasty beet salad is pricey especially given four razor thin rounds of red. Ubiquitous French fries were limp on Thursday evening, and I should have sent them back.  A side dish of kale to accompany my perfectly cooked halibut was almost tasteless.  The main dish plate did not look appealing at all: grayish white halibut on a white plate with a tiny tin of beurre blanc on the side.  A special dessert crumble was delicious as was a lemon custard served with fresh blueberries. Service was as always well-informed, professional, and efficient.  Would we recommend HSG to to others? We have with the kind of caveats outlined above.
author: Stu H.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised when I walked in and did not have to wait to be seated on a Friday before the symphony, but after eating there it's clear. I ordered the sea bass, and got this tiny sliver of fish. The fact that it came out after 5 minutes makes me think that it wasn't freshly grilled. 

The fries were cold, as was the apricot "crisp". Wasn't nearly worth the price we paid for the dinner.
author: Darryl B.

description: The food is great the service is even better.  We were in a packed restaurant and everything was on time, the right temp and cooked perfectly.  Party of 6 arriving at 5:30pm and out in time for a 7:30pm concert to see Lyle Lovett and Vince Gil.  Not 5 stars because I like a big chunk of ice in my old fashion not ice cubes.
author: Regan J.

description: A group of twelve of us came by for a reservation on 6.26.17. Waitstaff was accommodating and attentive, and the drinks and food were perfect. Grateful to have Hayes Street Grill and their excellent people in the neighborhood.
author: Cliff S.

description:
I have never been shamed for having a life-threatening allergy until last night. Our dinner plans for Lers Ros across the street, went sideways and we decided to try Hayes Street Grill.  I let the server there know I'm deathly allergic to peppercorns and I'd need my fish cooked in a pan instead of on the grill due to cross contamination.  She told me that I'm an inconvenience to the kitchen so no adaptation could be made.  Wow.  Ouch.  I don't choose to be allergic to certain foods.  If we hadn't already started drinking our wine, we would've left.  I had to settle for french fries and brussels sprouts.  I felt really humiliated.
Don't go if you have any kind of allergies.  They are NOT allergy friendly in the slightest.
author: Vicky T.

description: One star for the salad. This was an old favorite, but it has gone down hill. The mature d' was rude and stuffy, the waiter was stoned, the food was mediocre. From the starters to dessert and coffee, it was all, less than impressive.
author: Rinda C.

description:
This is not a good place! First for a little piece of fish and french fries cost $40!
Too over priced! For 3 people the bill cost over 200 dollars! After the food I felt bad and the food, the quality was bad! Our server was too busy and took us more then 2 hours for the food to come. I felt the place was squished and felt cramped like they would just place tables at each spot.
author: Urs C.

description: Always a treat. Good but pricey food. Professional staff. You really need reservations although I've been able to get a table for two on the spur of the moment.
author: Matthew J.

description:
The stars must have been aligned......
1 .We parked directly across the street from the restaurant in the only spot available. 

2 .Because the Jameson whiskey was near the end of the bottle, the bartender poured all of it into my requested drink.  It was at least a triple pour on the rocks.

3. The Oregon Bay Shrimp Louie with avocado, Iacopi peas, radishes, and farm egg  for $12 was an excellent starter.  So fresh.so tasty-- and generously sized!

4. I took our server's recommendation and ordered the paella for my main entree.
The paella included wild shrimp, Hog Island clams, PEI mussels, house chorizo, and saffron rice for $ 26.  It was authentic tasting and truly a comfort food.  The restaurant makes there own chorizo.  The spiciness is there but in no way overwhelms the dish.  Very, very nice!

5.  All of the staff that we dealt with were wonderful.  There was no rushed feeling but then again, it was a pretty quiet Sunday evening.

I would hope that the next time I go to Hayes Street Grill, the experience that we had repeats itself.
author: Thomas D.

description: We used to go to this restaurant all the time but haven't for many years.  I was disappointed although the tables are nice, we had a good corner and could talk with our group of 4, and that's the good part.  Service was very slow although we had told the maitre'd that we had a show at 7:30pm so needed to be out by 7:15pm.  We asked for a waiter several times and was always assured that he would be right there.   We waited.  Finally, he arrived and the service was good but then we were rushing.  I expected the seafood to be good but was very disappointed with the petrale sole; my husband had the "king" salmon but knows it wasn't "king".  He was not pleased with his meal, although he liked his calamari appetizer and my avocado & shrimp salad was nice.  We didn't have time for desserts.  Hays Street Grill needs some work on their service and food.  Our bill was $400 for 4 people including 2 bottles of wine.  Gluten free options are very limited.
author: Marianne K.

description: The tall waiter from Dr Phibes  was hurried rude and inattentive.The food was very good had a schracha  salad my friends had burgers .Good quality food .The atmosphere had the potential for being great but do NOT go there looking to get in and out.One dollar cover just to get in for the unpleasureness of dealing with the waiter of course!
author: Erick W.

description: I have loved the Hayes Street Grill since I first went in 1980. How many restaurants can keep up the quality for that long? Or put you on a list and actually call you when they have soft shell crabs or shad roe in season. I mean, who even KNOWS about shad roe anymore, this side of a Nero Wolfe mystery novel? While Hayes is convenient and mostly caters to pre-theater and pre-symphony goers, it's even better for rest of us more low-brow types. Why? Because the kitchen is less rushed and the service is better. They have the freshest fish (it changes daily) and do very little to it, except to cook it perfectly. I have never had to send anything back to the kitchen ever--and I have been known to be a little princess-y in the worst of times. Did I mention the sauces! Order the peanut sauce, (and save it for their thin bistro-style fries). But the beurre blanc and lemon caper are nothing to sneer at. What to order? Always the sand dabs if they're on the menu, or the grilled calamari if you're feeling minimalist. The hog island sweet water oysters are the stuff of food fantasies, always fresh and briny and are so perfect with champagne by the glass. This place could so easily be snooty given the posh clientele and the location, but they are always accommodating. They'll kill me for saying this, but they will let you change the set-ups--the fish is always paired with such interesting combinations of interesting retro vegetables like succotash or butter beans with unexpected but simple sauces but sometimes you just HAVE to have the fingerling potatoes and trumpet mushrooms with thyme that comes with the petrale sole, when you're having the scallops. They will let you switch. But maybe they won't let me do it anymore, after this review. But they always go that extra mile. Last time I was there, my dining companion couldn't find a parking place, and was 25 minutes late circling the neighborhood looking for a spot. The maitre d' actually moved a sign in front of the restaurant for drop-offs and let him park there. Talking about saving an evening! This place is perfect. My only complaint? They took the baby poussin off the menu. Oh yeah, and the hot fudge sundae is irresistible, and I hate myself for finishing it. Every time.
author: jaan u.

description:
Rediscovered an SF Gem

Had not been here for a long time.  This place is a landmark.  Had a geat experience and it's definitely back on our rotation of favorite places  The fish was as fresh as it could be and was cooked perfectly.  The servers could not have been friendlier.  The night we were there they had a killer potato leek soup and their Caesar Salad is way above average and very good.  We had assumed it was an older and stodgy place but were very happy to discover that this classic place is still a gem. Prices very reasonable as well and the location in Hayes Vallye is incredible.  We will be back.
author: L R.

description: I was at HSG last night.  It has always been a favorite.  My sand dabs were superb as were the accompanying pommes frites but the service was mediocre thru the whole meal.  We had to ask for more water, more butter, etc. The drinks were mixed up.  I expected more.
author: Carolyn M.

description:
Love the great staff at Hayes Street Grill. They go above and beyond, when needed, to accommodate special needs. For us last week, that meant figuring out a way to make space for a group of 12 on just 2 days notice. 

The food was delicious; the servers friendly, helpful and flexible for squeezing through narrow spaces. Felt like we were at a friendly neighborhood restaurant even though we 12 were from many parts of it he Bay Area.
author: LH M.

description: Unfortunately, HSG hasn't maintained its standard of excellence. Tonight five of us dined for a birthday celebration, pre SF Symphony dinner. My salmon was incorrectly cooked with its top uneven as if they had pulled the top layer off. Two of our party had halibut: one serving was a good 1/3 less than the other. We had to ask for most everything rather than the server anticipating dining guests needs. Water and sourdough are available upon request. We asked for both, bread was served without bread plates. When we asked for Balsamic vinegar for sourdough, red wine vinegar was served. Because the birthday boy didn't order a dessert, the server said/did nothing--very disappointing to his wife. Next time I'm in the area, I'll go to Absinthe.
author: m m.

description: Good place in SF to grab lunch. The burger was really good and came with a bit of a salad which is nice. Drinks were good. They have a nice side bar which is great for happy hour drinks. Staff was friendly and attentive. It's a bit pricey, thus the loss of a star, but I would go back to this place.
author: Dylan B.

description: Simply overpriced for the quality and quantity of food. I got the salmon with fries for $30. The salmon was tasty and cooked well and the fries were phenomenal, just a small portion. I'd come here just for the fries if that wasn't weird. The dishes should be about $4-$5 cheaper and this might be a nice old-timer spot to frequent. The service was slow but it was a busy Friday dinner crowd so I won't hold it against them.
author: Gonzalo S.

description:
I visited HSG for lunch on a Wednesday.  I started my meal with a vegetable soup that was a special for that day.  This is my second time visiting for lunch.  Last December, I had a delightful dinner at the grill.  On all visits and as with this time, I was pleased with the food and service.

The soup was so comforting.  It came out at just the right temperature, which is how I wanted it -- not too lukewarm but not too unbearably hot.  The seasoning was spot on.  It was a water-based soup that complemented the main course.  The portion was appropriate for lunch. 

My main course was a white fish (I believe) paired with a vegetable medley, and topped with a divine pesto-based sauce that I couldn't get enough of!  The fish was cooked perfectly.  The medley had an assortment of cooked vegetables that brought out of the fish's flavor.  And the pesto sauce ... well I would've licked the plate clean of it if there was no one else in the restaurant.

Service, like usual, is above average.  The staff is efficient and the cooks know what they're doing. 

Also, HSG's caesar salad is one of the best in city, along with its french fries :-)

HSG has a dedicated following and I can see why.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Cameron M.

description:
This old reliable has, sadly, slipped.  Opening Hog Island oysters were impeccably fresh, and the romaine salad with blue cheese appetizer was just fine.  But the entrees:  $32 crabcakes were tasteless (I assumed the crab was fresh, but tasted frozen), accompanied by a small portion of arugala and a small portion of French fries; the grilled scallops were tasteless as well, accompanied by flavorless mashed celery root and a dab of spinach.

Deserts were lackluster; the chocolate cake was lacking flavor, as was the pear tart.  The chocolate sundae was simple, but good.

Service is ok-plus, and wine prices are very fair, but the food is expensive and has become lacking in flavor.  Prices are high, portions are small, the food has become lackluster (last several visits), and the value has, sadly, become poor.  Too bad; this had been a longtime "go-to" place for a reliable pre-symphony/ballet/opera dining experience.
author: Local R.

description:
The food was delicious. We split a soft-shell crab as an appetizer, and had oysters and scallops for entrees.

The service was terrible:

1) they were very understaffed (I realize that Frankie Valli was performing at the symphony hall a block away at 8pm so everyone came in for dinner at the same time, but it's not like that was a surprise that they couldn't plan for, or even something that doesn't happen probably twice a week).

2) there was a reasonable variety of wine on the menu, but with very little description (in particular, the French wine didn't list the regions, just the vineyards - which makes it hard for a non-sommelier to know what they're ordering). When asked about the wine the waiter knew nothing (that's fair enough) but also said that the place wasn't fancy enough to have a sommelier. If you don't have descriptive menus, knowledgeable waiters *or* a sommelier, how are people supposed to know what they're ordering? (We resorted to Google to locate a reputable Burgundy from the list).

3) they slipped an extra charge for a non-existent cappuccino on to the check.

I don't think I'd go back - at their price range they should be providing better service.
author: Paul M.

description: This place is over priced and the food is not good. I got the crab cakes for $32-- bad quality. With all the great restaurants in Hayes Valley, go somewhere else. When I asked the waiter what he recommends for an entree, he said "French fries" yikes.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Pro's: Service was friendly and quick even though restaurant was crowded. 

Con's:  Food underwhelming and just average.  Between the four of us none of the meals had any sort of presentation value to them.  You order fish then you get fish, fries, and a couple leaves scattered about your plate.  You order sausage then you get two sausages, fries, and a couple leaves scattered about your plate.  We got the steak but there was no sizzle.  Food was good but plain.  Meh.
author: Ray S.

description: We have been twice, before music but worth going just for dinner.  Our favorite restaurant among several good ones in Hayes Valley.  This time, trout toast and caesar salad to start, then lightly grilled scallops and a plain grilled fish, with fries.  All delicious.  Service first rate, friendly and quick.  Old fashioned San Francisco atmosphere.  They often take reservations only on the telephone before 7pm.
author: John C.

description:
We were attending a comedy show at the Symphony hall, so wanted to find a place close by to have dinner before.  You can't really get any closer than this place.  
It's very old school and caters to the arts crowd who are going to the symphony or the opera.  Great people watching.  The food was good, but not really worth the price.  Service wasn't all that great-we got more attention from the guy filling our water glasses than our waiter.
author: Penny C.

description:
Hayes Street Grill is in many ways, same as Tadich Grill. Steeped in history, serves fresh seafood and has expensive entrees for the simplicity you get. 

At the heart of the menu is the grilled fish with some type of sauce and french fries. I wasn't feeling the fish the night we came in after bar hopping, so the burger it was. Estancia farms' grass fed beef is a generous patty topped with cheddar and comes with all the trimmings. The french fries were good and hot off the fryer, but in no ways life changing. The bf's flatiron steak with mustard butter and balsamic onions were just so-so. However, the fried calamari was excellent.

What stands out within the sparsely decorated dining room is the service. These are genuine folks who are helpful and truly serve you with a smile. I can always appreciate faultless service like this. 

Hayes Street Grill is close to Davies Symphony Hall and a block away from the Opera House, but with competitor Absinthe down the street, I'd be hard pressed not to go there instead.
author: Janice C.

description:
I think it's been at least 20 years since I'd eaten here, and a friend suggested we go. Was pleasantly surprised that the food was excellent, and better than I'd remembered it. Service  very good and quite cordial, except that we were never offered any bread with the meal. Not sure if that was an oversight or considered an extra food item here. Would have been a 5 star review if we'd been served some bread after our orders were taken.

I had a salad with fig, melon, and yogurt dressing which was superb. I'd gladly order that salad again and recommend it. Also had the Pork Chop which was generously sized and cooked perfectly. The meat was tender and flavorful--about as good as a pork chop gets.

We did not have desserts, but no dessert needed. The two "dirty" gin martinis I had before and during dinner were well crafted.
author: IQuack D.

description: Distinctly dated and mediocre, will not return. You walk in to a restaurant that hasn't been updated since the mid-90's with stucco walls, tacky fixtures and tables stuffed together. SO and I both had the grilled fish which is basically just that--fish grilled without any particular technique or care served with the bland fries you get at any chain like applebees. Service was impersonal and hurried. This feels like a famous steakhouse that has coasted too long on its laurels except, was this place ever famous or good?
author: N A.

description:
This shouldn't be a $$$ sign restaurant, $ sounds better. A very important occasion in my life, my husband decides to try it, since they cater to the symphony hall. Well guess what! They need to change location, because they're riding on the other restaurants coattails. I've ordered the fried oysters for my entree, boy i tasted nothing.... It was so bland, it had no spice, no taste. My husband didn't care much for it. Strange combination for the appetizers, beans and shrimp , fries with everything.Wow!!!

Good God i can prepare this better than this chef,i'm French, i know what i'm talking about. I told myself maybe the dessert might compensate. Well the chocolate cake had an amazing and flourish introduction but it was a couple days old and the decor is long overdue. 

Wood chairs and a some pictures on the wall depicting opera singers and glass on the table with a white sheet of paper for kids to draw on. Seriously!!!
The presentation for the meal was boring.Overpriced to booth, and you need a 4 weeks reservation to try this place.
 Seriousement,ca vas pas la tete?C'est deguelasse.Absynthe is more refined and the decor is beautiful.
Never again. I do not recommend this place. Do try another, like the Boxing Room.
author: Fabienne U.

description:
I came here with a group of about 15 people to celebrate my co-workers graduation.  We had reservations and were seated promptly upon our arrival.  The service throughout the lunch was very good.  There was always someone filling our glasses with either water or wine : )

My co-workers wife had a pre-established menu for our party.  As an appetizer I had the summer squash soup with basil.  It was light and perfect for a summer day, but nice and warm for the chilly afternoon in SF.  For the main course I ordered the grilled San Diego yellow tail with caper, lemon, butter sauce with a side of broccoli di cicco.  The yellow tail was seasoned well and was delicious.  The broccoli was unfortunately overcooked.  For dessert I shared the buttermilk panna cotta with rhubarb strawberry compote.  The compote was nice blend of tangy and sweet.  The food and service was an excellent experience, and I will definitely consider coming here in the future.
author: Yvette G.

description: Our waitress was Jules and she was great. Very pleasant and helpful. Now to the menu. Started with the warm goat cheese salad and the mushroom celery soup, both were fantastic. I had the San Diego Opah and my wife had the Paella. The Opah was fresh and delicious. The Paella was good, but stick with the fresh fish. All around a very pleasant pre opera restaurant experience. Thanks Jules.
author: Raymond U.

description:
Had the paella. Fish was scarce and mussels and clams way overcooked. Ceasar salad very ordinary. Others had the halibut which looked like a  better choice. Fries were great. This used to be a  great restaurant.  Now very expensive and not worth it.  Arlequin, down the street, is better and less than half the price. Disappointing experience
.
author: Alan B.

description: Good service. Classic power player lunch spot. Lawyers, politicians, and theater folks.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Not worth the money.......

I was there a week ago before attending a show....I saw the prices on the menu....very high...but, it IS San Francisco...and I do not mind paying high prices for high quality food...

Unfortunately...I have had better meals at Red Lobster...the food was bland...portions small....and service was so-so...and I guess they don't offer A/C, because we were all hot and could not wait to get out.....left there and thought about the bill I had just paid instead of the food....

Across the street I could have saved $100 and ate much better....

I will not be back
author: Brandon C.

description: Was so disappointed.  Came here before a show and it was just not good.  Bland, boring and tired food.
author: Barbara B.

description:
3 1/2* Hayes Street Grill
320 Hayes
SF 94102
Happening place, high noise level; tables are close together; recommend reservations
Near the Davies Symphony & Opera House; very convenient for performances
Hostess was less than gracious
Also, a lot of children were with parents and grandparents (some naughty; some nice) provided for a less than optimal ambience; some parents can be rather inconsiderate, do you think?
Nice wines by the glass; also have beer; and full bar
Great Caesar salad; I even loved the croutons which I normally don't eat
Ono was good, but the sausages (served with arugula salad and fries) were the best
Waiter Justine was friendly
Bus person Luis was excellent and did all the heavy lifting in terms of food service
Very nice sourdough house bread
Delish apple crisp dessert
Nice after dinner coffee; but coffee drink from the bar was not served hot, try warm
author: Rosquete B.

description: I had to update my review because I just had lunch at Hayes Street Grill and loved it. I ordered the grilled shrimp salad and it was done to perfection. My lunch companion had the crab salad, which she loved. (I've eaten here for dinner and have been underwhelmed, but it might be because I ordered fish prepared in a rather boring way, so, not surprisingly, the fish tasted boring.) I'm still knocking off one star, though, until they dust off the decor in this place. It's like eating at the Ivy in LA, which is frozen in time.
author: Morris R.

description:
It's hard not to really enjoy Hayes Street Grill if you find yourself there, invited - or urged to go - by others who love it.  However, it's easy to justify going elsewhere to eat high quality, well prepared seafood.  Here's why...

HSG has lineage and credibility. They've been doing simply prepared fish long  before it was chic to do that. Kudos to Patty Unterman and her partner and team. 

I've always found several items on the menu to enjoy, varying from clean to rich, crispy to raw... so you'll have choices.

Another plus can be service, although I've sometimes felt it was a little phoned in (waiters of another era too used to doing it their way, or just walking around on automatic), it's equally likely you'll land someone ultra professional, warm and helpful. So it's a very mixed bag for service given the prices.  Today my father celebrated a very big birthday. HSG is an old favorite so we went.  At the end of our meal, the barman, Rodil, treated Dad like visiting royalty. Wow, that was lovely. To make a very elderly man feel special when he hasn't been a regular for years, and you're not the server getting the tip... that was some classy on-the-fly service. Service was competent today otherwise, but it can lack warmth. It's very personality dependent and I sort of wish that weren't the case. 

Prices, portions, value, execution.  Here's where HSG has trouble keeping my business - although it will always be a sentimental favorite.  The prices are very, very high relative to things like portion (modest by American or even European bistro standards). Prices relative to execution, also feel high. While execution is generally good, there are mistakes that shouldn't come out of a kitchen this seasoned (A far too heavily dressed Ceasar salad - and I'm a dressing nut so I practically never fault for heavy dressing; Fish that was sold as being medium rare, purposely underdone in the middle arriving instead well done; Prices - yikes... $28 for a small piece of fish and one side).

Pluses, besides usually very well executed fish and often good service...  Location, Wine List, Generous pour of a single glass of wine (at least today it seemed so), and desserts...

Ok, stop the presses and open a pastry shop for the woman making the sweets.  To quote my gourmande 11 year old.. "That is the best chocolate cake I have ever eaten."  She's probably right. It was *that* good.

I'd happily give HSG 4 stars if any one of those negatives went away, but I've been often enough in the last 3 years to see a pattern:  Uneven service, varying from chilly and aloof (I don't mean traditionally professional and restrained, I mean chilly and aloof), to warm and fabulous (Rodil: You added so much value to our lunch today, I felt ok about spending $240 for 3 lunches with tip).  The prices are the really weighty issue. It's so, so hard to justify that big a ticket on an entree these days - in my opinion.  If you're going to charge that much per plate, there needs to be more consistency of service and execution.

Still... a sentimental favorite with awesome french fries, killer sweets, occasionally lovely people.  Worth trying again to see if they up their game, or if they're resting on their laurels.  I hope it's not the latter.  Hayes Street Grill has no practical reason to fall down on its reputation for good food, well executed.  Maybe there needs to be more attention paid by ownership?  Are we getting tired, overstretched maybe?  

Let's hope they can pull it out and lift it up.  I'd certainly like to bring that 3 Stars up to a 4 or 5.  Rodil and the chocolate cake alone *almost* justify that... just not quite.

Good luck. :)
author: Juliana C.

description:
First impression:
Me: "Mom, this looks like a retirement home"
Mom: "Yeah, very 50s or early 60s decor in here"
Me (in my head): "Why is it so silent in here?"

During the Appetizers:
** Salad with Beets, Blue Cheese, Radishes and Walnuts ($12) ** 
Me: "Mom, can you taste this? I don't know what it is"
Mom: "I think it's the blue cheese...too bad you can't taste anything else"

** Smoked Trout on Toast with Pear Salad ($11ish) **
Me (in my head): "Mayonnaise with a bit of trout wasn't what I was expecting"
Mom (in her head): "Well at least the pears are ripe"

During Dinner:
** Scallops with Celery-Fennel Puree, Peas, and Fava Leaves ($28) **
Me (in my  head): "Hmm interesting mashed potatoes. Do these scallops taste weird or do I not know what scallops taste like? At least the peas are good"

**  Grilled Halibut with Avocado-Cilantro-Poblano Salsa ($30) **
Mom (in her head): "Wow. This halibut is bland. At least it's not overcooked"

Immediately after Leaving:
Mom: "I didn't think that was very good, did you?"
Me: "It was old people food!! Just like eating at Grandma and Grandpa's retirement home"
Both: Proceed to laugh hysterically all the way home about how awful the food was.

After Reviewing the Menu After the Meal:
Me: "Omg that was celery-fennel puree not mashed potatoes! No wonder it was so weird!"

Recap - This is a restaurant for people with no teeth who like really bland food and enjoy feeling like they're eating at a retirement home. The only redeeming fact was the pears were ripe. But for the price pretty much anywhere would have been better.
author: Talia G.

description:
This has been on our list of mental bookmarks for years.  We were meeting our Filoli group at the SFJAZZ Center for a concert Thursday night.  Because Alan was facing possible back surgery, we didn't get tickets when the others did and when he was improved enough to cancel the surgery I didn't think to get tickets nor to join our friends at Absinthe.  I scored tickets at the last minute and Absinthe couldn't accommodate us.  Alan reserved us a table at Hayes Street Grill, where we ate à deux.

We walked into a relatively empty restaurant, though the bar in front was pretty full.  We were greeted and seated at a table for two in the middle of the restaurant and given menus.  We requested water and bread, which were brought.  There's a cover charge of $1.50 per person for this, which is fine.  The bread was dense, grainy and lovely.  We decided to share a salad, hearts of romaine w/ buttermilk-blue cheese dressing and watermelon radishes.  Alan was disappointed to find only three choices of fish to choose from, a Washington steelhead salmon, local swordfish and something else we can't remember.  He ordered the swordfish grilled, w/ a lemon caper butter.  I ordered the grilled Niman pork chop, which came w/ mashed potatoes, carrots and apple-cherry chutney.  I noticed on the menu that it was possible to substitute braised greens for the fries that came w/ the fish, so I asked our server if it would be possible to substitute the greens for my mashed potatoes.  It was, so that's what I did.

The salad arrived unsplit, so we divided it.  It was delicious, the dressing flavorful yet light.  When the mains arrived, Alan's fish and fries were excellent, though he didn't care for the sauce.  He requested catsup for the fries and tartar sauce for the fish, which he preferred.  My pork chop, carrots and chutney arrived on one plate, w/ the greens in a separate dish.  Everything was delicious and I was very pleased to have changed to the greens.  The restaurant filled as we ate and by the time we were ready to leave pretty much every table was filled and there was a line at the door.  The crowd trended toward our age or older, w/ a few 30- or 40-somethings mixed in.  It was a comfortably old school yet upscale place.  The walls are covered w/ autographed photos of celebrities.  It was a nice dinner and then a short walk to the jazz center.
author: Toni M.

description:
We went for dinner on a Saturday night, with 7:30 p.m. reservations - after the Symphony crowd had finished dinner, and the restaurant was very quiet.  Had a nice round table for the five of us and good service from Jack.  As others have mentioned the seafood isn't great.  I chose the grilled skate which was seems to have been grilled filleted and was consequently rather dry despite my requesting it medium rare.  My wife's fish dish was also rather dry despite requesting medium cooking.  All our dishes were served without vegetables - only french fries.

The wine list is good and prices aren't ridiculous.
author: mark j.

description:
I love old school places and I suppose a place that opened in 1979 is "old school" these days. Therefore, Hayes Street Grill is just my speed.

My partner had the salmon which was fresh and perfectly cooked with a lemon-caper sauce on the side. I thought it was odd that the fish dishes come with French fries but I tried some and they are really good fries! I opted for the pork chop which was tender and delicious with mashed potatoes and carrots. The portions were just right for us to have room for dessert. We took the server's recommendation of the chocolate tart with hazelnuts and a creamy Cognac sauce and it was fantastic!

Sure, the clientele leans toward the senior set, but at this point I'm leaning that way too. Plus it's nice sharing a dining room who have good table manners. There aren't obnoxiously loud hipsters taking selfies and I totally appreciate that.
author: Lisa W.

description: Got there last minute I had a play at 8 they took care of me right away the meal was delicious for myself and my wife and it was raining they went outside and get me a taxi I'm coming back tomorrow the service will five star.
author: Hector E.

description: This has to be the worst ripoff ever!!! Very expensive--$110 lunch for 2 - no wine. Bland, very small portions of food. One small piece of fish with a very small portion of french fries. Not even a nice presentation. And the waiters were anything but friendly. We left here hungry. I am a native Californian and have lived in the San Francisco Bay Area for 45 years. There are so many wonderful restaurants in this great city. I will never return here. If I want to be financially ripped off for a meal, I can go to Rome or Venice. At least the food will be good!!!
author: Joy L.

description:
I have always loved this place and it has still got it going on several decades later. Simple, well prepared, unpretentious food. Great service and a fantastic location. 

And to the people giving it one and two stars, please just go to the Mission and be done with it. As another reviewer said, this is old school San Francisco dining, so let the adults who frequent this place enjoy it and go eat a taco somewhere. Thanks, a grouchy little old lady.
author: Susan B.

description: The bartender did not know what "up" vs a martini with vermouth. That's ok but then to be rude and argumentative was unacceptable.
author: Mark C.

description:
I am of mixed mind about the Hayes Street Grill. It is caught in a time warp, but it executes its '80s vintage dining experience well.

The menu is above average (though not modern by any means) with the core offering being a selection of grilled seafood; you get to choose the sauce on the side (ranging from beurre blanc to a tomotillo/chipotle salsa). The salads were unique. My mother and I ordered the grilled scallops. We each received six scallops, which ranged in size from a quarter to half-dollar size. Not overly generous on the portions, but delicious. The gentleman at the table next to us raved that he received "the best fries in the city." The beer and wine list were good. I had a Chimay Blue, which paired well with my butternut squash soup. I wish the sage in the soup had been fried. Raw sage can be somewhat bitter.

The ambiance is classic San Francisco bistro with photos of opera/symphony stars who have visited over the years. The clientele is on the older side, probably averaging 60-70. Many of the patrons were there in advance of the symphony. The vibe was quite staid. We sat at a table in the middle of the restaurant, which was sufficiently roomy and comfortable.

There is an undercurrent of a condescending/unhelpful attitude. When I went to hang my mother's coat on a nearby hook, the hostess told me, "You can't hang that there. It can't be near those other tables." She then directed me to some hooks across the room, almost hidden from view. She made me feel like I had made some kind of blunder. Jeez. There were coat hooks EVERYWHERE. It's not really a big deal, but her snootiness spoiled my mood. It would have been much better had she offered to move the coat herself with a "Do you mind if I move your coat over here so people at those tables have a place for their coats?"

The service was adequate, but as the restaurant filled, we saw our waiter less and less. Even though our waiter knew we had a show, we had to sit a good 10-15 minutes after our plates were cleared to be offered desert or the check. The result being we ran out of time to enjoy a nice desert. I had their creme brulee 20 years ago, and it still stands out in my memory as one of the best I've ever had.

They are still operating on paper checks. Our waiter made a simply math error which I had to correct. In addition, they charge a $3 cover charge, which seems a bit steep for a few slices of bread, butter and water. But they are still filling the place every night with loyal clientele, so I guess they can get away with the additional gouge.

In summary: well executed, tasty, but dated food; adequate service with a hint of condescension; ossified clientele, outmoded front-of-the-house practices. I'd probably go back one more time to see if the creme brulee is still as good as I remember.
author: Peter K.

description:
2.5 stars.  Just plain mediocre.

I came here for their prix fixe dinner and had the butternut squash soup, grilled yellow tail, and creme brulee.  The soup was actually pretty good.  When the fish arrived, I got a whiff of a fishy smell, which was quite startling.  Luckily, the fish tasted alright (was saved by the herb butter sauce) and did not give me food poisoning despite the smell.  The entrees were served with fries on the side -- pretty dry and cardboard-y fires.  And then there was the creme brulee... oh dear.  First off, there was a thick layer of sugar on top and it was way too burnt.  The consistency was also off - way too thick, it had the consistency of a strained greek yogurt.  Not a single person at my table of 6 finished their creme brulee.
author: Beatrice W.

description: A few years ago I gave this place only two stars because I was not at all impressed with the food, then last week I ate there with a group of 8 people and we had a fantastic experience.  The food was excellent.  I had a salad with grilled shrimp, which was one of the best I've ever had.  When I finished it I told my husband I wanted to order another one, but he wouldn't let me because he knew I wouldn't be able to finish it.  Service was great.  We weren't going to the symphony or opera so we stayed on and closed the place down.  Great dinner!!!
author: Nancy R.

description:
The food was okay, but very basic, nothing I couldn't have prepared better at home. My companion had the San Diego Yellow Tail and I had the Pork Chop, and they looked exactly the same with a vegetable and mashed potato side dish. We shared a creme brulee for dessert and the crust was overcooked while the creme was uneventful and obviously straight out of the refrigerator. 

The kicker was the bill ... with the addition of two glasses of wine, we paid $96.00 before tip (the service, it should be noted, was excellent). For the food we received, the bill was astronomical, even for the Hayes Valley location. We're willing to pay for a great dining experience, but this was the same meal we would have eaten at a lousy chain restaurant for half the price.
author: Mike S.

description: Convenient place if you are headed to the SF Symphony afterward; they definitely cater to the pre-show crowd.  Classic, white table cloth, older crowd atmosphere.  Our waiter was nice but totally screwed up our order; mixing up sea bass with halibut,  various side dish orders and sauces.  The food was solid but nothing spectacular (especially for the price).  Given that there are a wealth of other options in the area, I would recommend trying one of those before coming here.
author: Andrea L.

description:
While this place is in a cute location, it really doesn't fit the neighborhood.  It has a dated feel, almost like a cheap road side restaurant,  the clientele resembles a pac heights crowd, meaning s bit stuffy and old, and the food just doesn't cut it.

The wine list is very sparse at best, the Malbec I had was flat and flavorless.    We had the goat cheese salad and asparagus to start, both were nice but not exceptional.  For the entree I had the soft shell crab and my friend had the scallops.  The crab was nice but soggy, so when I ate it it just dripped in sauce and butter.  I like it crispy.  The calli flower that came on the side was OK but something you could make at home in 5 minutes.  

While nothing was really bad, nothing was great and for the prices of $28-$30/entree I just expect a lot better food, experience and atmosphere.
author: Inga W.

description: Warm goat cheese salad and hearts of romaine with blue cheese were good. My Rex sole was drenched with butter sauce and could not taste watercress. Service was little off. It was very busy, but felt that there are better restaurants with this price.
author: Kyoko T.

description:
Old school. Always solid. Always good. Fresh fish. Sole is great.

We go at least once per month before symphony or ballet.
author: Scott H.

description:
Went to HSG today with a group of 5  for  a special occasion lunch. Hadn't been in 20 years and all I can say is- what was I waiting for? It was perfect.   Comfortable table where we were able to talk even though the place was full- on a Monday, which says something about their quality. Great food and the service was exceptional- considerate and attentive without being hovering and cloying. Needless to say, we left a very generous tip.

Started with Quail Salad with grilled apricots- a special that I shared. Nothing left on the plate. Then onto perfectly grilled Alaskan Halibut -  I chose the classic Buerre Blanc sauce and was well rewarded for keeping it simple. The accompanying french fries were a self indulgent treat and perfectly salted. The Italian style broccolini ( we got a side plate to share) with garlic and a bit of hot pepper  was perfectly al dente.  As for the two dessert that  we shared- again the word perfect comes to mind. Classic zabaglione with berries was  flavorful and simultaneously rich and light. Plus the trio of Lemon Basil sorbet, Raspberry Merlot sorbet and vanilla frozen yogurt had us all digging our spoons in- so refreshing. 

And when the owner realized that we were celebrating a wedding- there was a nice note and a little surprise gift on the bill when it was presented- very classy. Will definitely be back again soon. There's a reason why they have lasted as long as they have.
author: Joan P.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  I've had almost everything on the menu.  Excellent for seafood, for their pork chop, for wine, for drinks, for dessert.
author: James H.

description:
Gayle and I observe various Anniversaries. For example, it's been just over 2 years since I proposed on Valentine's Day and next month we will celebrate our 1st Wedding Anniversary. And last Monday Night's dinner at the Hayes Street Grill was just 2 days short of of the date we first met 6 years ago. So why shouldn't our celebration be at a nice French Bistro? 

We were also going to see David Gray at Davies Symphony Hall afterwards, and this restaurant is an easy walk over. So were others as our immediate table neighbours at our very nice window seat had the same plans. Otherwise, the room was full, busy, and a fun place to be. 

Gayle and I had a great dinner and a wonderful time together. Service was excellent and so was the fish (plus split sides of veggies and frites). We also  shared a tasty goat cheese/almond salad to start, finished up our stay with a single hot fudge sundae, and quaffed a nice bottle of Honig Sauvignon Blanc in-between. 

Gayle and I had our very first date at Plearn (Walnut Creek), where I earned the notorious distinction of being the only man that accepted her offer to split the bill. That's one Anniversary tradition that wasn't repeated here. :-)
author: Eric B.

description:
The food was a solid 3.5 stars. The fish was well cooked. I enjoyed the roasted cauliflower.

However the service from the waiter and the manager was so abrasive and rude. When some of the people in our party were about 15 minutes late, the waiter huffed and puffed multiple times, even after the rest of our party arrived. He was visibly irritated at the fact that we only ordered 2 appetizers for a party of 8 and the rest of the order was entrees.

Then as we were waiting for our checks, the manager comes over and tells us he has another party and that we need to leave. We were waiting for our check for 20 minutes and would have left sooner.

Overall food is good, but the service is abrasive and curt. No need to go back.
author: Shannon M.

description:
We've dined here a few times while staying in the Hayes Valley area and usually it's in conjunction with a concert at Davies Hall.  Our recent visit was no exception and this time we were joined by another couple.

Nothing has changed since we've been here and that's a good thing!  The menu offerings are the same and there's always a fresh fish of the day option that's grilled and served with a choice of many sauces.  I selected Opah, with the recommended lemon caper sauce---very moist, cooked medium.  My husband had Petrale sole with mushrooms and said it was delicious.  One of our friends had swordfish, and the other opted for a bivette steak.  Everyone enjoyed their meals.  Dessert was a slice of meyer lemon tart which my husband and I shared.  Our friends went with the hot fudge sundae.

All in all, a pleasant dining experience.  Good service.  Good food.  Consistency counts when selecting a restaurant.  And the Hayes Street Grill is a place that one can always depend upon to deliver!
author: Mary A.

description:
I hate to give an unfavorable review, but my experience here was subpar on several levels. 

I will say that this place was great in accommodating our group of 20 at the last minute. 

The food here was really bland and unappealing. I had the king salmon, which was really disappointing.  They offer a selection of sauces to go with your fish, none of which sounded appetizing to go on top of salmon.  I opted for the Beurre Blanc, which arrived (thankfully on the side) as a pool of butter/oil.   What was worse was the creamed vegetable dish that came with it. I'm not a big fan of creamed spinach/vegetables in the first place, but this was so awful looking (and tasting).  It arrived a brownish-creamy  mess and was really unpalatable. 

I used the restroom twice, which requires you to walk past the kitchen. On both occasions I was basically gawked at by the chefs, it was creepy/unprofessional.

Sad to say, but I won't be back...
author: Brianna M.

description: I had a lunch meeting here yesterday; it was my first time. I need to go back because the meeting part of the experience was so discussion oriented it distracted me from fully enjoying the food. Darn! Having said that, the petrol sole with hedgehog mushrooms and fingerling potatoes was great! Lovely earthy buttery taste mild enough to let the light fish come through. I really enjoyed it. The garnish was a mindless   Bunch of baby spinach leaves neither attractive or of any value. The herring appetizer was standard fair. Service was good and good looking. All in all this was a good lunch. I'll go back, the next time without talkers so I can really savor my food.
author: Richard A.

description: Wow does this place need an update.  If you need a place to take your elderly grandparents to gum their food this is it!  Super pricey for what you get.  We had the Halibut with peanut sauce and Yellow-tail with salsa verde which come with greens or fries.  The fish was fresh and cooked well but everything felt like elderly cafeteria food. We were brought bread and butter but no individual bread plates were presented, I saw this same approach to shared salad at another table (like multiple dogs sharing the same bowl).  They serve fries with everything which is weird for entrees at the $30. mark.  The place was stifling hot, which I am sure was great for all the ancient diners (seriously the median age, of diners and waitstaff) had to have been 70).  The only good thing I think I could point out was the wine.  I think they are super lucky they are in the arts area where folks just want diner before the ballet or symphony, and all the good places were already booked up, because I can't imagine them making it anywhere else.
author: Heather D.

description:
I would just like to say that the petrale sole with trumpet mushrooms was absolutely divine.  

**jubilant trumpet solo here**

Divine.

Thank you.

Service is sharp.

Prices on the whole are quite high.  I'm ok with that if it's what it takes for sustainably caught fish.  And those mushrooms.  Seriously.  Divine.
author: .caroline. ..

description:
Very Very Very Mediocre food at expensive prices. I would not recommend eating here. Scallops had sand in them: not well cleaned. Friend had a pork chop...I know it is known for it's fish.....but the pork chop was served raw in the middle....who in the flock serves food like that? he sent the food back 3 times....it finally was not raw but it was tough as shoe leather. the smart waitress should have brought another cooked piece of meat...but she had no brains...just a robot.

Do not eat here!
author: David G.

description:
Had dinner for 4 at this place. Three of us ordered the recommended Soft Shell Crab and one of us had the Halibut. We also had the Carrot Eggplant soup which was a pureed soup - delicious; the Watermelon something or another salad, also good; and the Shrimp Louie, which was good, but a bit too much in regards to portion... a little overwhelming for an appetizer.

The wine list must have been decent (I didn't get to have a look at it because someone else ordered the wine before I had a chance) because what we drank was quite good... both Pinot Noir's. We all agreed that the food, especially the entrees were really good. Just good old fashioned, home cooking. Not a whole lot of frills, but the menu was still very creative. 

Our server, a true professional, obviously took his job very seriously. He would bring us what we mentioned amongst ourselves (not to him yet) before we had a chance to ask him for it. I noticed he was wearing a hearing aid, and I think he must turn it way up so he can hear his customers, because I also noticed him flinching from afar, at an interesting story my friend was telling us about his recent trip to Ireland. A little unnerving if your discussing anything of a sensitive nature meant for exclusive ears. But I thought it was a creative technique of providing better service. Not to mention the book he must have in the works, featuring his most interesting eves droppings.

Anyway, I'll give it 4 stars because it was super clean, white table clothes, impeccable service, delicious, good, clean food, and perfect location if you happen to be going to a show nearby. I'll be back for sure.
author: John A.

description:
*lackluster place with a price that doesn't match*
#mehallaround
#nothingstandout

Never spending much time in Hayes Valley, we decided to not yelp and just walk through the neighborhood to see what caught our eye, or stomach. We settled on this place after reading a decent menu through the window. 

Unfortunately we were dully impressed. Not to say the food here was terrible by any means, but it sure wasn't worth the price they were asking for it. A stale loaf of sourdough bread to start, a steak that was cooked well on a bed of plain spinach, and a paella that left me wanting a bit more. 

Again there is nothing dreadfully wrong with this place. Fair service, fair food, fair decor. It just provided no excitement in any way shape or form. My 3 star rating is a mediocre place that I will be back to if I'm in the neighborhood. Unfortunately, nothing draws me back here. For the price you can explore some much better cuisine here in SF.
author: Kevin T.

description: This was probably one of the worst meals I've had in Hayes Valley.  The place very much reminds me of a high end Denny's - a majority of the patrons seem to be octogenarians and the food is bland and poorly prepared to say the least.  It's very telling that the owner when inviting friends to dine with her in the neighborhood suggests other restaurants than her own :-(.  The one and only time I've eaten here I ordered the sole and my date ordered the sand dabs, both of us left with our plates less than half eaten and there was no need for to-go boxes.  True it was a Monday, not the best day to order fish, but if you're going to have seafood dominate your menu you better be able to prepare it well regardless of the day of the week, especially at those price points.  I'll never go back.
author: William C.

description: Had the most fantastic late night dinner after SF Symphony.  If the SF Symphony playes like it then you know it's good.  Musicians know the hidden gems. Highly recommended
author: Wind S.

description:
My wife loves this place. It's her favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I have a former colleague from Washington, D.C. who also comes here whenever he is in town. So I know it has strong fans.
