As for me, I enjoy it, recommend it, and probably have dined there at least a half dozen times in the past year. So I have much positive and nothing negative to say. It's highly competent and reliable. It isn't an amazing knock out, once in a lifetime place.

It's mainly good for seafood. Every type, very fresh, and prepared to your liking. 

People also rave about the french fries. They're at a high level of competence. So if your dish doesn't come with them, it's good to order a side for the table.

The setting is a class act. Moderate high end. So not as fancy as Jardinere or as noisy as Absinthe, to name two nearby competitors. 

The one warning is this is the go-to place for people attending cultural events. So on any night with symphony, opera, etc., it is jammed from 6 to 7:45. They understand this routine, and they have a little note on their website. So the upside here is if you are seeing a show, they will get you out the door. The downside is if you are not seeing a show, there is no way it makes sense to go during the mad rush period -- just wait until 7:45, and the waitstaff will be relieved to see you arrive for a leisurely meal.

It's also a terrific venue for a business lunch.

They have specials such as shad roe, which is seasonal. I can't say I've ever had shad roe I haven't liked, but they do an excellent job. And the mere fact that they have it is a sign. Not many places do.

I see that some folks pan it. I don't know why. It has its market staked out: it is for someone seeing the symphony who has mid-level tickets, not rush nor box. If that isn't you, then it's not likely to be your scene.
author: Frank W.

description: How does this restaurant stay open in this day and age with all the great food around for the same price?  The fish was OK, but lacking any originality (and a few pieces of fries and 5 arugula leaves are not considered a side dish in my mind). It's fit for an older, less discerning dining crowd. If it wasn't for the lack of dining options in Hayes Valley that night due to the ballet, I never would have given it a try.
author: Odnit D.

description:
I admit that I was slightly hesitant about this place before going there last night pre-symphony.  I feared that the location perhaps had more to do with the relatively high ratings than the food or service--after all, who wouldn't love a decent restaurant that's across the street from Davies, and so close still to many other venues?  But with little time to plan ahead, we made reservations for Friday at 6 PM anyway.... and THANK GOD WE TOOK THAT CHANCE!!

First, this place has an understated style--outside, it's your typical facade and could be anything, really--and inside, it's smallish, straight-forward and clean--nothing particularly outstanding to catch one's eye upon entering.  

We were seated promptly by a friendly and efficient host.  Our server arrived right away, and waters and complimentary DELICIOUS fresh bread was quickly on the table.  (Must say--that butter reminded us of the incomparable sweet butter one gets in good European restaurants.  YUM.  So YUM, we asked for more!  lol)  

Not too busy yet at 6 PM, but the tables steadily started filling up throughout our meal, and it seemed pretty obvious these were mostly other symphony goers.

I appreciated the fact that my lame-ish question of "What are some of the most popular dishes" was met with, "The menu changes daily, so it's a bit hard to say."   (So what you see on their website menu is not a complete listing--but gives you an idea, for sure.)  And truly, the menu had that day's date printed on it--they're not kidding about using fresh ingredients.

Anyway, I started with the Warm Goat Cheese salad with Toasted Pecans--served with a balsamic viniagrette.  TO DIE FOR.  Seriously.  Like dessert.  The cheese tasted so fresh, and was just slightly warmer than room temperature--perfect for a salad.  While I often feel cheated by a high-priced side salad, this was WELL worth the $10 price, and I would order it again without hesitation.

For an entree, I chose the Halibut with the lemon and caper sauce (you choose your fish, then your sauce from a list)--about $28, I believe.  When the plate was delivered,  it was looking kind of sparse:  nondescript white plate, piece of fish, a few sprigs of green, and a small dish of the sauce (see photo).  French fries were served in a separate cup on the side.  

I had NO idea what I was in for when I went for my first bite.  But dear GOD.  That halibut was absolutely the most DIVINE halibut I've ever had in my LIFE.  Delicate, succulent, PERFECTLY cooked (to order).... It nearly melts in your mouth!!!!!  The sauce was light but beautifully complimented the fish.  It was the freshest fish you can imagine--and a nice, big piece, as well.  A perfect, perfect entree.  

The french fries, which many reviewers rave about, were good.  But...they were french fries!  Yes, tasty & fresh.  But still:  French Fries.  lol  Interesting to serve a spectacular entree with this item.  But whatever.  Honestly, they could have served Kleenex as a side with that delectable fish, I wouldn't have cared!!

My dinner companion started with the Asparagus salad (which had an egg topping and was VERY good) and chose the Swordfish as her entree--and while I'm not a "huge" swordfish fan, I admit it was rather light (as far as swordfish goes) and tasty, as well.  AND, yes, VERY fresh.  But we both agreed, my fish was the winner.  

After our concert, we actually returned for coffee and dessert.  My companion had the Champagne Ices ($8 I think)--she enjoyed it, but she's really not a big dessert eater typically, so it's hard to comment (I didn't try it).   I opted for the Apple-Huckleberry Crisp with vanilla ice cream ($10).  Good, but not outstanding.   Next time, I'll go for the Creme Brulee everyone raves about!!  

One final note regarding the service:  I read some less than stellar reviews, but must say that OUR experience was exceptional.  Unobtrusive, gracious, timely, and attentive to the point that I merely had to turn my head in order to catch eyes with a server across the room, who quickly arrived to assist us.

I look forward to returning.
author: Gabriella P.

description: Sustainable, Fresh and always Delicious. The grilled fish is simple, but you know what you're getting is sustainably caught and expertly prepared. The special items for lunch or dinner are always a treat - and the desserts!! Oh the desserts! One of my Hayes Valley Go-To's.
author: Maya D.

description:
Our second dinner at HSG and we enjoyed it thoroughly.  Our server was very knowledgeable and clearly experienced--friendly, to the point but not rushed.  We had a delicious chardonnay to start while we attempted to decide on appetizers,  entrees and what turned out to be a killer dessert!  We had the bay shrimp salad with avocado, corn and beets and loved every single bite!  We also had the grilled calamari, artichoke and butter been salad-very good but not as delicious as the bay shrimp.  For main courses we finally decided on the salmon (lemon butter sauce) and Hamachi tuna (tomatillo sauce) --both were fabulous!  The tomatillo sauce was a fav of the evening.  For dessert a chocolate hazelnut torte with OMG AWESOME fudge sauce!  Another very good meal and we will be back.

PS parking is the usual nightmare and getting a cab can be just as tough...
author: Jeff P.

description: The worst.  Used to be a fine restaurant.  No more. I escorted a party of 10.  Three ordered salads.  Two were served.  Supposed to contain avocado.  There was none.  Waiter tried to say it was "in the sauce".  Glass of wine a thimble full and guest charged 18.00.  Not a receipt.  Demanded a better price.  Got another $3.00 back.  Service the worst.  Slow and unresponsive.  Food mediocre.  Will NEVER go back to this old has been of a former time.
author: Kimbal A.

description: good but very, very expensive. I had the mussels, warm goat cheese salad and mushroom/celery root salad. All just .... good. A "good" wine list, nothing great.! Great proximity to Davies, etc. here's a clue!it was 6:00 and it wasn't packed on a Monday night, even when Absinthe is closed ... doh!
author: Kevin F.

description:
Ate their 4/11. Busy night because of the local venues. 
Good thing is they got us fed quick. 
Halibut under cooked. 
Steak under cooked and full of gristle 
Way to much money for what we got. 
Will not return.
author: Daved D.

description: Born in SF; been to every terrific restaurant in the City ; we think this is the best for fish. Cozy atmosphere , great fish and terrific service. Wonderful before the theatre.
author: Roger M.

description: Wanted to love it but $30 fish arrived cold, and the "famous" fries were cold and mushy.  Bummer as I've heard about this place for a while.  I love fish but would rather have it raw than cooked and served cold. Desert and coffee were delish.
author: Devi R.

description:
The food was very good, but the air was toxic!

Last night I visited HSG with a party of 9 for dinner. By the end of the meal, four of us has respiratory problems, including me. I asked if there was smoke coming from the kitchen, I was told that there was nothing unusual.  One of the four of us considered going to the ER because he could not stop coughing. Beware!
author: Derrick B.

description: Declined over the years.  Four of us came for dinner before the symphony - we ordered fish and it was so mediocre.  Two of us had cold fish - as if it had been pre-cooked, then inadequately rewarmed.  For $30, barely warmed white fish with a small bowl of french fries - nothing more.  The fish was mushy and rather tasteless (Opah).  We've used this restaurant over the past 10 or 15 years.  We won't be back.  To much $$$ for too little service and marginal food.
author: Carolyn C.

description:
Great place to get the equivalent of hotel food or NY diner.
Only reason to go is to try and grab a last minute bite before you go to Nourse theater or any of the surrounding spots like SF opera, etc. 
Service was good but in a city of great food this place is just about hunger and calories.
author: Gus K.

description: Fish was obviously frozen and water logged. It was the thinnest piece of fish I've ever seen. Serving it with fries is very telling. This didn't even measure up to a Costco frozen patty. No offer of bread. Less appetizing than Applebee's with a nice side of vegetables for $14. Clearly a tourist trap. I should have known better.
author: Christine M.

description:
We LOVE the Hayes Street Grille. Never ever a disappointment and we are there once a week, each and every week. Service/owner/food EXCELLENT.
We are now thinking we should be featured on the photo gallery wall as we are the best marketing clients ever. BEST spot in our hood.
author: Susan R.

description:
It was just ok in my brain butter bucket.
Had the Boudin sausage, kinda bland however and the meat was ground super fine like a pate' and stuffed in little 3" long casings.

Frankly, At home I make better bigger sausage than this place. They should just order these from Taylor Sausage company across the bay. Those people know how to make sausage!!

WAY OVERPRICED!!!
$28 for 2 little sausages and a bowl of fries. REALLY? Must have the value in those fries and they were crispy. 

Whoever is running this place is pushing the limits on the little servings and high prices. But I guess thats part of the downtown Civic Center ripoff routine.

The service was very polite and prompt.  Actually the service was the best part of the entire meal.

All be well
Uncle Bobby
author: Bobby M.

description:
Went here after a gap of about two decades. What an enjoyable place. The service was excellent; they got us a table without a reservation. Same thing is true as it was long ago: Hayes Street Grill is still a fantastic place to get grilled fish. I had the sea bass, and it was delicious, fresh, cooked perfectly, and served with a lemon butter (there are other sauce choices) that is terrific, even if almost unnecessary because the fish was so good.

Nice glass of Pinot Gris and some fantastic fries to go with it. 

Companions had whiskey sausage, which was fabulous; steak, excellent with a nice presentation; and scallops, also perfectly cooked.

Can't miss with this place.
author: Mister K.

description:
Hey, young Yelpers, don't go to this restaurant - it's not for you.  This is a place for people who appreciate the traditional San Francisco seafood grill-type restaurant equivalent to Sam's or Tadich.  It's a place for people who understand that when all seafood is fresh diners need to arrive relatively early in order to have abundant choices, such as the Rex sole or sand dabs expertly grilled on the bone. It's a place for people who like the outstanding and reasonably-priced wine list appropriate for the entrees.  And it's a place for people who appreciate the professionalism of the staff - from Fred, the outstanding maître d', to the excellent and efficient group of long-term waiters.

No, young Yelpers. this is not your kind of restaurant.  You will not find many people staring endlessly into their smart phones and tablets.  There is actual conversation taking place which is possible because of the absence of distracting background music.  The result is a pleasant hum rather than the "energetic" noise level you are used to.  Oh, and by the way, the pictures on the wall are of great operatic and symphonic stars who have dined here - the kind of people who appreciate this kind of restaurant and are appreciated by the other patrons.  No rap or hip-hop performers are represented.
author: Gary H.

description:
Lovely casual place with a limited but excellent selection of salads and grilled items, specializing in fish and seafood. 
I had the goat cheese salad with toasted pecans, then grilled salmon. 
The salad was über fresh greens with about 3-oz of warm goat cheese (rosemary scented?) and a PERFECTLY balanced vinaigrette. I spread some of the warm goat cheese and pecans on their fresh whole wheat bread and it was the perfect appetizer. Really well executed. 
The salmon was cooked to order which, for me, is practically sashimi-raw. But this large filet had a delicate smoky flavor while being "just" cooked on the outside. Only four tiny bones, but they are vindicated by the excellent spicy peanut sauce I chose (from among several options) and DELICIOUS wilted greens and fresh rocket. 
The only reason for 4 stars is that the default side for the salmon is fries with the option to sub greens, which I had requested; I was initially served fries but the waiter made a correction immediately.  
I don't eat sweets, but their dessert menu was well-balanced with fruity and chocolate options. 
Parking is plentiful (but not cheap) nearby and several popular venues are one block away (Davies Symphony Hall, War Memorial Opera House, Nourse Hall, and more).
Check out their menu online, as choices all fit on one page with plenty of white space to spare; first be sure it's your cup of tea, and if it is, you won't be disappointed!
author: Aimee C.

description:
So this was not the restaurant version of the Embarcadero food stand, apparently.  I should have known from looking around the restaurant that the restaurant catered to people who had more money than taste, seeing as how everyone looked like they had just gotten back from Sunday church...except on a Saturday night.  

The food itself was okay.  It felt like a high end cafeteria, I guess, but commanded "fancy night out" prices.  I can't really complain about the quality, except that all of their dishes seemed very old fashioned (not to be confused with "classic").  The wait staff never engaged in any sort of conversation and lacked any charm, but the service was at least speedy.

Will never return here again, at least until I'm so old that experiencing anything new would likely cause a heart attack.
author: Norman S.

description: Pin bones left in the salmon? Come on. Was good 20 years ago now fading. Swordfish bland. (Frozen?) perhaps better places nearby
author: Andy S.

description:
Running late for date night at the SF Ballet's "Romeo and Juliet" (great production, by the way), we stopped by here for a quick bite to eat.  Hayes Street Grill appears to specialize in seafood, but they do have a couple of well-reviewed land-based mammal dishes to munch on as well.

As soon as we were seated, I informed our server that we had a show to catch and that we were running late.  He laughed and told us half the people dining there were in a similar predicament (curse you, 101 rush hour traffic!), then assured us we would have our food with plenty of time to spare.  True to his word, he took our order at 6:20, and plates were in front of us by 6:30, giving us a somewhat leisurely 30 minutes to enjoy before walking over to the performance.

Dinner for 2, comprised of scallops and sole meuniere, and 2 glasses of wine, was fine, and came to $80+ all in.  Portions seemed skimpy at that price, but quality was good.  Overall, a decent place to get a bite when in the area, and their close proximity to various performance venues means they know how to bang out dishes quickly.  To be honest, the dishes aren't the most creative or interesting, but I think these guys know they fulfill a particular purpose and do a great job at it.
author: Alan L.

description: The creamy corn under my scallops was amazing, buttery, rich (but not too rich) sweet and tender.  It was the bright yellow sunshine on my plate and I only wished I could have ordered more.  The scallops were good, could have been seared better and always larger because more is better but tasted good.  Since it was hot outside and inside provided no relief a light meal was perfect.  My husband had swordfish with a butter caper sauce which they served in a ramekin on the side and it came with fries.  I expected the fish to have been heated in the sauce and served with the sauce on the plate.  It would have been a much better presentation that the diner silver cup.  The presentation took this dish down a notch along with $32 dollar price for fish and chips.  Overall the $100 meal (two entries and two drinks) was too pricy for what was served.  It wasn't special enough to return but if the corn is ever served as a side I'll pick up a container to go.
author: Dianne M.

description:
I had long wanted to go to Hayes Street Grill and very much looked forward to my dinner here. The result was extremely disappointing.

I'm not sure they deserve 3 stars. I give 3 stars to nice little neighborhood restaurants with acceptable food, good service, and moderate prices. Hayes was none of the above. Maybe 21/2 stars. 

OK, details, I had a 5 PM Saturday reservation. I was seated ... and sat. And sat. I waited more than 15 minutes while everyone who had entered when I did, and people arriving later, were served. It was not busy, I could see servers standing around. I kept staring them in the face and they ignored me. Finally I started to get up from my seat and walk to them. Then someone came to my table. I said they had been studiously avoiding me, and he said not studious, just accidental. Accidental that I was the only solo woman there? You guess.

I ordered a cocktail, the beet/fennel salad, grilled opah with both greens and fries, and asked for bread, and also ordered hot tea to arrive with my entree. Drink good, salad very good, beets, fennel and radish in a tangy dressing. I was feeling a little better. The entree arrived, good portion size, everything LOOKED good ... neither the fish nor the greens were hot. Barely tepid. It was as if they prepared my salad and entree at the same time and then left entree sitting there while I ate my salad. If I had said anything they would probably have nuked it in microwave which would have made things worse. Neither fish nor greens hold heat well; a heated plate would have helped but plate was not heated. I gobbled my food fast in an unsuccessful attempt to finish dinner before it all got totally cold. I don't go out to eat to gobble food; I don't even do that at home. The food was still totally cold before I finished and my stomach paid later for eating so fast. The fries were fairly hot, crisp, not greasy, but fries don't make the meal.

Also, when the waiter brought my entree he asked if there was anything else. I had to remind him I'd ordered tea. When they started clearing the table they tried to take the bread plate although I had not finished the bread.

For dessert I got chocolate terrine with whipped cream and cherry compote. It was good, how could it not be, but very small portion.

When I spend over $80 on dinner I want it to be good and well served. I cannot recommend Hayes Street Grill and will not be back.
author: Carol S.

description:
Hayes Valley Foodie Outing

Stop five: Hayes Street Grill

Finally, it was time for a sit down dinner.  I did not expect the restaurant to be near empty, but it was good for us since we had a pretty large party.

It was service with attitude, though.  I get it, we're not the theatre crowd.  We're not senior citizens.  But you don't have to treat us like we're teenage hooligans!

I ordered the grilled Hoffman quail salad with grilled figs, french fries, and a glass of wine.

Don't get their fries.  It was kind of gross.  And not worth it.  Obviously they didn't make it when we ordered it, because the waiter comes back out with them in seconds.  Talk about fast.  And they don't have ranch sauce (I know, I'm classy).  And we got snooty looks when we asked for ketchup.  I'm just not used to eating french fries with tartar sauce, mmkay?

And, I get bribed easily.  The waiter became way nicer towards the end.  And he came out with a free creme brulee for the table, saying we can't leave without trying their signature dessert.

Nothing beats free.
author: Jenny L.

description: This restaurant had some good reviews so I tried it and it was pretty bad. And I was pretty sad. That rhymed but it's true and I feel bad saying there was nothing that I liked about it. The service was the one thing that was pretty good but the food was bad. Bland and uneventful. I had yellowtail with a salsa type sauce on the side. The fish seemed overcooked and tasteless and the salsa was super spicy. The fries that came with it seemed like the kind at the bottom of the fryer. Sorry this sounds mean but the food needs help in my opinion. The farmers market stand for Hayes Street Grill has always been good though :)
author: Olivia O.

description:
we shared the ceasar salad.  it was romaine lettuce, parmesan cheese and had too much garlic.  it was $11.

he had the paella.  i'm not much of a shellfish fan nor do i have any experience with paella so what the hell do i know?  i tried the sauce.  not bad.

i had the steak.  it came on a bed of uncooked spinach.  there was some garlic type sauce situation on the steak.

we had bread and water.

there were photographs of random people on the walls and real linens on the table with paper over them.

did my review bore you?  so did my meal.
author: Lauren P.

description:
This is a place for retirees and seniors to mingle and slowly eat fish and other soft foods.  Not in an old money kind of way, either.  

If you think this place is expensive, it's probably because you're not getting your money's worth.  You could definitely do better elsewhere in terms of sophistication, but this place has large portions and decent service.
author: Erika C.

description: Good food but erratic service - for the last half hour our waitress vanished and we had to order dessert and coffee from the busboy. Very crowded per-concerts but then rapidly empties out.
author: Ray D.

description:
Hayes Street Grill was fine for the most part: the fish was good, albeit a little on the expensive side compared to other restaurants, but fries may be the best in the city. The basic fish plates (around $30.00) come with either fries or veggies, not both; the service was a little stand-off-ish but okay. 

The problem for me was the dining room. We were located in the west side dining room near the kitchen, we got all the crashing noises, and all the smells of oil cooking and all the smoke. By the end of the meal it was such a turn-off we decided to skip dessert just to get out and get some fresh air. There are three ceiling fans, but they were not turned on.
author: david d.

description:
After hearing friends and family rave about the Hayes Street Grill, we decided to give it a try before an SF Symphony performance at the Davies Symphony Hall.  With our 5:30pm reservations, we were seated right away and were greeted as soon as we were shown to our table.

The restaurant became busy quickly with others who came for dinner before the symphony.  The average age of the patrons seemed to be in the 55 and up range.  The menu featured mostly fresh fish dishes, although there were steak and chicken selections.  

As an appetizer, I ordered a half dozen Hog Island Sweet Water Oysters on the 1/2 shell.  The oysters were small, but flavorful and the straight horseradish and shallot vinaigrette were a nice accompaniment.  For dinner, I ordered the Hawaiian Ono with a side of lemon & caper butter sauce.  The fish portion was large enough to feed two people and was seared to perfection.  The Ono also came with a side of french fries that were addicting (I finished almost the entire portion!). For dessert, I shared a hot fudge sundae with toasted pecans.  The sundae was rich and savory and any guilt I had in ordering it went away with each spoonful.

I enjoyed my experience at the Hayes Street Grill.  It wasn't too fancy nor was it too casual.  The wait staff was extremely attentive and friendly.
author: Chelle K.

description: This place has fantastic service, sustainable fresh fish, Niman ranch meats and reasonable  prices. Come after the crowds have headed to their shows (7:30 or later) and have the whole restaurant to yourself. No problem for groups.
author: D M.

description:
2.5 stars?  Hmmm...maybe.

Lunch on a weekday.  Smoked chicken salad with dressing on the side.  The rest of the party arrived first and ordered for me.  By the time I arrived, salad was there.  Nothing special.  Smoked chicken way too salty.  Luckily, asked for salad dressing on the side.

Even though salad was sitting waiting for my arrival, there was no glass.  I tried a few times to get someone's attention...then just gave up.  Mommy wasn't drinking her glass of water...so I took it.

Service was ok.  There was a bit of customer watching - if I noticed it....hmmm...our server and another one was watching/chatting about me and my company...sigh...C'est la vie...

I suppose, they will never lack business...ballet/opera/symphony...
author: Barb L.

description: Best calamari ever, and it was at the end of lunch hour.  Delicious glass of wine, too.  Partner had swordfish salad.  Yum!!  Will be back some day soon for dinner.  The service was excellent, too.
author: Leslie R.

description: we found this gem of a restaurant thru yelp and am happy to report back that it's great! we went for an early dinner before the opera...the food was fantastic (esp the point reyes blue cheese salad with diced radishes) - i also had the crab cakes and my husband had the halibut that was perfecty cooked...we were exceptionally happy with our sweet server, ron, who was very exellent! we will def go back again and hope we are in ron's section!!!
author: Tami B.

description:
We have lived in Hayes Valley for a year and been passing the Grill often.  It is a homey place, definitely an older crowd on their way to the opera, ballet, or symphony.

I recommend having the salmon or any fish with fries.  The food is overpriced but it is a great place to take the family when in town.
author: Chad S.

description: OK, on my way to a concert and was really wanting a burger and beer before hand. Major disappointment that was told in a manner that made it sound like my fault that they don't serve burgers on performance nights. I'd  not return on policy and attitude alone. There are so many more and better options.
author: Gary H.

description:
Just dined again on Friday night before Symphony and will again later this month before another Symphony, Beethoven 9.  As always food presentation, quality, service is first rate.

Had Copper River salmon this time but everything we've ordered over the years has been excellent, especially good are their French fries.

The simple , unpretentious atmosphere is nostalgic and holds up better than most establishments.
author: Kiyoshi W.

description:
Had my first day of summer work the other day and my boss took me out to Hayes Street Grill for lunch. Right when we walked in, my boss whispers to me to look in the corner. There was Michael Tilson Thomas, conductor of the San Francisco Symphony. Apparently he's one of the more prestigious figures in San Francisco. In fact, scanning around the place, the whole place seems to feature a lot of upper-class patrons.

This is not to discourage you from coming here though because the food is just exquisite. I was told to order one of their fish items. I went with the swordfish, topped with the beuree blanc sauce. Ughhhhh it was SO good. I had to pace myself at the risk of embarrassing myself in front of my superiors. The swordfish was extremely tender and juicy, and oh so pleasurable to eat.

Hayes Street Grill fails to reach the 5-star plateau however because I thought their fries were decent. I found myself forcing to finish the fries (I didn't want to leave anything on the plate, not in front of the bosses!)

If you haven't already guessed, their lunch items can get really pricey. Most of the entrees were in the 25+ range. Fortunately, this poor law student was getting treated out yeee.

Hayes Street Grill is a fantastic place which I definitely will have to come back. Hopefully someday, it'll be the case where someone will walk in and whisper in their friend's ear: "look in the corner, there's Tom P.!" Haha I know... dream on Tom.
author: Tom P.

description: Sad to say I had an awful experience at this restaurant.  My family's Salmon was frozen, some members of the party did not like Seafood and wanted the pork or steak which was not available. They were able to provide a chicken fillet which was very bland and tasted like fish. The rice that was offered was comparable to minute rice. And also I received a weird creepy stare from one of the cooks on the way to the bathroom. Very awkward experience all around.
author: Sam C.

description: Service was great. The food was totally without flavor. Both the fish and the pork chop were so bland I wondered if the kitchen even had salt at its disposal.
author: Leslie G.

description: Return visit last night was very disappointing. Food was mediocre. For pre-performance it is among ok experience, but for an evening where the food is center stage, it is a miss.
author: Rita G.

description:
What happens when you're on your way to a bar with friends but you're early and hungry!? We asked the door man if the bar served food and he said no, but he pointed us in the direction of  Hayes Street and it was a good direction.

After walking past some snooty looking places, we walked by the Hayes Street grill and read the menu. The bar menu that seemed to be perfectly priced and sounded amazing. Estancia grass fed hamburger with Grafton Cheddar with fries. I don't often eat burgers but when I do, I'll splurge with higher quality meats and cheeses. Basically, if they as you how you want it cooked, it's a good sign already because they're actually confident in the meat they're using. 

The cheese burger with fries were only 14 dollars which was a steal for the juicy goodness paired with great flavor and a cheese that is melted to perfect that compliments the burger. The fries were perfectly crisp yet light and all in all a great meal. Great meals don't come this cheap usually. Although you may say it's just a cheese burger and fries, I was surprised it only cost $14 because it was that good.

Close to the symphony and to Smuggler's Cove.
author: Rhoi C.

description: Nice quiet place. Good for conversation. Top notch service. Food was good - not amazing - but yummy French fries and fish. Great neighborhood option!
author: Allison B.

description:
The date was Oct 24th, 2010. We had reservations for two at Hayes st. Grill for 7:30pm. 

We were seated promptly however; it took a minute for us figure out who was waiting on us. 

I ordered Halibut with the seasonal vegetables and my husband ordered the Salmon, also with the seasonal vegetables. We had the goat cheese, beet and pecan salad as well as the calamari dish. 

The best dish that night was definitely the grilled calamari - if that can be turned into an entrée' it would rock. 

The halibut arrived completely uncooked! It was basically seared halibut. I told our server and he said, "oh, our current chef generally cooks it that way". If that were the case, that he served basically raw halibut, then the server should had mentioned this when we ordered. Instead of getting a fresh piece of fish, like all other fine dinning establishments would do. . . I got the same exact fish just reheated on the grill; meanwhile my sauce (for the fish) is basically cold. 

The server brings back the re-grilled fish, then asks me later "was the fish to your liking"? And I responded it was cooked thank you. I know that is kind of short but please, you don't serve raw halibut and then play it off like it's "in Vogue" or something. I enjoy Sushi immensely and you never see halibut as a sushi or sashimi. . . and this is not a sushi place.

The vegetable sides were a joke. Overcooked cauliflower, with random pieces of overcooked carrots. . . I should have asked what the "seasonal" vegetable was because the table next to us did and they decided to order spinach instead. 

I will likely not re-dine here, it seems the Hayes St. Grill has already had its Hayday.
author: Kristina A.

description: This is my friend's spot. She sings for the SF Opera so she's familiar with this place. We went on a non-symphony, non-ballet, non-opera day so seating was not an issue. Service was superb. I can't tell if it's always that way since I went with a regular. Food was fresh...but a lil' on the bland side. It was still good though. The lightness in flavoring allowed me to taste the freshness of the fish. If that's the intention then they did it well. I'm a fan of seasoning though, so I could have used just a pinch more creativity on my entree, just a pinch.
author: Helen L.

description:
Yes this restaurant exists for good reason, it's extremely close to all the Civic Center's great performing arts auditoriums. But that as far as I can tell, that is its entire claim to fame. 

Service was fine, but slow for a quiet Sunday night. I started with the fried oysters (an entree that we had served as an app) and then had sea bass for my main. The oysters were on the soggy side and while the sea bass was nicely grilled it was probably the smallest serving of fish I've ever received. 

The ambiance is old world San Francisco. Signed photos of symphony stars and the like, faces you probably won't recognize (if you're as uncultured as myself). The faded booths with geometric patterns, are clearly not geared towards my snotty and youngish demographic (most patrons were much older).
author: Jeremy S.

description: I've been going to the grill for so long that I'm almost as old as the host and the senior men on the staff.  But that is a bit the problem with the place:  the service and hosting is dreadful, so full of itself that it is no longer incapable of common courtesies; I understand that man's destiny may well be to become a Grumpy Old Man, but you don't want him waiting on you or telling you, when you return a piece of half-raw fish, that "the Grill cooks fish that way"!  Alas, the kitchen seems to have declined as well.
author: Guy h.

description:
This is a classic San Francisco establishment, it has been around for over 30 years and I love that it is unwaveringly true to itself. 

I love the cracked Dungeness Crab over a winter salad with aioli. This dish is simple, to the point and celebrates the crab. The warm goat cheese salad is divine with beautiful fresh greens, a simple sherry vinaigrette and a generous glob of delicious warm goat cheese rolled in chopped nuts. This is a salad that I crave in the wintertime! 

Service is warm and friendly, many of the staff have been in the restaurant since the beginning and it is wonderful to see how staff and faithful patrons regard each other as family. At the HSG you truly feel taken care of which is why there are so many customers who make the HSG a weekly tradition. Something about this place puts a smile on my face and if you come in for lunch on a Friday and sit at the bar you will see what I am talking about. This place is truly magical and offers a portal into old San Francisco that is irreplaceable.
author: Margot K.

description: Somewhat  disappointing... We thought we were off to a great start with the oysters, but then our fish entrees were mediocre. I substituted the French fries with the greens which were tasty ( better than the grilled yellowtail). Our server was not very personable from the get go and proved to be quite inattentive throughout the meal. Not the experience we were hoping for...
author: Renee T.

description: Disappointed.  I used to love this place, but tonight's post-symphony experience was just  ... well, nothing special.  The service was great, I must say right off the bat -- our waiter was friendly and attentive.  The wine was nice and the goat cheese salad was fine.  But the main dish, the grilled salmon, which is what I came for, was simply not very good.  I was told that the chef liked to cook it rare to medium rare.  I said I preferred medium.  Notwithstanding my request, the salmon was lukewarm and undercooked in the middle and with the pin bones still in.  But that wasn't  all -- the braised greens that came with it were also barely warm and without any seasoning.  I expect grilled fish to be hot and to taste, well, grilled, at least on the outside.  This was not.  It was essentially bland.   (I suppose I could have complained, but it was late and I was tired.)   Sigh.
author: Nina G.

description:
This place may look like any other restaurant from the outside, but inside I was surprised to find an amazing dining experience at a restaurant that seems to be a favorite among locals.

 It is near the theaters so a great spot to grab a pre-theater dinner and the service is very attentive and will get you out on time for your show. Their fries served with many dishes are pretty tasty indeed and every fish dish I have had from here has been seasoned perfectly and the sauces especially the ones with capers make my mouth water!! And don't forget to order their apple crisp dessert!! My dad and I couldn't get enough of it!!
author: Sarah G.

description: So, the food was fine.  Not great, but fine in an old-world traditional way.  The beef I have is that for what the food is, it just seems too expensive.  Our fish was perfectly cooked, the salad fresh but unimpressive Caeser.  The convenience before a performance, however, was outstanding.
author: Lisa A.

description: Ate there before Symphony and service was prompt so they get one star. My Niman beef was absolutely tasteless and when I said so to the waiter he brought me A-1. Never asked if he could get me something else or sent a manager by the table. My partners fish was very undercooked. Their attitude was one of complete apathy. We will not return.
author: Stacy S.

description:
I've heard good things about this place and was very excited to try it.  The food was ok, but the service was very disappointing for a restaurant of this caliber and price point.  

First, the waitress was not attentive.  I can understand if the waiters are understaffed (not their fault), but the restaurant was not crowded when we went.  Second, we were there for a birthday.  When I informed the waitress that we were celebrating a birthday, she said "we don't really do anything."  I had to ask if they could bring out a desert with a candle, to which she obliged, but only stressed only if we ordered a desert.  (This policy is fine, but most SF restaurants will bring a small desert out whether you order one or not.)  This seemed very awkward overall.

There are better options in the neighborhood, particularly at this price point.
author: Jason D.

description:
I read some other reviews and I am pretty sure that we were at different restaurants. My girlfriend and I went here before the San Francisco's Symphony NYE's Ball and we had a wonderful experience! So, if you gave this restaurant a two because your pork chop was a little undercooked, then order fish (that it what they're known for you know). Now, let me tell you why I'm giving Hayes St Grill a five.

Beginning:
We had a reservation. We were welcomed with a smile and seated very quickly. Our waitress quickly came to our table after we were seated and water came very quickly as well. (I love my glass of water!)

Service and Food Options:
I was very tempted to try out the fish that I heard so much about but instead went with the prix-fixe option for NYE because I was in the mood for a full meal and I couldn't say no to the short ribs. It included: Six Sweet Water Oysters in the half shell, borscht soup, Niman Braised Short Rib, and Lemon Mouse topped with Candied Lemons. My girlfriend had the Grilled Calamari with Arugula salad. It ended up being perfect the meal to satisfy our palettes and our stomachs.

Food:
The Oysters were a tad small, and therfore overpriced, so I wouldn't recommend buying them on their own unless you really like oysters. They were delicious nonetheless!
The borscht soup was soooo good.I had never tried it before and it was a little on the sweet side but very flavorful.
The Niman Braised Short Rib was cooked so perfectly with a perfect consistency of "chewiness" and smokey flavor.
The Lemon Mouse with candied lemons really took the show though. It made the perfect desert with a cup of coffee and was a wonderful portion for my girlfriend and I after the feast we had.
My girlfriend enjoyed her meal as well.

Overall:
A restaurant with great food and service (and A LOT of filling options).  the atmosphere is not quiet and private as some other restaurants that are around the same price range, but the food is definitely worth it. I definitely will return.
author: Arturo F.

description: Hadn't been here in a few years and oh what a change! ... Not for the better.  This used to be a great restaurant, but now they seem satisfied with the captive opera and theatre crowd.  On a Friday night at 7:30pm they were already out of oysters, Dungeness crab and other popular items.  The seafood items we did order were overpriced and underwhelming.  Both the tuna and "Santa Barbara halibut" were skimpy In size and didn't taste fresh. The sauces were mediocre too.   With so many really good restaurants in SF, I will leave Hayes St Grill to the tourists.
author: C S.

description:
I had dinner here last night after a beautiful evening at the San Francisco Symphony. I had the green salad, mesquite grilled halibut served with fries, coca cola to drink and an absolute out of this world sorbet!

This seemed to be a quaint quiet places. There are pictures of musicians and celebrates lining the interior walls. Service was impeccable, company was wonderful and I believe the menu is printed new everyday.
author: Patricia V.

description: Love the sole!  Great place to eat because it is consistently good. Has been in the city for decades which says a lot!
author: Nicki B.

description:
i really wanted this to be my go-to place since i live in the neighborhood but every experience has left me feeling like my time and money could be better spent elsewhere. last night was the nail in the coffin.  we arrived around 8:30 without a reservation - not a problem since all of the symphony/opera people had already eaten and the place was pretty empty. there was a party who'd finished and were talking to the maitre d' for what felt like several minutes, during which time we just stood at the end of the entrance ramp looking around for someone to acknowledge us. when they finally left and the host had no choice but to address us, he made no apology for the amount of time we stood waiting.

once we were seated (right by the kitchen, despite the place not even being half full in the main room and the other room completely empty), the waiter wasn't particularly helpful. while he took our order and occasionally refilled our water, once we actually received our food, he didn't bother to check on us until we were almost completely done. and never did he even ask us how our food actually was. my fiance was complaining to me that his side of fries looked like it'd been composed of the dregs of the fry batch - all of the short stumpy guys and crumbs. minutes later, we watched another table get 5 sides of fries which all had normal-sized pieces which must have come from a fresh bag. he mentioned it to the waiter who did bring out a half order of more average-sized fries but the damage was already done.

the waiter then asked if i wanted to look at the dessert menu rather than just share part of my fiance's final prix fixe course. i said sure and he brought me a menu. a few minutes later, without asking me if i'd decided on anything, he just brought out the prix fixe dessert. he didn't even remember that he was supposed to ask me if i wanted anything, though he did notice the menu sitting there and took it away. hello? if the menu is there, it means that someone may want to order something. !!

the food was mediocre, the service was spotty at best, and i joked that we were being discriminated against because we were too young - the clientele at that place tends to be the blue hair crowd. i really didn't get the feeling that they cared much for our business and it was pretty insulting. there was a young-ish party (probably close to our age - late 30s/early 40s) in the opposite corner that seemed to get a fair amount of attention and service from their waiter, so i don't know why our waiter seemed to be so annoyed with us.

i had the paella, which was okay. fair amount of seafood in it and the shrimps were peeled, which made it easier to eat. the style was more brothy, if you care about that kind of thing. we'd just been to a cooking class where it was made where the rice isn't stirred at all while cooking and forms a bit of crunchy crust on the bottom. this was definitely not that style. this is more fishermen's stew where the rice is less al dente.

eric had the albacore, which he was initially pretty excited about but when it arrived at the table, it was grilled to an inch of its life so it was pretty tough. he said it also had a fishy taste to it that you don't expect from a really good piece of fish (which the hayes street grill is supposedly known for - its seafood). oh, and we nearly tore up the roofs of our mouths with the bread they put on the table. there's crunchy and then there's stale and hard. being the end of the day, i think it was leaning toward the latter.

i've always felt like this place has a snootiness which kept me away. but again, because it's close to home, i kept giving it more chances. now i think i can write it off with a clear conscience. one off night i could excuse but every experience - whether it's lunch, drinks, or dinner - has been about the same. i don't feel valued as a customer or like they care to get my business again. maybe they rely on the fact that they're so close to so many performing arts organizations that there will be a never-ending supply of patrons who will come out of convenience. or maybe they treated us poorly because we weren't dressed in suits and fancy clothes like we were out for a night on the town. well, folks, this is san francisco where people wear leather chaps to the opera. you can't judge a book by its cover. or its age. choke on your snobbery, hayes street grill, i'm done with you.
author: sylvia c.

description: mediocre seafood. bad lighting (one gets tired after sitting in it for an hour). sterile decor. unfriendly waiters (the 40/50 year old overweight waiter was pretending not to see us signaling him because he is too ascribed to his flow of servicing various tables and promptly forgot that we asked him for some more butter right after we told him that it was running out). The only saving grace is the acme bread that they serve with the butter, which one could get elsewhere. enough said...
author: Rebecca C.

description: I went in for New Year's Eve. The host was nice and sat me straight away. The bread was extremely cold. I got the Salmon and Cured Roe appetizer, a glass of Champagne, and ordered the Yellowtail and fries. The appetizer was delicious. The fish for the entree was cooked perfectly but the fries were overcooked. I ordered the Creme Brulee for dessert. When the dessert arrived to me both the filling AND the sugar layer were ice cold. I had to beat the thing to death to get the top layer to crack. Most places torch the top right before serving after chilling the creme. Overall the staff was nice, firing times were good. I didn't complain because they were super busy and the kitchen was overwhelmed. For it to be that price I was hoping for a better visit.
author: Tal P.

description:
My grandma goes to Hayes Street Grill often before she goes to the ballet. I joined her for the first time and had a TERRIBLE experience. We were half way through our meal and a HUGE COCKROACH fell into my mother's lap from underneath the table. The cockroach was about 3 inches long and an 1 and a half inches wide, it was huge!  My mother quietly freaked out and only our table and the table next to us had seen what happened. The waitress caught the cockroach in our table cloth.
I know that things happen and mistakes are made but I was completely appalled when the manager came to talk to us and said that "they usually kill them before they get that big" and all they did was take a $10 glass of wine off of our meal. I never finished eating because I lost my appetite, yet my grandmother still payed a large amount for the meal.
author: Cali R.

description:
Like many people, my husband and I visited HSG in the evening prior to the symphony.  We've gone there every couple of years for quite a while.  Not again.  They've really gone down hill.  I ordered fried oysters because the menu choices were pretty limited.  There was such an over abundance that I could only eat half.  The side veggies were wilted and worthless.  My husband's fish was disappointing.  Surprisingly,
they only have one white wine by the glass IN A Fish Restaurant! ! !  Not only that, but for someone who really enjoys a nice wine, forget it.  I had a taste and, probably like lots of folks, we ended up ordering a bottle.  Tricky on their part, no?  All this for $160.  
They are resting on their old reputation and their location near many venues.  I don't plan to go back.
author: Nancy R.

description:
I've never been to the restaurant, but have been to Embarcadero Farmer's Market to their stand

The Dungeness Crab cake sandwich is absolutely incredible (hence 5 stars)

The staff that I've interacted with are very personable.

Love this place!
author: Eric D.

description: I had not been back to Hayes St. grill in many years, but now with the SF Jazz Center only a block away, I could not resist.  As always the fish was superb, and the added treat is that they have Navarro wines on their wine list.  Great service, excellent fish, and Navarro Sauvignon Blanc -- what could be finer
author: Hugh L.

description:
We had dinner Sunday evening after the Jazz center. We split an appetizer of asparagus which was delicious. However my main dish was shockingly poor. I ordered the sole which was described by the waiter as sautéed in wine and herbs with mushrooms.  An overcooked piece of fish with mushrooms in gloomy brown tasteless 
 gravy arrived. I didn't eat any of them and the fish was not good. I also think my dish was microwaved and previously cooked. It was quite expensive at 29 dollars. I think it is absolutely unacceptable. I think there was no real chef in the kitchen due to the whole presentation.
author: Elise J.

description:
This has been THE place to dine for people on the way to the Opera House and Symphony Hall for 29 years. It's especially nice to have a restaurant like this where one can have a relatively fast meal in an evening gown and not look at all out of place. The service on both of my visits was impeccable and so was the food. Both times I had fish. This evening my husband had the pork chop which, he said, was perfectly cooked and tender as can be. 
If you are catching a show be sure to make a reservation as the pre-show seatings are almost always packed.
author: Stacey C.

description: Two years later, and the food here continues to underwhelm.  I ordered a grilled yellowtail fillet, and it was woefully undercooked, especially on the underneath side.  The place continues to fill up the tables, and for some reason I keep going back too (mostly because of invitations I receive from others).  With so many other restaurants in Hayes Valley that are patently superior, I can only conclude that reputations die hard.
author: George L.

description: This review is strictly for the ferry building stand I went to this past Saturday. I thought this place was rather overpriced...correction: VERY overpriced. It was $10 for a sandwich, sure it was salmon, but still $10 for "stand" food, it's not worth it. I ordered the salmon BLT tartar, it was okay. The bread was cooked well, slightly charred, tastes good. I was disappointed by the salmon, there was nothing special about it, it wasn't the "tartar" I was expecting. Anything with bacon taste good! haha! Maybe I should have went with the crabcake sandwich.
author: Arnold W.

description:
We had been big fans of this place, having gone there half a dozen times in the past three years.  NO MORE.  We went there after the symphony last Friday - obviously, we weren't the only ones with reservations.  They were pretty effective at getting us a table, but then the fun began.  Twenty to thirty minutes before anyone came to take our order.  Bread and wine followed, fairly quickly, such that my temper had simmered down somewhat.  But then, it was another half hour before the main courses showed up.  I ordered a seafood combo with shell fish - mediocre - not horrible, but not worth the price.  Their famed caeser salad was fair at best.  My wife was pleased by her food - shrimp/avacado/orange salad and chicken livers.  But, the service was just about as bad as we've ever seen.

I advise against going period, but whatever you do, don't go after the symphony or opera.
author: Larry H.

description: Went here again....we went last year and the soft sell crab was amazing...so we called and they said as well as their website that they had soft shell crab in from Maryland...when we arrived before the Opera...the waiter told us they have not had it for 5 weeks...something about a storm...thought it was kinda bait and switch...the fish was still very good but very small portion for 28 whichis what i remembered from other trips here...also nothing is seasoned so make sure you season it yourself...would only come back if they had the blue crab...otherwhise too many other better locations in this area....also the host is not very friendly
author: Sean M.

description:
Mediocre food - starter salad was entrée sized, over-dressed, and just ok both in terms of presentation and taste.  Entrée - steak with salsa verde - was also mediocre.  Salsa verde was some of the worst I've ever had - bitter beyond words and greasy.  
Service was also just ok - didn't seem to really care or enjoy being there themselves.  The dessert - chocolate torte with berries - was excellent and the high point of an otherwise extremely lackluster dinner.  Too bad, I was meeting a good friend before the symphony too.  I have no idea how this place still is in business given the multitude of good restaurants nearby.
author: Michael D.

description: I guess it's a good thing that famous personalities eat at this spot prior to their performance (Gloria Steinem). Very good food; a little on the pricey side, but wasn't a surprise since I looked at the menu (on yelp) ahead of time. Packed by the theater crowd prior to 7:20; really opened up after that.
author: Spencer S.

description:
There are an unusual number of negative reviews here for a famous eatery. I can dispatch two of them fairly easily: the clientele is too old and it's not as good as it used to be. In a word, who cares, and who cares?

Why would you need everybody in the restaurant to be a certain age? It's true that there's no music blasting during your meal, but I take that to be a positive. It means you can actually talk to the people you're with. If you don't want to talk to them, why are you with them?

And I think the people who are comparing it to some fond memory of the place from 1977 aren't reckoning that 35 years ago, there weren't anything like the number of fine restaurants in SF that there are now. So Hayes Street stood out. It's still one of the 100 best restaurants in The City; that ought to be good enough.

What IS valid is that there are some weirdnesses at HSG. One would think that Patricia Unterman, Alice Waters' pal, would feature California cuisine. She doesn't: this is classic Continental cooking, with tons and tons of butter; Julia Child would be right at home in their kitchen. It's not rich in the sense of goopy--you're not going to get artichoke dip here. But it's nothing like the kind of heart-healthy fare that's now springing up all over. 

That's fine, you don't have to eat here every day, but if you want a scrupulously-fresh piece of fish cooked beautifully, it would be hard to do better than this. 

The second weirdness is that the default side dish is a bowl of french fries. Why? If you want fries, go to McDonalds; I have no explanation for this one.

But I had a Petrale Sole that was truly divine, and came with fingerling potatoes and mushrooms in a dreamy sauce. My date had a delicious Sea Bass with beurre blanc. But this is not your grandmother's beurre blanc; it had vermouth in it and was whipped into a creamy texture. She simply skipped the fries.

HSG offers two Niman Ranch beef entrees, but this is a fish restaurant, so stay on message. And be sure to make a reservation at least a few weeks in advance, especially if it's an opera or symphony night, and you want to go before 7:30. By 5:30 there's a long line, and if you don't have a reservation, there's no hope.

Like most a la carte menus, HSG makes their profit on salads, desserts and the wine list. If you want a nice fish entree, it's less than $30 and you can get out of there for $35 per person. Skip the rest.
author: David L.

description:
I had dinner here last night before taking the kids to the Nutcracker at the Opera House.

I found the appetizer selection pretty limiting, particularly with small kids.  The escarole and barley soup wasn't terribly good.  The goat cheese salad, however, was good.

The flatiron steak was good, and cooked precisely as ordered.  I had the grilled swordfish which was good, but surprisingly thin; the piece itself was normal size, but it was about half as thick as a typical piece of restaurant swordfish.    2 of our 3 orders of French fries were great.  1 was cold and stale.

For dessert, the kids' sundaes were fine.  The creme brule was served in too deep a dish and was cold everywhere (as opposed to the preferred hot on the top and cool in the middle -- brule, after all, means "burnt".)

My double espresso was only warm, not piping hot, when I got it.

Overall, I gave it 3 stars, not 4, because of the service which was the reason for most of the cold food.  While our waiter was nice enough, the restaurant overall didn't deal well with the pre-theater rush which is, after all, supposed to be their business.

We arrived at 5:00 PM to have plenty of time to get eat for a 7:00 PM show and we ended up getting stacked behind people who arrived between 5:15 and 5:45 PM.  When they should have moved us along quickly in anticipation of the coming rush, instead they mozied, and then we got lost in the throng.  The result:  some cold/cool food that waited too long to be served.

Next time I'll go elsewhere pre-theater:  Jardiniere, Absinthe (which appeared to be closed?), or make the hike down Gough to Espetus, the fun Brazilian steakhouse.
author: Dave K.

description: Best place for pre Opera or pre Ballet.  They are when you come in they ask, "symphony or opera?" LOL.  And they get you out on time.  We NEVER go with an RSVP and the adorable host always gets us in (I don't recommend this though, one day he won't be able to get us in).  We always order Cesar salads and fries because they are SO good.  I like the ambiance and seeing the great performers' autographs on the wall.  I come with my kids too. - It feels special and fancy and I never regret the $$ I've spent.  They always start a night at the opera out perfect.
author: Christine B.

description:
We dined here for New Year Eve Dinner with friends and Family before heading over to the San Francisco's Symphony NYE's Ball. With reservations we were seated pretty quickly and received service in a very timely manner. Our server was great and very attentive.

The food was just okay, nothing great and mouth watering. The wine and other beverages were good but they should be, right? I just wasn't impressed. The quality was alright, portion size was good and the flavor was okay. Again the food was just very mediocre and for the price tag it could leave a bitter taste.
author: Sam M.

description:
I went to this venerable institution thinking that since it specializes in seafood I would be able to get a high protein, low fat, low carb meal.  I found that this was not to be, as someone in the kitchen loves butter and the brief menu doesn't provide many alternatives.  

I started with an appetizer of oregon bay shrimp, avocado and some peas.  The small shrimp reminded me of what you used to get in sau-sea shrimp cocktails in the supermarket minus the cocktail sauce.  The teeny shrimp didn't have much taste nor did the peas.  The avocado tasted like avocado however.  

A main of sand dabs was a big disappointment.  The fish were swimming in a butter sauce.  All that one could taste here was the oil the fish had been fried in and the butter they were drowned in.  The fish came with some french fries that were french fries.  The only side of vegetables available was spinach making it hard to tip toe around the high carb fries and the clot inducing buttered fish.  

While the service was proficient, what was offered here led me to the conclusion that this restaurant just isn't trying very hard.
author: David D.

description: Friendly service, convenient before a concert at Davies, and it's nice to have sustainably sourced fish. However, I don't understand the "cover charge" at all. It equaled 5% of my check, so it seems greedy. Why wouldn't you factor it into the price of your dishes? Unfortunately a "cover charge" is a total deal breaker for me and I won't be returning.
author: Mortimer S.

description: Great environment and excellent food.  The fish is always fresh and well prepared.  A little pricey but worth the $
author: Kevin A.

description: The service was excellent, in fact some of the best I've had. The boudin blanc was tender and flavorful, as were the other dishes I've had from here. Four stars only because the dishes I've had have been poorly accompanied by other items, a problem that can be solved if you're dining with others and willing to eat family style.
author: Colin F.

description:
I'm jumping on the bandwagon like a few others who have reviewed Hayes Street Grill ... and I'm only reviewing it for their stall at the Farmers' Market.

This deliciousness can't be beat! My friend and I ordered the Crab Cake sandwich and Soft-Shell Crab sandwich and swapped halves so we could taste both. They were both served on warm, toasty and fresh bread from Noe Valley Bakery, piled with fresh greens and heirloom tomatoes (they were so sweet) and a nice dollop of tartar sauce. The crab cake sandwich was yummy, with a very tender cake that had just a bit of crispiness on the outside. It had green onions in it, and was sweet and enjoyable. I liked the soft-shell crab though, because it had a delicious crunch ... which really set it apart from the crab cake one. I think it's so neat that they take the produce from the stalls around them, so you know it's fresh.

All in all, it was an $18 well spent. I know that their restaurant hasn't gotten the hottest reviews, but the PR people at the Farmers' Market have been steppin' up their game for sure.

In other words, go get some!
author: Alison T.

description:
The food here was actually pretty good, but not the caliber I would expect given the price we paid.  I started with some dungeness crab then had the pork tenderloin.  Neither blew my socks off, but were still pretty good.  It was a nice quiet atmosphere, which worked because it was a dinner to celebrate our anniversary. Overall, it made for a nice dinner, but I think we could have gotten food that was equally as good elsewhere while paying a lot less.

I'm giving it three $s, but it was definitely at the top of that range (more than $100 for two people)
author: Justin F.

description:
Came here with family visiting from Seattle just before the New Year. We had a party of 7 reservation and were sat in the CENTER of the room, which at first seemed awkward. But it was more convenient I think for us and the staff to get around our group. Service was really great and attentive. The food was excellent. We had the chopped salad with beets to start, which was delicious. I had a steak that was tasty. But my little sister had a white fish that I almost tackled her out of her seat to steal from her. I'll be getting that next time. 
We ended up being the last people in the place and the service was super nice and patient with us.
author: Jena D.

description: Fresh, Fresh, Fresh Fish. They have great specials. They really have a wonderful bar. The parking is tough. The portions are on the smaller size. The average diners age is 50 plus, I would guess. The food is delicious.  Jason is awesome. I find it to be a bit noisy, why do people have to yell and laugh as loud as if they were the only ones in the restaurant??? Here's a clue, It's NOT OK people!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Perhaps most of them are hard of hearing!
author: JA M.

description: Just not up to par for the price.  We had a nice corner table.  Everyone basically got the same dishes:  albacore tuna salad.  Tuna portion was generous but uninteresting to eat.  The salad and dressing were okay.  Dessert was tasty but lacked form.  We all got the salted caramel bread pudding.  I couldn't find any bread and it was too runny for pudding.  Service was fine, but unmemorable.  The worst part is that we sat in a cloud of fish frying smell, which really disgusts me.  Without that unpleasantness, I'd give HSG 3.5 stars.
author: Kevin M.

description: Went here before a show. Hadn't eaten much for lunch, but figured no big deal I'll get a great dinner here before going to see Wilson-Philips. Big mistake. The menu is brief at best. And confusing. The waiter didn't explain the menu to us. We didn't know to get the fish or entrees. So we got fish. And appetizers. Two to share for three people. The plates were very small. When the fish came I think I gasped. It was literally a tiny piece of grilled salmon with a small cup of fries. My bf got an entree so he had a smattering of veggies too. Needless to say we got burgers after the show. Service is pleasant but not welcoming or attentive. Crowd is subdued and skews towards the older and dressier crowd. Not trendy. Not much value. You pay a lot for not much food. Struck me as an 80's concept in fine dining. Seemed dated. Better off going to the Grove or Absinthe instead. Even Patxi's.
author: Timoteo K.

description: This is a place we use to go before the Symphony when we lived in SF.  It's gotten very pricey with a limited menu.  The food was okay, but not fabulous.  A bit disappointing.  The chopped salad was good.  Halibut mediocre; Petrale Sole was very good (8 out of 10). It would have a been nice to have had more than three choices of fish.  Service was excellent; however, there were very few patrons this evening.  We might be back; but there are lot of excellent places in the vicinity and better seafood.  Maybe it was an off night.
author: Ann K.

description:
I have to agree with ds, on 10/12 who wrote "very, very, very mediocre food at expensive prices". I was ready to enjoy Hayes Street Grill after the theatre on a sunday night, but both the clientele and the food were old! I don't mind dining with older patrons, but the food was safe and appropriate for a retirement home. Nothing sparkled...not like the old days when it was such a good place to eat. And the service was also without a "thank you". That bothers me when I'm leaving more than a 20% tip.
And, really, don't serve me ice cold creme brulee and tell me "that's how we do it here". Really?
author: Janice P.

description: Hayes St. Grill has been my #1 SF dine out choice for over 20 years.  I travel the world and they're still my gold standard.  At a high end restaurant, one pays for service, quality, unflappable efficiency and genuine interest in customers -- yes, and food, but anyone can cook.  Few can put it all together like Hayes Street Grill does.   Plating a food doesn't need to be an art form either.  I feel relaxed here, served well, respected, and always pleased when I leave.  I found the complaints here disturbing and, frankly, unbelievable (or at best, exaggerated).  One wonders if the diners mentioned it to anyone at the restaurant to see the reaction.  Please do if you have a problem.  I'm sure any issues will be resolved.  There's a reason they just celebrated 30 years of serving happy diners.  They know how to do food and service well.
author: Bill B.

description:
1.25 rounding down.

Ambiance:  No music, few people under 190 years old.

Service:  Unattentive at best.  

Food:  Dry and bland ono, generic dipping sauces, lukewarm white nectarine and blackberry crumble, bland house sausages.  The grilled calamari wasn't actually grilled, but was actually flavorful.

Not the kind of place where you can ask for ketchup and feel like it's not offending anyone.
author: Katie M.

description:
First time at the Hayes Street Grill was a mixed bag. 

Loved the wine recommended by the staff as a red that would not overwhelm fish, a 2008 Fort Ross Pinot Noir. I'm not usually a huge Pinot Noir fan, but our table of 4 went through 2 bottles and I bet I drank one all by myself.

Loved my salad with shrimp and avocado.  My husband's mushroom soup was good, as was our friends chopped salad. 

The waiter said not to order the yellow tail off the grill menu, so I didn't.  I like honest waiters. They toed the line between informative and overbearing but did not cross it. 

My fish, a mahi mahi  off the grill menu, was OK but not thrilling. The texture was great but the flavor was only fair. I probably did not help matters by getting lemon-caper sauce. I imagine the salsa would have been better but I hate cilantro so didn't want to get it.  My husband's sole, off the main menu, had a better sauce and was very flavorful with a nice texture. French fries were fair-to-middling, served cute in paper-lined glasses.  

Desserts: I had the creme brulee, which  I usually love. The burnt sugar was the bitterest I've ever tasted, not pleasant. My husband's coffee ice cream was tasty but nothing extraordinary--I mean, it's ice cream.  Our friends' chocolate cake had a gummy texture and less chocolate flavor than I would have liked.

On the starters and mains, I can't complain that the sauces or dressings  overwhelmed the featured ingredients. If you like food where the single featured  ingredient (or ingredients in the case of salad) are of good quality and allowed to stand alone, you will probably like Hayes Street Grill. My personal preference runs to a little more lively melding of flavors and textures. 

Even after the 7:30 off-to-the-performance rush, service was lightning-fast. You order, the plates fly to your table. It was faster than some of the weekday lunch places in the Financial District.
author: Susie L.

description: Good down to earth food. We all had fish and it was cooked quite well. It's a no frills restaurant and still very popular even after all this time. Conveniently located near the Jazz club and cool shops.
author: Patricia L.

description: Went here for a Chimay and warm goat cheese salad with asparagus. Good, but nothing remarkable; service was very good. Servings are much too small for the price - in a city where there are so many dining options, talented chefs and innovative cuisine, you can easily obtain five-star food elsewhere for the same price.
author: Kit A.

description: Same basic for the past 10+ years - fish-centric. Salmon and swordfish both cut very thin. Calamari & black bean salad - not too bad but a strange combination. Caesar salad a 'chopped' presentation (wrong) with a nothing dressing. Totally overpriced. It'll be another 10 years before we go back - if then.
author: Ron M.

description: a word of caution, run don't walk from this restaurant. the service is decent and the decor is nice, but there is no other way to put this, the food sucks. overpriced undercooked. you would think a restaurant critic/owner would have it together, well think again
author: Don G.

description:
Ok, so I'll start by saying this is my frist review.  Woohoo! Yay me.  
We stopped by Hayes Street Grill post Symphony, as a third choice (Absinthe and Jardiniere had long waits--yes, I know, I should make reservations next time), and were immediately struck by the fact that this place seems stuck in another era.  Ok, not necessarily a bad thing, and I can certainly respect tradition.  
Oh, I don't know if the hostess was having a bad day or what, but can you say rude and unprofessional?
Our waiter noticed that we were not satisfied with our initial seating, even though the hostess did not bother to check.  He moved us to better seating, at which point we took a look around and determined that we were surrounded by what appeared to be every grandparent in the SF Bay area.
Anyway, on to the food.  Appetizers of soup and sald were very good.  A green salad was truly that...simply deep, dark green leaves drizzled with a delectable viniagrette.  
Butternut squash soup was also good, albeit a tad bland. I added cracked black pepper, and it was perfect.  It was also served piping hot.
The main course was the scallop dish, which only came with 4 small scallops.  Though..they were cooked perfectly.  They were surrounded by what appeared to be mixed veggies out of a can. : I
The sauce accompanying the scallops was tremendous. 
Wine selection had just been re-jiggered and was passable.  I had a Rioja and was satisfited.  
In a word: Overpriced.
Good food, but not a lot of value there, especially considering you are surrounded by social security recipients.  
I may take my grandmother here next time she comes to visit, and make sure to get the fries...
author: Ethan R.

description: I had grilled calamari as appetizer and the sole as main entree: the quality of the fish and preparation was good, the calamari were in fact above expectations, but the halibut someone else ordered was quite dry. A general lack of salt characterized most of the dishes. Overall the experience wasn't terrible but the place is unquestionably overpriced. The double white tablecloth standard may justify the expenses the owner probably has to bear, but $95 for 1 appetizer and 2 entrees (we did not order any wine or drinks) seems high for the size of the portions and the overall experience.
author: Riccardo T.

description:
My boyfriend took me here before we went to see the Nutcracker (amaazing! esp Yuan Yuan Tan!), and ahhh, it was soo yummy. We went around 5pm because the ballet was at 7pm. We had made a reservation (you can make them up to three weeks in advance), and I think it's necessary on the night of any kind of show in the area. 

I appreciate that they use the freshest fish of the day and change their menu accordingly.. that said, my fish was so unbelievably delicious that I wish it was a permanent entree!!!!

I had a sake kasu marinated black cod which came with a couple grilled eggplants, a radish/other vegetables salad with a creamy pan-asian type dressing, and white rice. Mmmmmm. Absolute perfection. This was one of the best pan-asian dishes I have ever had. It brought me back to the sake kasu taste of Japan, which was an added bonus for me. 

My boyfriend had halibut with a Vietnamese flair. It came on top of glass noodles and salad. 

The caesar salad that I started my meal off with was delicious too. The wine list was good too, though I didn't have any. 

The servers were all very friendly, which always brightens the experience. Nice mellow ambiance with unique decor (photos, autographs and other neatly displayed memorabilia of ballerinas and other celebrities), and it is romantically lit. You would probably wanna dress slightly formally (to formal) here. 

You get a big vase-like pitcher of water at the table (like in France!) so we had no problem with refills :)

We didn't have time for dessert, but I will go back!!!
author: Saori E.

description:
At a conference on Mkt. St. a few weeks ago with an hour and a half for lunch, hubby and I jogged over to the Hayes St. Grill. I had forgotten about this acclaimed eatery because it used to be impossible to get in, and besides I dislike the bland, nothing decor and the lack of connection with the street. But on that day I had the soft-shell crab BLT which was as divine a sandwich as I've ever had. 

So last night when we were on our way to Woodhouse for a casual din, hubby said well you liked Hayes St. so much, why not go back? He called and managed to snag a reserv. with 10 minutes to go, and we got the last table in the house at 6:30ish with an opera-heavy crowd cramming both rooms. 

On the way in I saw the notice on the door that they were going to be closed for 3 days in a row - holiday w/e. So I told hubby, well, the portions are gonna be big - they don't want to leave anything for next Tuesday. What I didn't anticipate is that every mouthwatering entry on the menu would have a dot next to it. All the softshell crab dishes - even appetizers - the petrale sole, the yellow tail, etc. - sold out.

Asked about the other dishes, the waitress described the Ft. Bragg Rex Sole as "small, like sand dabs." My husband didn't hear her (nor did he realize that "on the bone" meant that fish-bone picking was required;) he liked the dish - which was nicely pan-fried - but would've ordered something more substantial. It came with a few skimpy sprigs of watercress and the restaurant's famous fries (which really are good, if you like fries.)
