I got the Grilled Miso-marinated Bolinas Black Cod which was supposed to come with roasted eggplant - but they were all out of eggplant; so the substitution was a bowl of watery, sugary (like candied yams, my husband observed)  skin-on squash chunks and mushrooms. The theme of the dish was Asian and the other accompaniments were a delicious "Japanese salad," consisting of young spinach leaves and slaw-cut cabbage with a miso-based dressing, and steamed rice sprinkled with black sesame seeds. So the squash, besides its other deficits, was incongruous with the rest of the plate. As to the fish, it was very fresh, nicely charred on the outside, had a yummy marinade, and was too raw for my taste on the inside. 

For dessert, I ordered the coupe of sorbets - raspberry and blackberry - which were supposed to come with a pistachio tuile. But since there were no tuiles left and a sort-of zweibach cracker substituted, our waitress comped my dessert. I have to mention that when I was choosing a glass of wine, she actually suggested the least expensive offering. I can't remember a server doing that in my entire life.

My husband ordered the apricot walnut tarte; I had already had enough walnuts - which were embedded in the creamy goat cheese mound on top of the underdressed mesclun salad that he had shared with me - so I passed on the tarte to my regret. The crust and the streusel topping were heavenly, as was the absolutely fresh-from-the-tree apricot filling. I had to work fast to cadge a couple of forkfuls before he inhaled the dish.

My decaf was okay; hubby the coffee connoisseur, after his couple of regular cups at Hayes St., had to go to Blue Bottle for his fix; unfortunately it was closed by then.

I have to echo the comments of others re the emptiness of the room and the age of the crowd. I think we (60ish) were the youngest couple in the house. It was filled with elegant oldsters who exited en masse in time for the opera. Afterwards - notwithstanding a prix fixe din for $33 starting at 7:30 - it was a morgue. I have to wonder how our venerable institutions like the opera, symphony and theater - and the secondary businesses like this restaurant that thrive on their patronage - are going to survive when these deep-pocketed culturati go. The Hayes St. Grill would do well to try to capture the youthful crowd that jammed Absinthe down the block.
author: Leigh G.

description: I liked the atmosphere, although the surrounding shops were very snooty and overpriced. I had the softshell crab BLT, which was amazing except it had a little too much horseradish in the spread. The fries were awesome. Good service. Be careful at lunchtime because a lot of business men dine there and tend to have very loud conversations. The close proximity of the tables makes that unable to ignore.
author: MiChele M.

description:
Wow, from the outside, I thought this was gonna be a burger and fries/ fish and chips kinda joint.  I was way wrong.  French cuisine, white table clothes, waiters that look like my Grandpa.  

We had the sea scallops.  Cooked perfectly, served over mash.  They have Chimay too, Yay!  

It gets crowded after/before a show, since it's so close to the symphony hall/ballet.  We didn't have ressies, and were seated pretty quickly.  However, I would probably recommend reservations.
author: Sarah F.

description: Solid place. I always get the fish, I've actually never tried anything else. I always either get the yellowtail or the salmon. Everything is cooked pretty simply, and then you get to choose a yummy sauce to go with it (the lemon butter sauce is SOOOOO good!!) The fish also comes with an order of french fries, which are also delicious. I usually start with their ceasar - it's good and reliable. I definitely recommend this place, especially if you're going to the opera/symphony nearby.
author: Ashley H.

description:
if it weren't for my parents, i would never have gone here because i'm a starving & broke college student and this place is pretty pricey-but for good reason. my mom sings for the SF symphony chorus so always has shows at the davies symphony hall. this spot is perfect to go after for drinks & dinner, especially because of it's decor (it's decked out with signed posters & pics of musicians and performers). 

i've been here a few times and have always had an enjoyable experience. the service is impeccable. i hate when more expensive restaurants have snooty servers but the people here are nice without being condescending.

i had some sort of a salad with salmon on it and was surprised at how filling it was. usually salads aren't as filling as an entre but after having this along with the calamari starter, i was perfectly content. 

the selection is not huge, but the quality of the dishes is worth it. all of our meals were delicious & combine that with good service & a great location, and you have a great restaurant!
author: Jane S.

description:
Very basic interior, good selection of fresh fish. At $32 for a small (but good) piece of salmon, why can't they  figure out to heat the plates so my food doesn't get cold when they're busy? Standard practice  at most decent restaurants.

This place caters to the Symphony crowd and the prices are $5-10 higher  than similar places elsewhere.

At more reasonable prices, I would give them three stars. If the plates were heated they might get 4.
author: Peter J.

description:
Service was great, nice people, attentive.

Fish was delicious, fresh.  I had yellow tail, medium rare.  The only problem with the dish was that one side was medium, the other was rare.  They could have done better with an even cooking.

The fries that came with the fish were the WORST I have ever had.  I dare say worse than any fast food fries I've ever choked down.  They were mostly small scraps of small nothingness.  They almost ruined the meal for me.

This place is out of my normal price range: $24 for the Yellow Tail and fries, but almost worth it because of the fish.
author: kellen h.

description:
We always love this place.  They have excellent fries!  The pork chop is always amazing.  Steak is very good too.
Service is great - always on time for the symphony afterwards.
author: Cher S.

description: I have been going to the HSG since its opening when I worked and lived in SF, but it has been years since my last visit.  We were going to an event at the SF Jazz Center last night so I picked the restaurant to see how it was holding up.  I'm afraid the answer is "not very well."  Aside from the decor, which seems unchanged from day one, the food was abysmal.  Shrimp Louis salad brought us gray, pallid shrimp; hardly any lettuce; cubed avocado and sliced beans.  It simply had no taste or appeal and looked like something from a chain restaurant.  Next up, fried sardines.  They were cooked in old oil which left a funky aftertaste (and indigestion) for both of us the rest of the night.  And that's saying something given my strong constitution and tolerance of a wide variety of food.  {In fact, when we arrived home after the performance the first thing I did was make some peppermint tea to settle my stomach.}  Against my better judgment (knew I should have ordered something from the grill), I had the crab cakes.  Fried, flavorless and without any delicacy or sense of crab.  One of my signature dishes are crab cakes made with blue crab from the Chesapeake, but Dungeness can work too.  These were a pale imitation of crab cakes, and again, had the whiff of old oil.  On the other hand, the french fries are still very good and worth checking out.  Trying to cut our losses, we opted to split a dessert.  Panna Cotta with raspberries; hard to mess up right?  Served in a ramekin that resembled a juice glass, which proved to be too tall to provide a balanced taste with each spoonful.  But the clincher for me was when my wife observed that it tasted just like raspberry yogurt.  And she was absolutely right.  For the price, this was a dismal experience and poor value.  In light of the many dining options in the city and in Hayes Valley, I have no plans to ever return to the HSG.  What a shame.  My, how the mighty have fallen...
author: Chris B.

description: Great place to have a few drinks and appetizers before a show at the theatre.  The waiters are extremely aware that you're trying to catch a show and will be prompt in bringing out your apps and drinks so you can pay and leave with a little time to spare.
author: Maxine S.

description: hayes street grill is solid- the food is always fresh and always good.  the service is awesome- they are super busy during performance times and we still always get personalized, professional and kind service.  my only reason for not giving it 5 stars is the atmosphere is a bit dated and old.  i think a small face lift would do this place good.  but if you are looking for a great, solid, fresh meal, this is a great place.
author: Samantha B.

description: The food and the service were good BUT they served mashed potatoes with my dish (pork chop) that were clearly "spuds" from a box.  I mean come on!  It you charge for mashed potatoes.. please don't be so cheap.  Never, ever in all my days of dining in San Francisco or elsewhere have I eaten such a cheap heap of spuds.  In fact, I will not go there again unless I hear that they are serving the real thing... pathetic.
author: Laura T.

description:
I went here for my office Christmas party... free food and drinks... Yay!
So my unbiased opinion, it was WAY over priced and although they did offer a full bar I wasn't very happy with the "lack of blood" on my plate with the steak I ordered RARE. Though it was quite rare, I'd have prefered it to be bleeding a *bit* more... Over pretty good.
I was told the Creme Brulee was 'the best in the city', being a Creme Brulee connoisseur I HAD to try it! 
The verdict... Meh... it was to "custardy" and not enough cream. The sugar they caramelized was too thick and tasted a bit like the butane from the torch.
All in all, if I had a disposable income and could waste $40 per person I probably still wouldn't have the Creme Brulee again!
author: Sarah H.

description:
Goat cheese salad was great.  Sea bass was good.  My fiance got the homemade sausage which was very good.  Very good wine selection and the mark up isn't too crazy.  
But seriously they need too do something about their exhaust/ventilation system.  
When we walked into the dining room portion it was very smokey.  My eyes burnt a little.  When we left we both smelled like a deep fryer - which is really gross and made me self conscious at the opera.  I expect something like that from a greasy spoon but not from a normal restaurant  that services a lot of opera and symphony patrons.  So, my suggestion to Hayes Street Grill is to fix or invest in a new exhaust/ventilation system in your kitchen.  Other than that it was a nice dinner.
author: samantha D.

description:
Co-owner & head pastry chef is a family friend so I guess I may be already biased. The food was supreme. Oysters, salad, fish and fries. Damn close to heaven. Hog Island oysters are... so good. I split the warm goat cheese salad with the mother unit and it was everything I had expected.

Has anyone ever heard of Steelhead fish? Really good almost like salmon but more mild in fish taste. Dessert....chef friend came to sit with us and insisted we try it all. Everything was amazing, but the top, top, top was the brulee. Tasted like chomping into a hunk of sweet butter. Great filling station for all of your gastronomic needs. Great staff. Chill atmosphere and just down-right good food. Come here for the bay seafood.
author: Jonathan B.

description: It's a reliable, non-trendy place very conveniently located near the symphony and opera venues.  I like it, I go, I leave satisfied.  It's not necessarily for a special night out, but that's okay, they don't all have to be special.  You will avoid the young loud crowd.  The fish is well prepared and the service is just fine (I mean that in the best possible way).  It's a good place to take someone who is not adventurous in their food preferences.  Don't recommend it to your visiting foodie friends.
author: Laura H.

description: I have walked by this place for a bit now and it was not crowded one night so I came in. I didn't realize it was a "fancy" place. I walked in a bit of a mess and got a few stares from the staff and other customers. Oh well :) But I still sat down and ordered. The menu looked so good. So I got their swordfish with a side of fries. Well what I got was a tiny piece of swordfish and a large amount of fries. The fries were not that great. The swordfish was good, but not filling. I wasn't happy in the end especially after receiving the bill. It was like 30 bucks or so. Meh not my fave at all.
author: Greg G.

description: Kind of your classic San Francisco place. They know their way around seafood, especially fish. The ambiance is nice, but relaxed, and the service is great. It probably won't blow you away, but you'll walk out of the restaurant very satisfied.
author: Louis D.

description: First time, last time. Crummy food, rude service. Was looking forward to a nice dinner with friends to celebrate a birthday before a show. The room was so warm that  we sweltered; requests to turn on the overhead fan were met with shrugs, "I can't reach it", and "it doesn't work".  Yellow Jack was very dry, not fresh. When the waiter came to clear and saw my dinner virtually untouched, he suggested that I "take it home to give to my cat".   I asked him to take it off the bill, he stalked off, returning some time later to wordlessly slap the amended bill on the table and walk away.  Decent food, a comfortable environment, and pleasant waitstaff is what brings customers back. Hayes Street Grill epic failed on all counts.
author: Paula F.

description: I have been coming here for a few years. While there are a lot of new, slick, fancy places to go in Hayes Valley, I do like that this place is still here (but I like the new places too).  Whenever I've come in, the host and bartender are friendly and accommodating.  Most recently we popped in just before closing to get some dessert.  My bf had a chocolate sour cream cake with coffee ice cream and I had a berry pudding with whipped cream -- we were both very happy with our desserts!  In prior visits, I've had dinner here, usually selecting from their fresh fish of the day with french fries.  This combo has never disappointed. The wines have always been good -- I remember once they had a gewurztraminer wine and a gewurztraminer juice so I ordered both to compare, which was kind of fun. A few times I've come in with a friend just to get a drink.  The decor is sort of dated, but I kind of like it that way :)
author: Andrea T.

description:
After years and years of walking by this SF establishment, I finally got around to visiting yesterdy evening. For those who don't know it, HSG is one of the classics for a slightly older generation to dine at before the Opera or the Symphony, so it's actually easier to get a table after 7:30pm than say at six pm. That said, it has that neighborhood feel and walk-ins are definitely welcome and expected.

For starters, my friend and I went with the Farmers' Market Chopped Salad, which I thought was one of the better versions I've tried. We also tried the Shrimp Salad, which was pretty good as well. Nothing fancy but I think what HSG is about is preparing classic dishes and doing them right. The menu, by the way, changes daily, a sign of their frequent repeat diners.

For a city so close to the water, most of our official seafood restaurants are terrible. HSG (along with the Pacific Cafe) seem to be the exceptions. We tried two of the standard fish entrees - and both the Alaskan Halibut and Alaskan Salmon were freshly grilled and delicious. You can order sauces for dipping (the Beurre Blanc and Herb Shallot Butter are nice options), but the beauty is that HSG lets the fish stand on its own. Again, nothing fancy, just thoughtful and skilled preparation.

Note:  For the non-seafood lover, there are plenty of alternatives -the House-Made Boudin Blanc Sausages and the Niman Pork Chop both looked like stand-outs from my table observation.

The wine list is classic too, and there are some nice options by the glass - my recommendation is to make your menu selection and then let the able staff suggest a pairing.

Oh, how could I forget, the fish dishes all come with big french fries, nice and golden and crisp.

I noticed two reviews from Sameer S. and Big C. for this place - they're both anonymous - go figure, they sound like chumps!
author: Nish N.

description:
I usually only go to this place a few times a year and it's usually a special occasion like birthday or ballet tickets but I never get tired of it. I would describe it as a kind of a locals place. Locals who are in the arts scene of which I am not but I still like to go here. The food is great. When you walk in the place you can tell it has some history.

Here is what you should order:

Quail Salad (depending on the night) or Cesar
Any fish plate - but the key is to order the peanut sauce. It really is one of the best things they have. I order two because I eat it with my fries.
Creme Brulee

To drink: Orangina, Chimay, or wine/champagne

And your set! Enjoy.
author: Bryan K.

description: Went on a busy night before the Symphony. Very busy but very professional service and good food. Attentive to our schedule. Nice restaurant.
author: Band E.

description:
Light, airy, pleasant.

Hayes Street Grill was great for lunch on my first day of work.  What a pleasant experience.  The food was out of this world, really I had the best crab meat salad ever today I could eat it again for dinner.

Service was fantastic, quick but not rushed, and everything was just perfect.  It's an old neighborhood restaurant with white tablecloths and all but no stuffy vibe - friendly and politely attentive, and the food was amazing.  

Love HSG and will be back soon!
author: James M.

description:
This review is *only* for the fries, so take the 4 star rating above with a grain of salt (bad pun, I know). The fries are on the 7x7 list and are damn good for plain fries. I'd give more stars for something more inventive, but there's a ceiling of 4 stars for plain fries in my system so consider that. Good fries. 

Their fries makes me want to go back for the fish and chips, because if you can make plain fries perfectly you have a good head start on fish and chips. But I haven't tried theirs so I really don't know.
author: A A.

description:
I don't normally do bad reviews, preferring to focus on only good places.  But I'll make an exception in this case since I know it probably won't hurt; this place has been there forever and continues to draw from a seemingly never-ending fount of blue-hair opera and symphony goers.  

This is a tired old war-horse of a restaurant, serving dry, over-done grilled fish and steaks with lemon-caper-butter sauce.  You can get food ten times better at Chow's, for half the price, or at Absinthe, with better service and in a nicer environment.
author: Todd E.

description:
We ate at HSG for the first time last night, Dec 19, 2010. I would not recommend this restaurant. I've heard about it forever and always wanted to try it but was hugely disappointed overall. In my opinion, it's way too expensive for what you get and the decor/atmosphere is depressing.

      On the plus side: Our waiter was really nice and personable, not overbearing. The bus boy and receptionist were very nice. The Flatiron steak and the Scallops were incredibly good.

      But other than that, it was not good. The decor is awful. I was really surprised at how dirty and shabby it is considering their high prices. The upholstered seats were all really dirty and obviously old. The walls are drab and institutional looking. The old, dark photo's in cheap frames all in a line looked depressing. The floor leading to the bathroom and in the bathroom were coated in years old grease and I was worried I'd slip and fall (we were going to the ballet and I was in heels). The restroom (by the kitchen) was dirty and funky - like you'd find at an old gas station.

      While the Steak and Scallops were very good, nothing else was. The Caesar salad, at $11, was very ordinary. Did not like the French Fries, they were way too salty and had no flavor. The roasted vegetables (a couple of halved brussel sprouts, overcooked celery and yellow peppers I believe) were extremely blah - I normally love roasted vegetables but these were so flat and boring I had no interest in eating them.

      While the waiter was really nice, he obviously had too many tables because service wasn't good. We waited over 30 min between finishing our salad and getting our entrees. And what was odd was, our waiter brought my companion's entree but not mine. I had to wait about 4 more minutes before getting mine. It was strange. Never had that happen before when there was only two of us.

      We finished our entrees and waited at least 20 min with our dirty dishes in front of us before anyone took them away - then waited a long time before our waiter came by to ask us about dessert. We had had enough of HSG by then and couldn't wait to get out of there, so we said no to dessert and coffee and left.

      After the ballet we went to Max's Opera cafe to have dessert. We loved it! They had a fantastic piano player, lots of cheery Christmas decorations and a very fun, sparkly festive atmosphere. The complete opposite of HSG. Wished we had eaten there, for half the price of HSG and with much better atmosphere.

Reviews for Hayes Street Grill

    *
author: B. G.

description: We went before the opera, and the food was wonderful!  Sat at the bar, because the dining room was a bit smelly, but enjoyed it very much. Fabulous seafood, great chocolate desert, yummie wine, helpful staff.
author: Jessica S.

description:
So Sad. I took a co-worker here for her birthday and the entire meal was a disappointment. (Scratch that, the fry's were as good as the reviews say, oh and the wine) So much that I promised her another lunch. We brought another guy from the office as well. He asked me to try his Yellow Tail because he said he had never tasted a fish like that. He thought it was unique. It was just bad. 
This is a place I want to like. I want it to be better. It's an old school type place. Man was I disappointed. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE look at what you're doing and try to improve. You have a cool place but you should be aging like your clientele gracefully. If you don't you will just die off. 
All three pieces of fish were dry and clearly not fresh. The portions were small and the cuts were terrible. All three pieces looked like the last selections out of the cooler at Safeway. the garnish, look, who cares right, but if your going to bother at least use fresh watercress, not some wilting sad remnant. 
The deserts, well we only ordered one, Crème Brulee, my favorite desert in the world. The crust was so thick it would barely crack and the custard it self tasted like poached egg. The free birthday desert our awesome waiter brought us was much better. 
James (our waiter) you are awesome my man. A true gent and a professional in every sense. Our tip was based solely on your great service and professionalism. Get out of there dude or help them get better. You asked us how everything was. I am sorry, its not that I am too chickens&*t to be honest, I just didn't see the point. The point of this review is to hopefully open up the eyes of the owners and get their asses to improve this place pronto. What a shame! 

Exceptional service, sad sad food, but at least it is very expensive!
author: Dennis K.

description:
I met my mom and her fabulous friend here for a friday night, pre-theater dinner.  I walked in wearing jeans, high-heeled boots, and a beat up red leather jacket.  The grey-hairs in the room were not impressed.  They were even less impressed with my mom's friend, who came in wearing tight jeans, a shirt of some sort, a very sparkley blue sorta scarf, and a sport coat.  My mom said that the little old lady one table over gave him 'the eye'.

All that is to say, don't go here for pre-theater food unless you're old, or like to pretend you are.  And to get a pre-theater reservation, you'd apparently have to call three weeks in advance anyway.  

The service was a bit scattered.  The host was nice enough to help me figure out what name the reservation was under, and seat me before my party arrived.  If we had been a little bit more expeditious in figuring out what we wanted to eat, and the service had been a bit more attentive, we would have had time for desert. (6pm reservation for an 8pm curtain).  As it was, no desert :(.  And we had to look around for our waitress for at least 5 min in order to get the check. 

The food was good.  I enjoyed the warm goat cheese salad. I actually ended up choosing the steak for a main, which was cooked just fine, and nicely portioned.

I expected a bit more, but my mom and her friend were happy.  So that evens out to 4 stars.
author: Hilary K.

description:
Came here on a Sat Evening. Party of Five.
Not a single one of us was very impressive.  
I'm not sure what the deal with this place is. My guess is the restaurant is sustained by the steady flow of elderly theater goers, but it definitely isn't anything special.
author: Michael O.

description: We selected the Hayes Street Grill because it is very close to the San Francisco Symphony Hall.  We made our reservations several weeks in advance and we looked forward to a lovely meal before the symphony performance.  Pro: It was extremely crowded, but we were seated immediately.  Cons: The food was unimpressive and menu over-priced. Our waiter was in a constant rush, barely allowing us time to ask questions and could not give us any recommendations on wine or food.  In addition, after an expensive meal, we noticed a $10 COVER CHARGE had been added to our handwritten check.  This is unacceptable.  After inquiring about the charge, we were informed the money went into a "health fund" for minimum wage employees. I'm not against the cause, but it was not indicated on the menu and we were not informed about the charge when we made our reservation.  Beware out of town diners.....there are some San Francisco restaurants that are charging this fee at their own discretion and for any amount they think is appropriate.   What a disappointment, we will not be returning to the Hayes Street Grill in the future.
author: Jesse C.

description:
Love this place.  Great neighborhood style and character!
Great French fries and save room for a hot fudge sundae to end off a meal!
author: Steve N.

description:
I came here for lunch with my workmates today. It was our holiday luncheon. HSG deserves minus 5 stars for poor customer service.

When the waiter came by to take our drink orders, I asked if we could have separate checks. And he said, I kid you not, "You want NINE separate checks?" Like I asked him to take off his pants and dance on the table. And I said, "Yes." He mumbled something and left. My workmates were happy that I asked but we were all disappointed with his response. I mean this is a place where the LUNCH entrees are coming in at $25. What ever happened to customer service?

Then the restaurant manager comes to speak to me at my table and proceeds to ask me how I thought that I would pay for lunch. Excuse me? Is this really necessary? Do we have to draw this out any longer with this public shaming of little me who just wanted her own check for her own piece of fish and not have to pay other people's drinks?

So I tell him that I fully intend to pay for lunch as does everyone else at the table. And then he incredulously asks, "Do you do this all the time?" Um YEAH! I've been to group work meals at all types of restaurants where the staff is more than happy to split the check. We don't care if you tack on the 18% gratuity; I just don't want to end up paying for someone else's excessive eating!

The he says, "You will have to work something out with cash because we won't do separate checks." And then he walked away. 

That left a sour taste in my mouth. 

I'm a 20-something making the cheese but not enough to want to eat out at a place like this for lunch and drop upwards of $25 for ONE MEAL.

With the exception of delivering the bill, our waiter only came by once after the starters were served to ask us how it was and then he never came back. 

No eye contact or thank yous. 

The only decent service came from the water guy, the bread guy, and the guy who cleared the table and gave us dessert menus. This was a sweetie who asked before taking and was swift and elegant with cleaning up. And the fries are pretty good.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
A great place to go with friends for a slightly upscale dining experience, and only if you like fish!  The menu was almost entirely fish, save for the steak and chicken dish listed.  So many delicious choices prepared in so many different ways - some were more Asian themed, some more contemporary American themed.

I had the Sole with mushrooms and a cream sauce, which was delicious!  Everyone else in my party loved their fish and said it was perfectly cooked and tender.  The fries were tasty and the crunchiness was a nice contrast to the fish.

Service was very polite and non-intrusive, the way I like it.  The restaurant is decorated with old symphony and opera posters, as well as autographed photos by major symphony & opera players.

Dinner (4 fish entrees, 4 glasses of wine) came to be ~$160 total, so it definitely is on the pricier side, but well worth it.  Be sure to make reservations!
author: Wendy T.

description: A true bastion and classic in the SF dining scene.....freshest of the fresh.  No whiz bang fancy pants stuff...expertly prepared seafood matched by a list of sauces, depending on your mood.  Old school dining room (operated by Patty Unterman) with hunter green carpets and brass railings, palm trees--lending to the bygone days of Stars, Square One, Ernie's...my preferred method is to plop myself on the bar and order from the full menu.  Last time, I had a softshell crab with meuniere sauce, and French fries.  I washed it down with Anchor Steam.  No frills, no gimmicks, yet it all hits the spot.  Bullseye.
author: Angelo S.

description: Meh..is about right. The wine selection was meh at best the fish was somewhat bland and lukewarm at best, as was the vegetables that accompanied it. I have strong suspicion that the food was pre cooked and reheated slightly as it arrived just under 4 minutes of ordering it. With all the great restaurants that are in the neighborhood I would pass unless I want a $25+ entree and meal that finishes in 20 minutes or less...
author: Kacey H.

description: Food really good, service iffy, and they charge $3 for coffee refills. The waitress could've told us,kinda made me feel like they were padding the bill especially when the refills were mostly warm-ups.  i had the salmon -delish
author: pascual e.

description:
2.5 stars

I didn't enjoy our meal for several reasons.  First of all the main dining room is off the kitchen and was stifling hot and very noisy.  The table we had - sort of in the middle at the front - wasn't really that terribly close but my chair just seemed to be in the way of every waiter going by.  The starter was OK (not memorable since I can't remember what it was) but the main course made shoe leather look tender.  One of the friends we were with ordered her pork chop well done, while I ordered mine medium rare, so I can't fault them for cooking it to hockey puck toughness but I can fault them for giving it to the wrong person.  The waiter never returned to ask us if things were OK.  I would have sent it back (or bounced it back) in a second.  THe chocolate fudge sundae for dessert was good but nothing special.  I guess I might go back if someone else was paying.
author: S L.

description:
When you walk into this place, you know it is going to be expensive, but what you don't know is how mediocre the food will be. The prices are outrageous for the quality of the food and portions they serve. The lunch menu boasts fish and meat dishes for $25-30.

I ordered the Chinese Chicken Salad ($14.50), which was decent to say the most. This was a run of the mill chicken and lettuce salad with peanut dressing and some ramen nooddles on the side. AND If you thought that the portion size would make up for the medocrity, to justify this salad costing $14.50, you'd be sorley disappointed. 

The only thing this restaurant really has going for it is the personable staff who work hard to give you personal attention. Perhaps to get a tip after the disappointing food and outrageous prices.
author: Rachel B.

description:
#38 on the "big eat sf" list

French fries

...meh. i dropped by on my way back. the host was kind enough to get me fries to go (might not be a usual thing). glanced at the menu and seemed a bit expensive, buts seems to be a neighborhood hold out so i'm sure i'm missing out by not trying anything else yet. 

the fries though - why so special? the parmesan fries at the "catch" place in the bloomingdales food court is much better, as are in n out...
author: S V.

description:
Came here to try their famous fries, as its listed in the 7x7 list. Maybe because it was included on the list that my expectations were very high. I imagined the perfect frie...i should've lived my life's motto: low expectations.

The restaurant has a very unassuming green awning, can barely tell its a bustling restaurant from the outside. Inside, its got a very 60s feel..actually, i don't know my eras. It felt like a restaurant during Frank Sinatra's time. :) Diners were all slightly on the older side.

So food ordered:
grilled sardines (appetizer) - 3 meaty sardines grilled, very nicely seasoned.
sausages (entree) - 2 sausages with a small side salad, nice flavors in the sauage.
salmon (entree) - grilled perfectly.
bottle of reisling: $40 bottle of german reisling. gotta love german reisling.
fries: good, but not TO DIE FOR. I thought it'd come perfect as is, but I still asked for ketchup, and wanted a bit more salt on it. I do have to say, the texture was perfect. Crispy outside, but potatoey soft inside.

I don't think I'd be coming back, to be honest. The food was pretty good, but was very expensive for what it was. The service was good - our waiter was friendly and nice. The host guy seating us was cheerful and smiley as well. Bring the prices down a bit, and I'd consider coming back for some seafood and fries.
author: Carol L.

description: We used to go to this restaurant when we ate fish right before a performance.  It was a pretty good place to eat and the fish was always well cooked.  I returned last night with my daughter and experienced one of the worst vegetarian meals I have ever had (to be fair, she had fish and it was well cooked).  I get really bummed when the restaurant claims to create a vegetarian option only to throw a bunch of sides on a dish and then charge the price of a well prepared and executed entree.  It was an inedible mash of things overflowing on the plate (including cold cauliflower and cole slaw).  So, go there if you want fish prepared the old fashioned way; skip it if you can't eat meat.
author: Wendy K.

description: Tends to skew a bit older in the age of the clientel, but we stopped in for some champagne and apps and were entertained by a lovely bartender. We had some delicious scallops and white beans, a yummy beet salad, and some delectable and perfectly cooked asparagus. I don't know that I would seek it out again because it was sooooo...quiet and so....much older than us. But the food is good and worth satisfying your hunger when you're in the neighborhood!
author: Nikki M.

description:
I'm going to go middle of the road here. Wife and I were looking for a place to have dinner on Christmas Eve, and walked in to HSG the night before. Open tomorrow? yes. Reservation? No problem. Fast and friendly. 

The next night, table was ready and the service was good. No snootiness to be found. The oysters were perfectly delectable, with the customary champagne mignonette for dipping. Wife's fish was great, simple and fresh as others have confirmed. My NY Steak was ok, I thought it was past medium rare though. Definitely possible that it was done in the oven. I asked the waiter and he said he thought it was indeed medium rare but immediately asked if I wanted to send it back, so well done there (no pun intended). So minus one star for the steak. 

Fries are insanely perfect -- and have been for years. Wine was well-paired. A little pricey overall, but good value. Been there for decades, and a good, solid non-trendy place for a fancy sit-down dinner. For snooty, inefficient service, see Citizen Cake.
author: jim b.

description: My parents took me here for my 25th birthday last month.  The food was really good. I got the calmairi for the appetizer and the main dish, I got the flatiron steak. The restaurant is really small inside and hard to find if you don't already know about. My parents parked in a public garage a couple blocks down.  I would like to come back here soon!
author: Brian B.

description: Overpriced, very nothing exceptional food, and a dinner room filled with antiques on Opera night.. The waiter was cool, but the food was soooo disappointing. The swordfish was dry and very bland, how do you ruin french fries, and the paella was absolutely boring. The salad was great and the oysters fair sized. But the whole room was filled with no one under the age of 40, so it's like going to visit your grandma's nursing home for dinner... this and a whole lot of drama, opera, broadway types.. gag.. I'll pass. Next time I'll save the 130 dollars and go somewhere better. .
author: Brian W.

description: Great spot for a multi-generation birthday dinner, pre or post concerts.
author: laura g.

description:
Was here during the pre-theater rush and was satisfied, not dazzled. The server was friendly even recommending a walking route to the Orpheum, but disappeared after the place filled up around 6:30. I like that they offer some seasonal produce, local fish and Niman meats, but cringed when someone in my party ordered swordfish. Had a chocolate sour cream cake for dessert that was mediocre, but my dining mate was very happy with her strawberry meringue parfait. 
I also noticed I was probably the youngest person in there (I'm 30). So that either makes this place stuffy or a classic, or a little of both.
author: Amelia J.

description:
Hubby and I found this restaurant on our way through Hayes Valley; wanting  to *clink* to our next milestone in life...
Dinner was very good as was the service...
I had a succulent Niman Ranch Pork Chop cooked perfectly; the veggies were crispy but the mashed potatoes needed to be mashier and softer...they started hardening after some minutes passed...Hubby ate the sausage with DELICIOUS FRIES...Mmmm...MMmmm....and for dessert we had...Creme Brulee.  I NEVER order Creme Brulee and it has never appealed to me BUT boy am i glad i tried it here...YUMMY!!!
Definitely will return....
author: Karen B.

description:
My office use to be near Hayes Street and I have eaten many lunches there.  Until you get to know them the food servers can seems a bit aloof.
Service has always been profesional and attentive.

I always appreciate their style of food preparation  -  get the freshest fish possible, prepare simply and don't screw it up.  Hayes Street also has some of the best french fries in the city.
author: Steve S.

description:
Over-priced food for the quality that they offer. We went for a friend's bday dinner, there were about 12 of us and our bill came out to be $55 each. We didn't order appetizer, just entree and 1 drink / person. I ordered prefix menu with ceasar salad, which was ok, grilled yellow tail, which was dry, and some apple cobbler for dessert, nothing impressive.  The portions are tiny.

The service was mediocre, the server was so scatter brain. She had to come back to some of us to re-record our orders because she forgot what they were.  And since the prefix menu wasn't written anywhere, when we asked her what it was, she didn't know and had to go check with the Chef.  When she returned, we asked her again, guess what, she FORGOT what they were, so again she had to go back and finally got it the 3rd time around!
For the same amount of $$, House of Prime Rib, or a little pricier Ruth Chris offer much much better food and service.
author: NT C.

description: Good food, great fries.  Much too expensive for the experience.
author: Stuart S.

description:
My ravishing girlfriend and I were taken to this restaurant by her adorable grandparents last night.  We cook so much and are such thrifty folks that a dinner in this cost area is a rare treat- something not to be squandered on the unawesome.  So when we heard of the plans, we Yelped the place, saw bad reviews, and tried to steer our hosts to another nearby joint (Zoya, Absinthe, etc).  

They were receptive to the idea, but after an interminable bitch of a time parking, being refused at Zoya, and recoiling at the dinner prices at Absinthe, the mood was dropping fast so we thought we'd just say fuggit and try out Hayes Street Grill after all.

As we entered and saw the not-pleasantly old-school interior, the walls covered in signed photos of marginal stars, I said a silent "Ut-oh" to myself.  As I looked over the menu, I found that the prices were nearly identical to Absinthe, but that the offerings were firmly traditional and markedly unvaried (how many ways can one serve grilled fish?).

The company was great though and we were soon seated (after a sort of uncomfortable wait, staring down wait staff that seemed determined to dodge our eye), so heck, we went with it.

We all had some form of grilled fish with fries, as none of the hoity-toitier options sounded all that good.  The grandparents each got halibut, the girl got steelhead (trout), and I got the sea bass.

We were offered no bread (where most other tables were), we were missing utensils and the general tone of the place settings were slapdash and institutional.  Bleh.

When the food came, I was surprised to find the fish cooked perfectly, and fries that were tasty and had good texture.  The problem was, the entrees cost just south of $26 each and the supplied sauces left much to be desired.  I can buy two huge tuna steaks, make some wonderful side dishes and condiments and cook the stuff precisely to my whim for about $4 per person, and hell, I can get good fish and chips at a chip shop for $6-8, sans the stuffy, airless atmosphere of HSG.  Why do people pay these prices?

I guess I came here expecting little, and would that the entrees were $10 instead of $26 I would be kinder.  I just felt terrible running up such a tremendous tab for the wonderful G-rents at such a forlorn establishment.  Next time, dinner's on us, guys! (and we'll probably make it ourselves ;)

Anyhow, the place needs a drastic renovation, a staffing refresh, and a revamped menu to come close to its burgeoning neighborhood competition, but honestly, the place was rather full, so perhaps they've found a perennial captive audience in Theatreland. :(  Say it ain't so!
author: George C.

description:
Oh, Hayes Street Grill, how I wanted to love you.  You were opened by my favorite restaurant critic back when I was an impecunious young'un.  Back then I couldn't afford you, but I was sure that you were the pinnacle of wonderfulness.  Sadly, not so.

A friend from the midwest visited recently.  I wanted to take him to a nice San Francisco restaurant, and the logistics pointed to HSG.  He has health issues--a heart valve replacement means he has to steer clear of alcohol, extra fat, and sodium.  We made our reservation for 7:30 so that we could get in as the symphony-goers were leaving.  We succeeded, mostly, but they seated us at a table for two right next to another table for two that was against the wall.  It wasn't until those folks got up to leave that we realized our table had them penned in completely.  Not only did we have to get up, but we had to pick up our belongings and move our chairs and our table.  It was weird.

My chopped salad was quite good.  My companion ordered the green salad with dressing on the side.  He got a plate of lettuce with a small cup of vinaigrette.  Now, granted, their green salad may be that simple, but somehow it was just odd to be served a plate of lettuce--especially for ten bucks.  It may be a stretch, but I would have liked to have had the waiter either provide some sort of caveat, or offer something else.  It just wasn't very happy, that plate of lettuce.

My entree was grilled halibut.  It was fine, but small.  The lemon-caper sauce is indeed delicious, but they didn't provide much of it, and the menu states that they charge for extra sauce.  My companion ordered his steak medium well, and they brought it blood rare.  (We were on a bit of a tight schedule, and he chose not to send it back.)  The French fries were fine, but they were French fries and ketchup--nothing special.

I had the Meyer lemon mousse for dessert, and that was quite good.

The service was generally good, but not spectacular.  Our waiter was fine, but there were a lot of other folks (bus folks?) coming to our table who seemed fairly clueless.

If the bill had been half what it was ($100 with tax and tip, which included one glass of wine), I would have no complaints.  For that kind of money, however, I expected more.  I don't want to say "meh," but--meh.
author: Earline A.

description:
I prefer Hayes Street Grill during lunch.  It's a nice restaurant, but I've enjoyed the lunch menu while finding the dinner menu just the same, but under par compared to so many other establishments.

Hayes Street Grill is a haven for politicians from City Hall during the day and performance-goers at night.  The lunch salads and burger are fantastic.  The fish selection is vast and you can choose your sauce.  Feel free to bring friends or co-workers here for a low-key but consistently solid place to dine.
author: E L.

description:
Wouldn't go back.   The apps were good but my Halibut was pitiful.  Watery and bland.   Forget the flat iron steak.   Not only was it overcooked but it was also bland and flavorless.   We went there with my wife's parents and they seemed to enjoy their meals.    Ordered a couple of cocktails.   They got one of the drinks wrong and when we finished our first cocktail, the waiter never asked us if we wanted another despite the fact that they were only half full.

If I were you, I'd pass.   I couldn't believe also that for a seafood restaurant in San Francisco there was no clam chowder!
author: Jon D.

description: Good food, friendly service. We were in a bit of a rush as we were trying to catch a performance post dinner - our server did his best in trying to get our dinner served quickly. Highly recommend the sole and spinach side.
author: Shweta V.

description: We had a super disappointing dinner here. First, after we perused the menu, the waiter announced one of the entrees was not available (soft shell crab). It was denoted with a black circle on the menu but we were unaware what this mark represented.  Okay then. They have 3 fish specials (salmon, sea bass, and halibut). I order the halibut but the waiter says this is no longer available. Okay, I then ask about the sea bass. Guess what, he says "sorry" they are out of that too! So I  then order the salmon, which they have. We should have left at that time. We stayed and was served a  bad dish. My wife's dish was mediocre and agreed this was a not so good experience. I've heard nice things about this place but obviously they had a problem with inventory of something. This happened at 8pm Saturday night (7/28). The manager somewhat apologized and said it was a trying day for them and will advise the owners.
author: George J.

description:
Possibly the best fries I've ever eaten.
One of the truly great lunch spots in San Francisco. 
Today's soft shell crab was one of the best lunches I've had in recent memory.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I was quite satisfied with my experience here. I came to HSG for a quick bite before a movie at the Opera Plaza and had a delicious meal. First, let me say this place is by no means fine dining. It's one of those restaurants that was pretty popular in the 70's and early 80's (according to my dad) and hasn't changed a single thing since then. Literally. My dad asked, they have the same lady making the creme brulee as when my dad last came here in 1981.

I had the grilled yellow tail with burre blanc, it was perfectly cooked and the sauce was so tasty. They really do their fish simple and right. And the fries... ooh the french fries. So crispy, so salty, and just the right size. The big surprise of the evening was our dessert! As a restaurant known for their fish and french fries, they make a damn good dessert. I had a blackberry satsuma crisp with fresh whipped cream and my dad had the creme brulee (which he fondly remembers as the best he's ever had). Oh man, those were gone in 30 seconds flat.

Another thing that hasn't changed since the 70's is the wait staff. All a little older than you might expect in a restaurant in Hayes Valley, but very friendly and knowledgeable. All in all, a great meal. I hold back a star, though, for the cheesy celeb head shots hanging on all the walls.
author: Em G.

description:
Excellent service.  They get you in and out in time for the Symphony (or other local performance).  

The food is OK, but not great.  When you order fish you get just that - a piece of fish on a plate.  Nothing else.  For these prices, they could put a veg or two to balance the meal and please the eye.

It isn't a good value, but may be your best option if you are going to a performance in the area.  While there was nothing wrong with the meal, there was nothing special about it, either.
author: Bay G.

description: Best burger and fries in Hayes Valley.  Add a couple of Gin Gibsons and that's dinner.
author: Bali D.

description: Ya know, when the side dishes taste great, you know your in for a great meal!!  The seafood was fresh and oh so tasty!!  Our waitress recommended the perfect wine to go with our various choices and the service was just great!!
author: Paul L.

description:
We dropped in (without a reservation) before the Symphony.  We were seated with only a minimal delay (and were offered a spot at the bar to eat if we preferred - we didn't) The staff was courteous, friendly, professional, prompt, and helpful.  I believe the chef was Rhea O'Neal (from the menu).

We had drinks to start (while we waited) - my companion wasn't impressed with the rum and coke  but I thought the Kir was well made - even with using a very dry Chardonnay. After we sat down and had ordered bread and butter were served with a carafe of water and glasses prior to the first course.  I had a Cesar Salad (one of the best I've enjoyed in years) and he had the Warm Goat Cheese Salad - which looked delicious.   For our entree I had the Sliced Niman Bavette Steak (done medium rare) with Salsa Fresco, Arugula, and French Fries.  The steak was done perfectly and the dressing on the Arugula with the Salsa Fresco was amazing. It provided a wonderful burst of flavor for the dish. The fries came in a separate tall bowl - freshly made.  I did ask for Dijon mustard - which may have been made by the chef.  The fries do not need it I'm just partial to Dijon mustard.  He had the Bodega Bay Petrale Sole with King Trumpet Mushrooms, Thyme and Fingerling Potatoes.  The Sole was covered with panko crumbs, which meant I couldn't try it - but it smelled wonderful.  He thought it was good but slightly bland.  I skipped dessert (trying to finish my fries!) but he had a blackberry shortcake with freshly make whipped cream.  He said it was good.  We skipped the after dinner coffee that was offered as neither of us drink it.  

The decor is light and airy, and the lighting is comfortably bright - not glaring. With the large windows at the front is makes for a pleasant atmosphere and an intimate feel.   They have photos and mirrors on the wall along with coat-hooks.  The tables seat 2 to 4 patrons and are set somewhat closely together.  I commend the staff for navigating the rooms successfully!  

Considering the time we got there, and the fact that the symphony crowd was packing the place, the act that we were seated, dined, and done before the performance was great.  

I'd gladly stop in again when I'm in the city - looking forward to trying their lunch menu.
author: Kiri L.

description:
We may have seated our butts down on the WRONG night, but our dinner consisted of small rubbery portions, too much starch, and half-baked desserts from hell! I was ready to play ping-pong with my scallops. The raspberry cobbler was cold on one side, warm on the other, and watery on the bottom. This is just duh-sgusting!!

Being busy is no excuse. We were here on a weekday night, and the grill was not busy at all. This is one of the many pre-performance restaurants around civic center, and I'm quite surprised that they weren't more attentive to quality, especially toward us music snobs.

I was just about to slap my BOYCOTT stamp on this one, but I'll let someone drag me in here one more time. You will, however, have to DRAG me in.
author: Daniel C.

description: I'm really surprised to see any negative reviews, to me this is a classic SF experience. Yes the place is old school, but I just ate there last night for the first time and loved it, one of the best meals I'd had in ages. Definitely not cheap but no more expensive than (the way overrated and super noisy) Absinthe! I like it better than Jardinere too. We had requested a window seat via opentable, and there indeed was the perfect window table waiting for us, with the window slightly opened to let in a fresh breeze on a warm evening. Had an amazing martini and a fresh, delicious grilled carrot salad w/ toasted almonds to start, both divine. Main course: fresh, melt in your mouth, perfectly grilled halibut with a spectacular white wine/butter sauce and their famous French fries. Nothing innovative really but just so so delicious. For dessert a decadent chocolate torte with fresh berries and whipped cream. Everything was just perfect and the service was so friendly and efficient. Obviously the place gets super busy on big theatre/symphony nights so you have to make a reservation in plenty of time, but I just loved this place and will definitely go back for another special occasion.
author: Philip M.

description: This looks like an old school place that is a stalwart in the neighborhood for years. i've never really looked at the menu but met a friend in the neighborhood and wanted to try it. What was it they say? never take a friend to a place you've never been before. True. We got there and stood at the line while the maitre d' doted on her guest list for several minutes. heck out $19 for brussel spouts/mushrooms over white rice for lunch. Add another $4 for tips. Gulp. Overpriced and not recommended, especially for vegetarians. Go to the Grove, Ler Ros, the kabob place do  wn the street or even Patxi instead.
author: Rrr X.

description: This place is Hayes Valley is very average and clearly serves the pre-theatre crowd.  Duh - take a look at the pics on the wall.  We went for lunch recently.  The waiter recommended anything fish.  The preparations - basically grilled with a choice of sauce - didn't really appeal to me.  However, since fish was supposed to be a specialty, I ordered the grilled albacore salad.  Very unremarkable and hardly filling.  All that for $19.  Service was fine, but nothing special.  Wouldn't go back - even before a show.
author: Ryan W.

description: Try another restaurant.  Mediocre quality of food.  Only redeeming feature was food servers who really tried.  But they don't purchase or prepare the food.  Should have known when the place was fairly empty on a Friday evening.
author: George F.

description:
We just got back from eating at the Haye's Street Grill and we give it a 4 stars.  From the moment we walked into the restaurant, we felt welcomed. They have a very friendly wait staff. The fish was fantastic, cocktails generous. We had the banana tart dessert...very yummy!
I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: babs m.

description: The fries are amazing and the butter caper sauce is lovely. I liked the atmosphere and the service was great.  The food here is all fresh. Fresh veggies fresh fish. The fried calamari was divine.  Maybe a little pricey if you're on a budget.
author: Gina A.

description:
Amazing.

Had a wedding party dinner with about a dozen people. These types of gatherings really tend to show any weaknesses in the kitchen or service. Everything was wonderful. I tried the tomato salad, sole and creme brulee and all of it was top notch. The tomato salad was so amazing, I am going again just for that dish.

The service was warm, friendly and attentive.
author: Storm W.

description:
So a BFF wanted to go here for her 30th, mostly because it was convenient and none of us had been there before.  It's one of those places you keep meaning to go, you walk by, nothing interesting, but you have heard it's really good.

Don't believe it.

Decor is early 80's oak, with photos of old symphony stars.  If it has been updated, they must have purchased a lot of muted pastel print.  There is a decorator somewhere off-loading 80's chic.......

Sorry, I digress....but the food was not that much better.  We had, between 5 of us:

1 summer squash soup.  Pretty good, but also pretty easy. I could have made this.   8 bucks.

1 Caesar Salad, split into 2.  Standard. Store bought croutons. 10 bucks

2 New York Strips.  They were very good, but tasted like grill and nothing else.  Came with butter, and more butter. 24 bucks each!!

1 Crab Cakes (on the menu BTW), good, but can you spell BUTTER. 20 bucks !

1 Salmon, this was mine, cooked perfectly, but not much more....but MORE BUTTER.  23 bucks!

1 Pork Chop, friends said it was pretty good.  This at least came with potatoes and green beans.  The green beans rocked.  23 bucks.

1 Chalk Hill Chardonnay for 50 bucks....not money well spent.

ALL the meals come with French Fries.  WTF? And no AIOLI. We had to ask for ketchup.

The waiter was very good at his job, and had obviously been doing it for a very very very long time.  No chit chat, although my DH thought he was a jerk.  I thought he was just chill.  

So, all in all the food was ok, service ok, atmosphere ok if 80's, but for 50 dollars each we could have gone to so many other great places.
author: David S.

description:
E took me here on a Saturday night after we went to see The SF Symphony accompany a showing of The Wizard of Oz (simply awesome).  Next door to this restaurant is a cute little home decor store.  After sitting down, E went to check it out and came back with a couple of presents for me.  So nice...

Anyway, this place has been around for 20+ years so I was told.  I figured that any place that has been around for that long can't be bad.  Luckily, we weren't disappointed.

We started with the half dungeness crab which was succulent and sweet.  Absolutely yummy.

For dinner, I had the Japanese miso-marinated Alaskan black cod.  It was served with Japanese pickles, small cabbage salad and some rice.  The Alaskan black cod was delicious - flaky and flavorful.  The pickles and cabbage salad was okay.

Service was really great.  On the menu, the restaurant had recommended a Mexican Gulf Sierra and when we asked the waiter about it, he said to skip it.  How cool is that!  We ended up sitting there and talking for three hours.  No one came and bothered us at all.

The interior was nothing fancy but the food and service more than made up for it.
author: Yuan W.

description:
In another city this place would probably be considered fantastic, however being located in San Francisco it does not particularly stand out. I was actually disappointed in almost everything.

I will say it does have a very nice, clean, fun atmosphere but the crowd is defiantly  the over 40 crowd.

We ordered a few appetizers the fish and chips and the cracked dungeness crab. The fish and chips were so-so. The fish breading just wasn't flavourful at all. The fish itself was just ok. I will say the chips were actually the best food of the outing. 

I had the San Diego Sword Fish as my entree. It was too thin and cold but tasted ok. I have had a lot better even at lesser places. And for $25 way overpriced. 

My partner ordered a skirt steak (the only steak on the menu). The portion size was ok but again the taste was just lacking. I will say that they knew what "rare" means.

I had a crème brûlée for dessert which the staff toted was the best in the city. I will say that it probably is the best portion size for crème brûlée in the city but the taste was just ok. The caramelized top tasted of butane to such an extent I was almost ill. Not the best in the city. Try Ruth Chris's if you want the best in the city.

I do want to say that our waitress was exceptional. 

I really can't recommend this place but I can see how some might like it, so give it try but go in with low exceptions to be safe.
author: Gaelic F.

description: very casual and sitting-in-grandmas-living-room feeling with quick, polite service. the menu's pretty limited and the dishes are really simple, but there's a good selection of fish and it's cooked perfectly with good texture and your choice of a sauce for flavoring. i dunno if i'd ever make a special trip back here, but it's definitely a good spot for a quick dinner before the symphony.
author: Stephanie C.

description: My wife and I have eaten here several times, usually when we are going to a show nearby. The food is very good, but the menu kind of limited. The prices are high, as is the cost for parking in the city garages. But HSG is convenient and makes for a nice quick meal before the show.
author: Jim T.

description: A San Francisco classic. Fish dishes are delicately prepared and grilled up fresh with seasonal side dishes like grilled asparagus. They have a prix fix menu which is reasonable at around 30 bucks. If you're in the Hayes Valley 'hood this is a great place to bring out of town guests, family, and date(s). I recommend bringing them all on separate occasions.
author: joolia f.

description:
Came here with a friend on her mother's recommendation and had a really pleasant evening.

The feel of the place is a little more formal than I was expecting from the name and location, but it worked well.  The menu is clear and avoids weird combos and ingredients you've never heard of; always a bonus.  As other people have noted the selection of grilled fish with a selection of sauces is a nice touch.  Also, as it's a daily menu there's no obligatory reeling off of a bunch of specials you have to try and remember while reviewing the printed version.

We both had calamari to start (very good), then I had their Paella and my dining companion went for the Petrale Sole, which she thoroughly enjoyed.  The Paella was an interesting twist on those I'm used to in Spain - at first I couldn't see the rice, as the dish arrived piled high with shellfish - rather than cooking in with the rice this version seems to be assembled with seafood on a rice base, and it worked very well, all the fish was very tasty and the rice had picked up the flavours without being swamped in them.  The definite zing of the chorizo helped too.

Service was good - attentive without being intrusive, and the bottle of Gavi we had was a definite winner and a bargain at $30.
author: Jon M.

description:
Had dinner the evening of Dec 9, 2010.  Remembered it fondly from a few years ago.  It was the most unpleasant dining experience I have had in a very long time.  The waiter was not helpful and when I asked for a taste of one of their "by the glass" wines and did not like it, the service part was over.  The sausage he spoke highly of was soggy and tasteless.  When I told him I was not happy with my meal and why, he shrugged and left.  He igored us from that point on.

Net/net, poor service, bad food, obscene by the bottle wine prices, low quality by the glass (and still pricey) wine prices.  There are other options in that area.  Find them.  This place is over, just riding out the proximity to the arts.
author: Steven W.

description: They charge the prices of a much, much better restaurant.  Food was mediocre, at best.  Fish was flavorless and was prepared and presented with the flare of a low-end cafeteria.  Service was very good, which is why I'm giving it 2 stars instead of 1.
author: Adam C.

description: Overall not too bad. Place is definitely old school on the inside, like super old school. I ordered the sole which was nicely cooked and had good flavor. The calamari appetizer was drizzled with some sort of aiolli which made it a little heavy. Service was attentive and friendly.  Creme brûlée was pretty damn good. Definitely up there with the best I've had. Just for the record that girl who made the comment below with the group of coworkers who wanted 9 seperate checks is wrong - just divide the check by 9 and move on.
author: David H.

description:
I have been coming here for years. But sadly, my last trip was a disappointment. The place felt worn and out of place. The pictures on the walls of long ago performers just made it more dated.

The service was pretty terrible as our waiter only came by to drop off the menu, take our order, drop off our food and leave or check. My dinner companions are nice and gave Mr. Goatee the standard 20% tip and I wanted to just leave 10-15%.

The food was totally mediocre. What the hell happened to this place. I can't be the only one feeling this way, the place was more than half empty (they didnt' even open the other room) and we were walk-ins.
author: Tracy Y.

description: Fresh, quality food, light and airy atmosphere, pleasant easy service, a mixed-age crowd- this place is what SF used to be like before all the wannbe-Manhattanites moved here.  The grilled calamari salad and an amazingly delicious grapefruit/ champagne sorbet are my favorites.  The wines and the fresh grilled fish are also always great.
author: Deb A.

description: we ordered the calamari appetizer and 7x7 big eats fries to split and i am sorry to report the calamari was bad, sauteed with a mayonnaise textured sauce we only finished it to be polite. The fries were good but while eating them we tried to figure out why they made the list since they were pretty average good fries. well the bartender broke it down, they are double fried in California rice oil which apparently is healthier and they use a different potato which i forget its name :( but i did like the subtle taste of whatever potato they used.
author: Barbara C.

description: Really bad form Hayes St.! On the website and the outgoing reservation message it says you are open on Monday, so imagine my surprise when I arranged to meet some out of town guests for a birthday party there, only to see that you are indeed closed on Monday!  Why would you advertise on your website, have it on your outgoing message and on Open Table that you are! My guests, who are not Spring chickens were forced to walk around to other restaurants, all of which were closed, but at least they said so on the door! Really bad form ......33 years in the business. Neh
author: ava k.

description: When a restaurant offers you the choice of six different sauces for your choice of fish or chicken, you know it's somewhere along the lines of a fancy Olive Garden. There was something jaded about the way they just phoned in the realizations of what looks like a good menu. Unfortunately the food wasn't very good, especially in light of the fact they put themselves in a rather high price point. They could change the way they cook or just drop the prices by 30%.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Wish I could give half-stars.  This isn't French Laundry, and as such can't get that kind of rating, but it's darn good French Bistro-type fare, specializing in seafood.  The owners very much know what they are doing.  
It's sort of sad that this kind of food is seen (and priced) as so upscale here, whereas it's really just the way food should be.  If you are going to an event at Davies or the Opera House, come early and sit at the counter for a casual yet delicious eating experience. 
 Many years ago, I sat at a table in the main dining room a few feet away from Catherine Deneuve, and was so impressed with my fellow SF'cans and their ability to let a beautiful celebrity enjoy her meal in peace.  It's part of the civilized atmosphere of this place.
Last time I went, a few weeks back, though, I saw a lot of people who had more money than knowledge about food, and were throwing their weight around about a bunch of trivial stuff.  I could tell they weren't Yelpers, though, just by their demeanor - we would never do that, right?  RIGHT?!?
author: Kimberly V.

description:
nothing can go wrong with a piece of grilled fish, that's what my two other diners got at our last visit: ono and yellow tail fish. i had a bite of them and it was perfect. as a risk-taker i ordered soft-shell crab. i like crab in general and i'm always intrigued by crabs in different preparations, my two crabs tasted good, were well-prepared in light batter and watercress sauce but be warned that there's more to put under your teeth than to get out of it...(a bit of crab juice at most).
i was happy anyway with the good companionship, the wonderful concert after the meal and very decent wines (a white Chinon, i've never heard of it before except for the red one).
to fill up my hungry stomach i did finish the very yummy french fries while feeling very guilty...
forgot about appetizers: calamari, soup and salad all decent and tasty.
author: Thuy G.

description: It's spare in its presentation of fish, without alot of add-ons from a culinary perspective.  I like that.  The ingredients are fresh as can be, and it's simple and unadorned, but delicious.   Great creme brulee to boot!  Perfect for the holiday work lunch (which is what we did today).  Extremely civilized.
author: Laurel B.

description: I stopped by here on our way back to the suburbs of SF.  He's known and has come to this place many times in the past, as he says.  I was pretty pleased with the service and the food.  I had the oysters it was quite tasty as it is the first ever I've had there were lightly fried and NOT dry inside. mmMmm....yummy!  I wanted to change the coleslaw off my plate for a regular green salad but the waiter said it was not allowed (booo!)-for the prices it should be accommodated!  But, I did actually end up liking the coleslaw.  It also came with french fries which were soooo soooo soooo good, 2nd pick after In-n-Out (lol).  I picked off my friends plate of filet of sole and it was perfectly tasting, seasoned perfectly and everything.  Can't wait to go back here again!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description: Had steak and fries after the opera and it was excellent. Classic dishes executed carefully. Service was just right and yes, they offered us ketchup right away. Why do some people have a complex about ketchup?
author: KimchiKraut K.

description: How could I have missed this place all these years? Oh, yeah - I don't eat fish...Anyway....I dine with people who do, so off to Hayes Street Grill we went. It was great. Service was formal and good. I would have to try very hard to imagine that any of the staff have sarcastic senses of humor. They take their restauranting very seriously. I had the Chinese Chicken Salad, which was excellent. Fries on the side. Also excellent. My dining companions had the scallop salad and the sole. One dining companion said that the scallop salad was the best salad she has ever had. With emphasis. My other dining companion said that she's been saying that a lot lately about a lot of things, so I'm not sure what to make of it.  Try it and decide for yourself.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I would give this place a 3.8, so I rounded up. My swordfish was well prepared and I like the option of picking between 5 or 6 sauces to go with your fish (the waiter made excellent suggestions if you're debating between two as I was). Also, the sauce comes on the side, so your fish isn't doused in it, so you can put as much or as little as you want. The desserts were also good- my creme brulee was delicious and my friend's devil food cake was chocolately goodness.
author: Noelle Q.

description: Who knew the best seafood in San Francisco could be found in Hayes Valley? Judging by the other reviews of folks who have given this bistro bad marks, one would think they were expecting Long John Silver's or something. Every single dish I've eaten here has been epic, even simple sand dabs lightly pan friend in nothing but butter and garlic somehow manage to taste better than anywhere else. I never experienced any of the attitude others write about, but I also can't say I've ever been here for dinner (it's a lunch stop for me on my way to the South Bay). I would be hard pressed to reccomend a better sea food establishment in the city proper.
author: Tal K.

description: We being a business group of friends out for lunch today 04/24/2012. The staff was a bit disrespectful and slow at our table. The last time I checked my money was the same as others around us but you would not be able to tell by the way we were treated. The bus boy was great the waiter and manager must of thought we were homeless. When we finished paying our bill we walked to the door said thank you to three people and got no response back. RUDE!!!
author: Tom W.

description: This place is honestly hit or miss for me. I don't like the fries as much as some people. They kind of remind of In n Out fries which aren't my fave. I do like the option of choosing your fish and sauce though. I do enjoy the old school feel of the restaurant which makes me feel almost like an adult every time I go there. Definitely a spot to hit up before or after the opera or ballet or symphony as the restaurant is very experienced with handling the arts crowd and getting you to your show on time.
author: Cathy T.

description: This place was very ordinary. It's a great place if you're looking for simple fish dish, but there is absolutely nothing special about this place. I enjoyed my food... defintely get the caper sauce. I orderd another one of their sauces to go with my fish but they brought me out the caper one too (I don't remember what else was in the sauce, probably something with lemon). It is very conveinient if you are going to the symphony. I don't know if it had to do with the night we were there, but it seemed to have a much older crowd, I was one of very few people without white hair. Nice waiters, good service, clean.
author: Jen S.

description: I tried the Petrale Sole ($25), which was fantastic.  Perfectly cooked.  Very nicely complemented with mushrooms and fingerling potatoes.  Also tried the basic salad with sherry shallot dressing, which was nice but strangely came with nothing but mixed greens.  The salad portion was large and easily fed 2.  The table bread is also better than most restaurants.
author: David L.

description: REALLY pleasantly surprised.  Thought this was just a place for oldsters to go before a night at the opera or Davies Hall, and it is, but the food and service are fantastic.  And it's a hoot (oh no, I'm using their oldster lingo!!) to look at all the signed photos of celebs on the walls.  I couldnt recognize any of them except for Lily Tomlin when she was, like, 30 years old.  If you're not looking for the ambiance of Absinthe, give this place a try when in Hayes Valley.
author: brewgirl b.

description: I've been lucky and missed theater nights here, but its worth a trip to Hayes block (I mean Valley) to try this one out.  Nothing over the top super amazing, but all around very good, great service, comfortable atmosphere with a great mix of bright and shadow, white linen and dark wood.  The bar is an unexpectedly cozy place for a snack and a glass of wine.
author: J P.

description: This place is overpriced, the food is sub par and the service is terrible.  My fish was hardly warm part of it was crispy cold and the shallot butter had little evidence or flavor of shallots.  I can't believe restaurants such as this remain in buisness when they have nothing to offer their customers.
author: big c.

description: We've had dinner there many times over the past 5 years and while the price is the same, the food has gone down hill significantly.  Had the Niman steak - a tough piece of meat sliced on top of cold, uncooked spinach straight from the grocery store + great french fries = $30.  My husband had sea bass - dry, served with a sauce too hot to eat & french fries = $28. Cesar salad was chopped pale green romaine, powdered parmesan cheese and few croutans = $11.  Final insult, the restaurant filled with smoke from the kitchen that irritated our eyes and will require our clothes to go to the dry cleaners.  Will be a long cold day before we go back.
author: Eleanor C.

description: Great seafood! I had the Yellow tail jack !!! this is a fish for a more sophisticated palate, looks like people that have reviewed this dish are not quite informed about this type of fish, sound a bit Ignorant. I then had beet salad with blue cheese, radish, walnuts. Service amazing and the Hostess Andree always happy to see use again.
author: Ray E.

description: I must admit I'm very surprised by the lukewarm reviews of HSG. I've come here for years...it's our pre-opera staple. It seems to get heat for being a classic fish grill where the focus is on the quality of the fish. That's why they keep their sauces on the side (beurre blanc and lemon-caper butter are my favs). Their salads are exceptional as well...great ingredients and perfectly dressed and seasoned. Their fries are excellent albeit not as good as when we first came here about a decade ago. Last night, I had scallops on a base of lemon butter, shallots, corn, and minced bell pepper. It might have been the best sauce I've ever tasted.
author: Bill R.

description: I expected better (However in hindsight I should have considered the source).  After hearing about how good this place was, I was shocked to enter a world that old people going to the symphony might enjoy.  It's San Francisco so you can expect seafood, however that's about all you can expect.  Nothing special was on the menu and nothing special came out from the kitchen. The service was great but as the other reviews have said, this place is old and it shows.
author: David W.

description: I cannot review the food because both times i called to make a reservation, I was cut off mid-sentence and hung up on by the person taking the call.  It must be nice to be so successful that they can be that rude to people who call for reservations.  I am reluctant to actually go there since I am not willing to be treated that way as a diner either.  There are plenty of good restaurants in SF that treat customers with courtesy and appreciate their business.
author: Janet G.
