description: There must be something about Hayes Valley that produces superior French fries, because the folks at this place can sure give Absinthe a run for their money.  I take my mother here every time she is in town (by request).  She likes the pre-theatre prix fixe.  I prefer to order off the menu, which changes daily.  Some of my favorites have been the Farmer's Market chopped salad (in fact, thinking about it is making me drool), petrale sole, and the pork chop.  Friends and I like to dip the fries in buerre blanc (way too decadent for words) or the house-made tartar sauce.
author: darla s.

description: The food was very good and the service was excellent.  A little pricey but not unexpectedly so, considering the area and the type of classy restaurant that it is.  It's the perfect compliment to a special evening out for the Symphony.
author: Duane S.

description: Seafood is the star here at this often bustling eatery on Hayes. On theatre and opera nights, the two dining rooms are packed, and the bar is filled with diners, not drinkers. Everything is straightforward here: fresh fish, simply prepared, white tablecloths, efficient waiters. I liked my scallops with succotash. My date loved her crab cakes with fries. I prefer the thin cut fries from Absinthe, but for thicker fries, Hayes Street Grill beats Fritz without question.
author: Timothy O.

description: I went back to Hayes Valley Grill with a friend because in my mind I had remembered the prices being reasonable - but let me tell you, my memory definitely failed me. $30 bux for literally a piece of grilled fish and (quite tasty) fries. The fish is not exceptional and while it's better than what I could make at home, it's not *that* much better. I wouldn't come back here again because it's just not worth it, and there are better food options nearby. It definitely caters to the theater crowd (read: older).
author: Kathy L.

description: Terrible food. My sliced steak was served lukewarm and undercooked. While I might understand that, given the restaurant's supposed strength being seafood, my husband's swordfish was also served at room temperature and was essentially a chunk of uninspired, lukewarm fish with nothing else going on. The fries and soda were delicious, but you could get that at a fast food place for much less money. I would NEVER go here again or recommend it.
author: Anoushka S.

description: This review is JUST for the Ferry Bldg Farmer's Market vendor stall outside... I love their "Scrambled farm eggs, Hobbs bacon, local tomatoes in season on Acme baguettes "  its such a wholesome breakfast ... If I get in late I go for the Pan-fried Hama Hama oyster po'boys ... Need I say more :-)
author: Arissa C.

description: Only speaking about their stall at the Saturday Ferry Building farmer's market, but just go there and get their grilled salmon BLT.  Can you beat it?  Nope.  (Ok, actually, picky yelpers may say the bread could be thicker, but c'mon, it's tas-ty.)
author: Melanie C.

description:
I know that this restaurant can sometimes miss the mark, they have on my last visit before this one serving a luke warm undergrilled halibut but on Saturday night they hit on all cyliners.
Yes it was a celebration moment and we were already having a great time when we got there.  But the restaurant took our mood and brought it up even higher.
On food, I believe that you should stick to grilled fish here, the combination of well selected seafood, choice of sauce and consistently great crisp fries are always a winner, even if they look at you a bit odd when you ask for ketchup.
What this restauarant brings is a professional attitude.  Go and enjoy the after opera crowd, the table next to us was having desserts and martinis...
We, 6 of us, had a great time, fueled by a egalitarian wine list that lets you drink at 30 or 200 dollars, your choice.  
Always a classic be happy Hayes Street is part of the SF restaurant scene after all of these years.
author: Jules K.

description: I was excited about  first visit after a while. Unfortunately, we were a bit disappointed. the food was ok, but not exciting. Our fish dishes could have been flavored and improved and the Cauliflower was soggy and not well flavored, The waiters were good, but rushed and didn't seem to have enough time to check on how the meal was.Maybe this was because we arrived after the opera crush was over on a Saturday and the kitchen and staff were tired.
author: George w.

description: I have heard that French service sucks, but I have to say the worst service in San Francisco I have received was at Hayes Street Grill. The wait staff made sarcastic remarks about how we walked in just five minutes before the kitchen was due to close and were rude to a friend who got in their way while returning from the bathroom.  Needless to say, we walked out without ordering.
author: Sameer S.

description: Got the oysters, boudin blanc sausage, and devils food cake. All was quite good, especially the cake- very moist and flavorful. Service was good, atmosphere on the softer side as its normally is here.
author: Ben G.

description:
Excellent grilled fish.  Good wine list.  Very professional service.  They
will get you out in plenty of time for the opera, ballet, or symphony. Tables
a little too close together.
author: Morton D. P.

description:
First, I want to tell you.. I'm obsessed with yelp. After watching me start this review my boyfriend told me "you need help with your yelp" However, I will continue to review this place because I feel it is worthy of a yelp review and it's rare when I get to go to a fancy restaurant for dinner. 

I saw this place on Best of the Bay. It's right down the street from my house, but I've never been able to afford it. When my parents came into town this weekend, I thought this place would be the perfect setting for a double date with the 'rents. It's an older, more sophisticated crowd. I knew this when I called in two weeks earlier to make the reservations and they told me that they were booked until after 7pm.  In case you didn't already know, old people eat early. Needless to say, we didn't make it in time for the early bird special. For youth, this is considered "happy hour". Anyhow, we got there at 7:30 and the place was empty. There were several pictures on the wall that resembled the opera singers from the Opera house close by. We were seated and immediately waited on. 
For an appetizer, we ordered oysters, and soft shell crab. It was my first time eating both of these delicacies and I enjoyed them very much. Then I shared the farmers market salad with my bf. For the main course, I reveled in the scallops on a bed of squash and sweet corn. 
Since I was a child, I've always hated fish, oysters, and crab.  As we discussed my most embarrassing childhood memories, I remembered how my parents couldn't pay me to eat scallops.  Now that I'm older, more mature, and my parents were actually paying for the meal, I decided to give it a try and It was unforgettable! 

All in all this place was a hit amongst the fam and the bf. Since I rarely get the opportunity to communicate with my family, it was the perfect atmosphere and  the service was wonderful. We all enjoyed our meals and the fact that it was quiet enough to hear each other talk.  Happy birthday Daddy! Thanks for coming to visit!
author: Lucy G.

description: I have been for lunch about a dozen times and dinner thrice. I work nearby. This place never lets you down. They get their fish delivered 6 days a week. Always the freshest! Their Mexican Mahi Mahi is my favorite- try it with the peanut sauce. Their house made sausage melts in your mouth. Steaks are incredible. The fries! OH THE FRIES!! Creme Brulee is perfect. Nice choice of wines, plenty of whiskey. Service is always impeccable.
author: Eddie L.

description: I ate here with some friends before going to hear Anthony Bourdain taping City Arts & Lectures at the Herbst (I was the one who asked him about the vegan potluck in Berkeley...).  Dinner was pretty good, but not outstanding.  I had been eating sushi about two hours before so I wasn't up for a big piece of fish....had the sardine starter which was nice enough, stood up well with a peppery Zin (kudos to HSG for offering some of their nicer wines by the glass).  But then the New York Steak was just sort of grey and unexciting, like it had been cooked in the oven then just tossed on the grill for a second to put some lines on the surface.  The grapefruit-campari ice for dessert was outstanding, though, a hint of a hot summer day.
author: Derick F.

description: "I regret that I am so opinionated that I am rating HSG such an average score. BUT! There is, of course, a reason. Okay, a couple. First let me say that the food is wonderful, expensive and pleasing. Second, it is a restaurant catering to the pre-symphony/opera crowd. Nope, no hipsters here. You'd best be elegant or on good behavior when you arrive or you will be asked about your business there. Snootitude overrides the kitchen."
author: Tracy E.

description: Went here for a birthday dinner (oh, did I mention it was MINE?), and I was pretty disappointed.  Not a single person who worked there was that nice (some I would say went as far as having extreme attitude), and the food was just iffy.  I really wanted to love this place (hence why I booked it for an occasion!), but needless to say, it disappointed the majority of our table.
author: Jenn K.

description: Lunch left me unimpressed.  The hamburger was so tasteless, I nearly emptied the pot of mustard trying to salvage the patty.  The chicken salad lacked appeal, too: just iceberg lettuce and shredded bits of boiled chicken.  Well...atleast the service was good.
author: M A N I K.

description: This place is a consistently satisfying bistro.  Casual, comfortable, great for a weekend bite or a business lunch.  My favorite is the grass-fed burger--real beef taste but a clean finish. Service was excellent.  A great standby when you need a quick, high-quality bite.
author: tim p.

description: Fresh Crab Sandwiches. Please do yourself a favor - get your lazy ass out of bed early on a Sat morning and head on over to their stall at the Farmers Market. Every bite made me feel warm and fuzzy and oh so glad to be in San Francisco. Its $11 dollars a sandwich but they make it exactly the way I would (except I would add pepper and hot sauce as well).  Thanks for getting my Saturday off to an awesome start!
author: Abhi S.

description:
ate here before going to the opera last night.  the food is good, well prepared, and not all that fancy.  this is a seafood restaurant, yet to me what stands out most about this place is their french fries.  usually you don't pay these kind of prices to get good fries, but this is what they do well.  my fiancee and i have eaten here a few times now, and we've never been disappointed, but never particularly impressed either. 

 the service was snappy, although somewhat impersonal.  a pet peeve: when i shell out for a fancy meal and order a bottle of wine, i don't think my hands should ever need to touch the bottle.  our waiter refilled our glasses once, but then left us to pour out the rest ourselves.  it's really a small detail, but one that i'm always aware of when i order wine.
author: Jeff W.

description: Service was awesome the first time,,,even coming in my pajamas!  They let me order crab cakes and fries that were not even mentioned on the menu...one of the best dining experiences I had in San Francisco.  BUT THEN the second and last few times I have been here the service has kind of sucked!  They looked at me like I was crazy every time i asked if they had the crab cakes and last time I think they just ignore the question not even acknowledging an answer!  IT still has been decent food, but has not even compared to my first visit here!
author: ELIZABETH W.

description:
I had to weigh in on this restaurant after reading some of the so-so reviews recently. A group of 7 dined there recently- ages  ranging from 20-83, before a show at the Herbst.  I am an avid locavore/gourmet home cook, and foodie who reads many food blogs, food sections of many newspapers, and dines out regularly at a variety of places (including all the latest, hip places in the Mission, incluidng the Folsom Street Food Fair, the Chocolate Salon, etc.)  I found many of the reviews not to reflect our experience. Every single dish that we ate (appetizers, main courses, salads, soups, desserts, etc.) was stellar.
I believe restaurant-goers in the Bay Area occasionally become a little jaded with hip decor, cutting-edge food (many of those places go out of business in a fraction of the time Hayes St. has been in business), mixologists, etc.  The food and service at Hayes Street Grill was impeccable. In a nutshell, fresh, local, simply prepared delicious, seasonal food. That is what they have been doing for all these years, and it must be one of theh main reasons they are still in business.
And, no, I am not related in any way to anyone connected with the restaurant!
author: J Z.

description: Dreadful.  Trading on it's reputation, this tired horse needs to be put out to pasture.  The petrale was covered in artichokes that completely robbed it of any flavor, the "paella" would have been marginally passable if it were more accurately described as a bouillabaise and the "green salad" was nothing more than a mound of bib lettuce dressed with olive oil and a waive of some nondescript vinegar.  In a party of six there were no - zero - high points.  Considering that this joint has never been inexpensive and considering that there are so many more options, I see no reason to return.  In fact, I said to my wife as we left, "Now I remember why we haven't been back in 25 years.
author: robert l.

description: Great choice for opera nights, but like everyone says, they're very busy, so come early.  Just a nice way to start off a nice evening of the arts.
author: Tricia S.

description:
Very nervy, charging $25 for a small piece of tasteless fish. Doesn't matter how fresh it is, if it only tastes of "grill", we might as well have let cavemen cook it. We went for the first time last week. The salads were ok, an uninspired chopped salad and grilled calamari and cranberry beans. The beans were beautifully prepared, but the calamari was wet and mushy. Not exceptionally grilled like Chez Nous and SPQR.

The tuna and mahi mahi came out. My tuna had been grilled long ago and was lukewarm. My fries were cold/lukewarm. My husband's mahi mahi was cooked rare, although they didn't ok that with him. He ordered the peanut sauce which was really bad and sweet. 

I would have rather had a balanced looking plate with fish, perhaps some cooked greens and a hint of a starch, but the restaurant seems bent on living off its "fresh" reputation with nothing more. Service, however, was fine, though the waiter didn't seem to notice my husband had barely touched his mahi mahi.

I attended a lunch there with Marion Nestle and was impressed. This dinner made me never want to go back. The kicker was that that evening I attended a talk on Michael Pollen (Omnivore's Dilemna) and   Patricia Unterman was the interviewer. It was hard to hear them speaking glowingly on what good food is.
author: louise f.

description: Went here for lunch on a friday. Definitely has that old rich lady luncheon vibe, but i was most interested in the (somewhat) organic menu. Anyhow, i had what was billed as a grapefruit avocado salad on a bed of greens with half a dungeness crab. What that actually was: a few romaine hearts with some grapefruit and avocado pieces on a plate, and half a crab in a bowl. it was alright but romaine does NOT equal mixed greens. I was disappointed. The boyfriend had his usual cow burger (nieman ranch yay) with fries and he said it was also alright. so 3 stars. good (but humorless) service.
author: Mary V.

description: Okay so I only go to their tent every Saturday at the SF Ferry Bldg Farmer's Market, but their crab cakes sanwiches and bacon and egg on baguette sandwiches are awesome.  Hell....last Saturday my greedy ass had 2!
author: Greg R.

description: I've been meaning to write a review about the Hayes Street Grill tent at the Ferry Building, on Saturdays, for quite some time. I've been ordering the bacon and eggs on the baguette for a couple of years now and it's pretty fricking good. Although, this weekend, I finally broke the tradition and tried something different this time around: the oyster po' boy. Can somebody say, "yum!?" The mushroom and eggs are pretty tasty too.
author: Chris G.

description: This was my first trip to Hayes Street Grill but it certainly won't be my last.  The atmosphere, service and food were top of the line.  Just a wonderful evening.
author: Rabbit B.

description: Long ago I used to favor this restaurant and last night returned after many years --the food was good, the service attentive but we were seated in outer Mongolia. A large room off of the main dining room, completely frigid, and with only one other table of diners. I should have requested that we be moved but I thought that even with our reservation we might be kept waiting for a different table. The maitre'd appeared to be oblivious and actually rather amused when upon leaving I complained to him about the very substantial draft at our table. All in all a miserable experience. Margaret Bahan
author: margaret b.

description: I'm confused at how this restaurant is getting good reviews.  The seared scallops I ordered at $24.95 last night were absolutely tasteless. They were cooked through, but barely seared.  Just terrible.  Six of them were sitting on a pile of butterbeans the same color as the un-seared scallops.  So not only was the dish tasteless, it looked drab as well.  The green salad at $7.95 was just that -- a pile of green lettuce leaves in a bowl --- to help carry the boring and tasteless theme even further.
author: Bridget S.

description:
This is the best seafood and best service in SF. Everyone who works there is very friendly and professional. David is great, and very funny. 

The fish and salads are really remarkable. Try the petrale sole and a decent salad like the Warm Goat Cheese salad or one of their specials like the Miguel's salad. Their fries are really good as well. 

If anyone asks me for seafood, I would take them here. It's expensive ($25 for an entree) but well worth it for the food and service. 

It's also one of the quieter restaurants. If you don't want a deafening din, try Hayes Street Grill.
author: John W.

description: Hayes Street Grill is very close the venues at civic center.  That is about as far as it goes. Service was quite good BUT. Supposed to be a fish place.  The Sole and potato was a lot of food, but not a lot of flavor.  The Sword Fish was not cooked and tough.  Not a very satisfying meal and very expensive.  I will look for another place in the area before I ever went back.
author: Ralph N.

description: We went to Hayes Street Grill after a Symphony Concert so we had two children, ages 7 and 9. Upon entering the hostess looked a mess. Her hair was flying all over and she could not have been more bored with her job. She kept us waiting even though we had reservations. We finally received our table 15 minutes late, sat down and just waited until finally the waitress came up. she was pleasant but clearly overworked.The menu for children is very limited. Our grandson, age 9, wanted the adult hamburger but received the child's hamburger, which he said was tasteless.. We had to ask for bread twice before we received ours. The used plates were not cleared until way after we had finished. this experience was a hugh disappointment so we cancelled our upcoming reservation and the hostess had no comments as to why. She clearly did not have training with how to treat customers.This restaurant is clearly a dinner restaurant, as we have eaten there numerous times and been very pleased but with this experience we will think twice and look elsewhere.
author: Kathleen R.

description: WATCH OUT!!!!!  Drinks by label range $16 EACH down to $12 EACH!  Will write restaurant to advise that waitpersons poltiely WARN customers!!!!  Horrible shock to get a bill for liquor twice the cost of a nice meal.  We feel terribly rippped off by this favortie restaurant of ours - for many, many years!  What gives?
author: Judith h.

description: I keep coming back hoping that they have improved and I am sadly disappointed. Went there for dinner with some friends on a Tues nite. I had the Argentinian steak. It tasted like it was cooked first in Argentina and then sent to the table. Not very hot, really tough meat. Pricey for what I got. My friend ordered the Halibut on a bed of veggies. The veggies looked like to were cooked earlier and reheated. We were the only ones in the place and every time I have been there I always get this elite st feel about the place.  Food for the price is not worth it.
author: J J.

description: Ohh man this place rules!!! I especially enjoy going to the farmers market on Saturdays and munchy grubin on a bacon and egg sandwich. Yeah man...hella good!
author: Devin R.

description: So I can't speak for much here considering all I had was a drink and French fries, but what I did have was great!! I could have eaten about 27orders of their French fries because they were sooooo good! Also, they gave us as much tarter sause and catchup as we wanted, which is a quality I love in fancy restaurants. The drinks were pretty good too but the bartender was great! He was so nice ad offered us "tasters" of a bunch of different things that he was making for other customers. What was supposed to be a quick stop in for a snack turned into a 2 hour chat, eat, drink fest! Anyplace you can do that is pretty good in my book!!
author: Tara T.

description: I judge a restaurant on quality of food, atmosphere and service.  A friend had recommended this restaurant as one of the best for seafood in SF.  We had arranged to meet at 7.45 pm.  I was about 10 minutes early.  Not a single staff person assisted me for 5 minutes.   I finally had to ask someone if he worked there, as I thought my friend may be in the other room.  I looked, he wasn't there.  Again, I was left as though I were unwelcome and felt that way as well.  Perhaps this arrogance stems from the restaurant dealing primarily to locals who frequent the opera, ballet and symphony which are nearby.  It was offensive and rude.  I mentioned nothing to my friend, as I did not want him to feel responsible.  The food was outstanding and the waiter was personable and timely.  However, given the arrogance, the lack of a maitre d', i.e. the lack of good management, I will never go to this restaurant again.
author: Jonathon C.

description: Party of seven and we were well-served, friendly and attentive, but not rushed. Room is a bit noisy for my taste. I had a very generous Caesar salad followed by their house-made (really?) boudin sausages, two large ones, with some frisee-type salad and a lot of truly excellent crispy fries. Chicken liver mousse was like ordinary chopped liver but finely processed, but tasty. Our friends raved about the fresh grilled sardines. Not cheap, but I think the prices are fair for the quality of the food, the size of the portions, and the service.
author: Mike L.

description: the cuisine is well cooked and fresh. not too much fluff or extra frill to get between you and the food.  the fish entrees highlight the menu.  it can get busy and hectic on opera/symphony nights, so plan ahead.
author: Vic A.

description: good breakfasts. eggs with jullienne onions=delicious. sides a little bland and the decor needs an update but the staff are easy going and the street is good for a stroll after you fill up on breakfast carb overload.
author: Adrienne P.

description: Hayes Street Grill has a great atmosphere and a good selection of fresh seafood.  Their swordfish was delicious and the salmon I had in the past was just as good.  I really like that you can pick a different sauce for your fish which comes on the side (adds great flavor to your order).  Their french fries are good too!  I never had a problem with the service at all.  This is a great spot!
author: Glen E.

description: warm goat cheese salad was excellent.  grilled yellowtail done medium was OK.  good place to go before opera/ballet/symphony.
author: Todd D.

description: Not a thing on the menu for vegetarians (I guess the word "Grill" in the title should have given it away...) but the waitstaff was helpful and creative enough to combine some side dishes and put together a decent meal.  The wine list was reasonable in price and relatively well selected and the proximity to the War Memorial Opera House (that's right, I said Opera House) can't be beat!
author: Anjali K.

description:
food 2; service 1; atmosphere 1; value 1.. only reason this is not a one star is because of the farmers market.

we love the farmers market booth - 5 stars so we wanted to try the restaurant and we were very disappointed.

my ono was poorly cooked but the waiter never came back to check so i couldn't send it back...

my husband's fish was much better.  desert (bread pudding) and the dessert wine was very good.

also - we ordered a bottle of champagne but they told us they were out but had the split.  but then they charged us for a full bottle???

for $120 - WAY OVERPRICED - especially when you want to send your food back.  go eat at a decent restaurant and take a taxi to the show or eat at absinthe next door.

one of the most disappointing meals i've had in the city.
author: Stacy N.

description: I found myself with 45 minutes to kill before a meeting in the civic center and an empty belly at an odd time of the early evening (I had skipped lunch) right after they'd opened. Wandered in and had a drink and a couple of starters at the bar for my late lunch/early dinner.  It was pretty good.  The oysters were nicely prepped and the only quibble with the grilled sardines is that they could have pulled out a few of the larger bones for me (I ate them anyway, but it was a bit pointy).  The sardines were nice and plump and well seasoned. The frissee salad on the side was just good, but not a big revelation about salad or anything.  The bread was hearty and good and all the servers seemed very swift and personable - my bartender even comped my espresso, a nice courtesy.  4.5 stars - reserving a half star since I didn't really have a full dinner and because my lemon drop needed a bit more lemon.   I plan to go  back soon for a date night, it seemed like a good spot for it.
author: jette s.

description:
ate here with my wife this week before attending a show at the orpheum.
service was excellent. our wine came quickly and was very good for the price (pinot). salad was delicious. i ordered soft shell crab...came loaded with butter and garlic, how could it not be good? wife ordered another fish special, good but not as good as the crab. couldn't resist a hot fudge sundae for dessert. 
maybe a tad pricey, but we very much enjoyed ourselves. place was packed as always, with noise somewhat a problem. would not hesitate to got there again when we are next in the city.
author: Joseph B.

description: my fish was raw in the middle.  am i supposed to be thanful for the big portion size?  will probably never eat here again.. but the fries were good.
author: Mary C.

description: This was the first date my fiance'  and I had. The food is amazing, the staff is great...an overall fabulous place to have dinner.  Also, they have specials during the week. Not inexpensive, but you can't match the fish preparation. Jon and I have made this our official "Special Dinner" spot, and go every chance we get. When you're there, try the sole with mushrooms, and the warm goat cheese salad...FANTASTIC!
author: Karen S.

description: Nice ambience and excellent service did not compensate for the mediocre main courses.  The chopped salad with beets was very good.  But the Uruguayan New York steak never should have been granted a visa to enter the country; I'd give it one out of 5 stars for flavor.  And my wife's halibut was similarly lacking in flavor, the sauce on the side notwithstanding.  The french fries were hot and tasty, but at these prices a vegetable of some sort should be included.  The waiter comped us a pleasant creme brulee -- said a table not ordering dessert would ruin his resume.  There were some very fairly priced wines on their list.  Great location for concert and opera goers, but I don't think we'll return.
author: Jay D.

description: this wasn't our first choice of restaurant, but so glad we ended up here.  menu was simple but food had a clear taste of what fresh food sould be.  organic ingredients and pretty reasonable in price.  nothing over seasoned or over sauced and portions are a good size and can even be shared.  service was nice, kind of an old world courtesy type of restaurant.  great experience!  definitely should try.
author: Food Is L.
